The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: THE PRESENT STATE OF EGYPT; Or, A new RELATION OF A LATE VOYAGE INTO THAT KINGDOM. Performed in the Years 1672. and 1673. By F. VANSLEB, R. D.
Wherein you have an exact and true Account of many Rare and Wonderful Particulars of that Ancient Kingdom.
Engli≈øhed by M. D. B. D.
LONDON; Printed by R. E. for John Starkey, at the Miter in Fleet-≈øtreet, near Temple-Bar. 1678.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
TO thee alone I recommend the peru≈øal of this Journal, which not only my ≈øelf, but ≈øome other judicious Per≈øons have thought worthy to appear in our Tongue, and among≈øt the Curio≈øo's of our Nation. The Author is well known to be a Man of Integrity, and one that ≈øcorns to impo≈øe upon the World an untruth; of which,
in this occa≈øion, nothing can tempt him to be guilty. If therefore ≈øome Particulars look with a ≈øtrange and unprobable Countenance, be not ≈øo un≈øociable in thy per≈øwa≈øion, as to reject what≈øoever thou ha≈øt no demon≈øtration to prove. A ridiculous Humour, and a pernicious Rule, which tends to deprive us of the benefit of many Knowledges, both in Divine and Humane Matters. It is unlikely that ≈øuch a Per≈øon of di≈øcretion and intere≈øt in the World, as he is known to be, ≈øhould ≈øo much forget his rea≈øon, as to
≈øub≈øcribe his Name to ≈øuch fal≈øhoods, as may be ea≈øily di≈øcovered at Rome, in the place of his ordinary abode. I confe≈øs ≈øome Ob≈øervations are trivial and ordinary, but others will prove ≈øatisfactory to ≈øuch worthy Souls as de≈øire to know the pa≈ø≈øages of the World, and Foreign Nations. This Country of Egypt hath heretofore been the riche≈øt Magazin of Learning, as well as of Provi≈øions: It hath flouri≈øhed in all Manual Arts, and the rare≈øt Sciences. No doubt but that there are yet to be ≈øeen ≈øome Monuments
of the Primitive Grandeur and Learning of the ancient Inhabitants: As therefore Van≈ølebius hath judg'd them worthy to be vi≈øited in his Travels, and afterwards of this account which he gives in Print, I think them not unworthy of thy knowledge; which thou maye≈øt perhaps improve in the interpretation of ≈øome ob≈øcure pa≈ø≈øages of holy Writ, and for other purpo≈øes according to thy Profe≈ø≈øion.

div.head: THE PRESENT STATE OF EGYPT: OR, A New Relation, or Journal, of the Travels of Father Van≈øleb through Egypt.

div.p: IN the Year 1671. about the 8th of May, I was at Mar≈øeilles, with an intention to ≈øail again into Egypt: for that purpo≈øe I found an opportunity, the Ship the Three Kings, Commanded by an Aged Captain named Artaut, was ready to depart for Alexandretta. I went aboard, and ≈øet ≈øail from the Port the 20th of the ≈øame Month, ≈øtrait towards Malta, where we remained five days, and after directed our Cour≈øe to Lernica, in the I≈øland of Cyprus, where the French Merchants make their abode; on the Sea-≈øide, looking towards the South, we arrived the 17th of June.

As ≈øoon as I ≈øet foot a≈øhore, I fell de≈øperately ≈øick of an ordinary Di≈øea≈øe to all Strangers, proceeding from the Infection of the Air, that is an Enemy to them: But my Di≈øtemper could not hinder me from going to Nico≈øia, the chief City of the I≈øland. When I felt my Malady increa≈øing every day, and the rather through the
dangerous Infection of the Plague which was then in the I≈øland, I re≈øolved to be carried to Tripoli in Syria, the neare≈øt and mo≈øt convenient Port where the French Nation hath a Con≈øul: While≈øt I was at Nico≈øia, Captain Artaut was departed with his Ship for Alexandretta, and the 26th of June I went aboard another Ship in the Haven of Lernica, and the next day with a favourable Wind we landed at Tripoli.

Though I had for≈øaken the infectious I≈øland, the di≈øea≈øe of my body for≈øook me not, but grew to that pa≈øs, that I prepar'd my ≈øelf, as Chri≈øtianity injoyns us, to leave the World: Neverthele≈øs, at the end of 35 days, my di≈øtemper being weary to torment me, ≈øuffer'd me to recover a little ≈øtrength; and though I was but weak, I went aboard a Ship bound for Alepo the fir≈øt of Septemb. arriv'd the 13th, and abode there four Months.
About the la≈øt of Decemb. I went to Dama≈øcus, where I remain'd a Month, and from thence to Seyda, where I was al≈øo two Months.

My purpo≈øe is not to give any account of the Curio≈øities of Lernica, of Nico≈øia, of Tripoli, of Alepo, of Dama≈øcus, and of Seyda. The≈øe Towns are ≈øufficiently known to all the World, by the many Relations already publi≈øhed of the Levant Countries: Be≈øides the ≈øhortne≈øs of the time of my abode there, together with the inconveniency of a Quartan Feaver which kept me company ≈øixteen Months, ≈øuffered me not to inquire into any ≈øuch matters. I ≈øhall therefore in this Treati≈øe give an account only of what Curio≈øities I have ≈øeen in Egypt, where during the ≈øpace of twenty Months I have had the lei≈øure and opportunities to take a view of the mo≈øt remarkable
things, with the greate≈øt exactne≈øs and care imaginable, which hath never been done of this famous and beautiful Country till now.

The 19th day of February, 1672. I took Ship at Seyda, a Town of Phoenicia, to ≈øail for Damietta in Egypt; but a contrary Wind ro≈øe, and brought us back to Seyda again, where we remain'd till the 16th of March. I went then aboard, and met with a favourable Gale, that drove us very happily to Bogas, which lies at the Mouth of the River Nilus.
I think it convenient, before we proceed, to give a general account and de≈øcription of Egypt, that the things that I ≈øhall hereafter mention may better be under≈øtood.

div.head: A General De≈øcription of Egypt.
div.p: CHam, one of the three Sons of Noah, had four Children Males, Cus, Mi≈øraim, named by the Arabs Beidar, Fut, and Canaan. Cus was the Father of the Aby≈ø≈øins, Mi≈øraim of the Copties and Nubians, Fut of the Africans, and Canaan of the Syrians, and their Neighbours.

Mi≈øraim after the Deluge, as Macri≈øi an Arabian Hi≈øtorian ≈øaith, pitcht upon Egypt, made there his abode, and left it and the Country, as far as the farthe≈øt part of Africa, to his Po≈øterity. He had likewi≈øe four Sons, I≈øchemun, Atrib, S√°, and Coptus, unto whom he divided the Land of Egypt in four equal parts; Coptus had all that tract of Land, from I≈øvan to the City of Coptus; to I≈øchemun he allotted the Country from that City to Menuf; to Atrib he gave the Heart and
middle of Egypt, now called Delta; and to S√° he appointed all the Continent, from the Province of Beheire as far as Barbary. They all builded Cities in their ≈øeveral Dominions, calling them by their own Names. We ≈øhall mention them in the ≈øequel of this Di≈øcour≈øe.

After the decea≈øe of their Father, the four Brothers were at variance about the Soveraignty, neither of them could endure a Partner. At la≈øt they re≈øolved to end their Controver≈øies by a Battle, which was to give the chief Command to the Victor.

Coptus the younge≈øt overcame all the re≈øt of his Brethren, and was acknowledg'd by them as their Chief Lord. He cho≈øe the City of Menuf, or Memphis, where his Father lived, as his Royal Seat. From this King Coptus all the Race of the Egyptians are now called Copties. Likewi≈øe from this fir≈øt King, the Greeks have given the name of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ to the Land of Egypt, by changing the K into G; which is the cu≈øtom not only of this Language, but al≈øo of the Arabian, as may appear by the words Nekkade, and Dunkala, written in Arabian with a K, and neverthele≈øs they are pronounced in di≈øcour≈øe Neggade, and Dungala, as if they were written with a G. They are the names of two Towns; the one in the Upper Egypt, and the other in Nubia.

The Moors and Copties, Natural Inhabitants of the Country, call it Ma≈ø≈ør, from Mi≈øraim the Son of Cham, and the Grand-child of Noah, who fir≈øt laid the Foundations of it after the Deluge. And from the ≈øame Mi≈øraim, the Turks have named it Mi≈ø≈øir, and the Jews Eretz Mi≈øraim, the Country of Mi≈øraim.

Egypt is ≈øcituate in Africa, according to the common and ordinary Opinion; neverthele≈øs, ≈øome of the Ancient Geographers have placed it part in Africa, and part in A≈øia, making the River Nilus as the Bounds between the≈øe two great parts of the World.

Egypt is bounded on the South with Nubia, and the la≈øt City of Egypt is I≈øvan, called by the Europeans Siene, which is commanded by the Bay of Girge; on the We≈øt it hath the Provinces of Vah, and Barca; and on the Ea≈øt are the De≈øarts that divide it from Pale≈øtina; and on the North is part of the Mediterranean Sea.

It ≈øtretcheth it ≈øelf in length from the City of I≈øvan to the Mouth of the River Nilus; at Ro≈øetta, in a ≈øtreight line, that is from South to North about five hundred and three≈øcore miles: it is not po≈ø≈øible to declare it preci≈øely, becau≈øe they are not wont to mea≈øure the Country by Miles, or by Leagues, but by the Camels Journeys only. I ≈øay here nothing, but according to the Relation of the Authors that have examin'd it.

It is divided, according to the accounts of the Divan, or Trea≈øury, into three parts: 1. Into Said, or the Upper Egypt, which begins at Sint, and extends as far as I≈øvan. 2. Into Vo≈øtani, or the middle Egypt, in re≈øpect of the Said and Cairo: And 3. Into Bahri, or Inferiour Egypt. The middle begins at Gize, a Village over again≈øt Boulac, and reaches as far as Momfallon‚ñ™ and the lower commenceth at Cairo, and includes Alexandria, and Damietta.

The Upper Egypt, or that part of it which is habitable and u≈øeful, is very narrow. In the wide≈øt part, a Hor≈øe in four hours may pa≈øs over it;
in ≈øome places it is not above three hours riding: and the Country in both ≈øides is wild, ≈øandy, and hilly.

I cannot give an exact account of its widene≈øs in the middle, but yet I am per≈øwaded it is not much larger nor wider than the higher part; for being ≈øcituated between both, Egypt begins to grow wider about Cairo; it mu≈øt needs follow, that the middle is not much wider than the upper part, unle≈øs it be about the Ca≈øcieflik of Fi√∫m, where Egypt in the middle begins to be wider; but yet I cannot give any exact account of it.
The Inferiour part is wider: The Inhabitants reckon about 70 miles from Damietta to Alexandria, the mo≈øt We≈øtern-Town upon the Sea-Coa≈øt.

A Learned Per≈øon of this Age, in a di≈øcour≈øe concerning the cau≈øes of the Inundation of Nilus, hath very well proved again≈øt the Ancient Philo≈øophers, that the lower Egypt hath always been, and is not a new gift of Nilus. He grounds his Opinion fir≈øt upon Homerus, who mentions the old City of Canopus, which was at one of the chief entrances into Nilus from the Sea. Secondly, upon the te≈øtimony of Mo≈øes and David, P≈ø. 77. who have mentioned the City of Tanis, where was Pharaoh's Court, and where God performed great Wonders.
Egypt was always governed by Kings, but the Royal Seats have not always continued the ≈øame, for the Conquerours have altered them according to their plea≈øure.

The fir≈øt Royal City, as Macri≈øi ≈øaith, was Am≈øus; but the Waters of the Deluge having ruined
it, the Po≈øterity of Noah built Menuf, or Memphis, which was the Seat of the Ancient Kings of the Race of Coptus, till Nabuchodonozor had ≈øack'd it. When Alexander the Great had built Alexandria, he made it the Principal City, where all the ≈øucceeding Kings of the Greeks made their Re≈øidence for nine hundred years, till the Arabians had taken Egypt, and made Fo≈øtat Metropolis. But when Giauher, the General of Meez le Din-alla had built Cairo, about the year of the Hegeira 362. he called it Dar il Memleke, that is the Royal Seat, which it hath been ever ≈øince.
Egypt hath been govern'd by three ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Mahumetan Princes, ≈øince the Arabians took it from the Greeks.

The fir≈øt were named Omara Ma≈ø≈ør, or Lords of Egypt, without any other Title. They were all Arabians, and Succe≈ø≈øors of Amru ibn il A≈øs, who was the fir≈øt Conquerour, and after to Abu il Fevares, the la≈øt of that Race. We reckon one hundred and twelve Princes of Egypt, during the ≈øpace of 337 Years, ≈øeven Months, and twenty Days. Their Conque≈øt happen'd about twenty years after the Hegeira, and ended in the year 358. They all dwelt at Fo≈øtat Ma≈ø≈øer, or thereabouts.

The ≈øecond Race of the Arabians were called Caliphs. They began to take that Title, when General Abuha≈ø≈øein Giauher had built Cairo by the Order of Meez le Din-alba, who was then Prince of Barbary, and Conquer'd Egypt, and took it from the Arabians. Egypt was afterwards govern'd by its Caliphs about 108 Years, 4 Months, and 22 Days; that is, to the death of Adet le
Din-alla, who was the la≈øt and Eleventh Caliph.
The third ≈øort, named Sultans or Soldans, ≈øucceeded immediately after; of them there have been of four Nations.
The fir≈øt, who was the Po≈øterity of a certain Eijub, were called Sultans Curdes.

The ≈øecond came from beyond the Seas, & were named Mamaluk Turks, becau≈øe they had been before Slaves, and ≈øold by the Merchants of Con≈øtantinople to the Kings of Egypt, who cau≈øed them to be brought up and in≈øtructed in all Martial Di≈øcipline. When the King was dead, one of the≈øe Slaves was cho≈øen to ≈øucceed in the Throne.

The third ≈øort were ≈øtiled Mamaluks Circa≈ø≈øians, becau≈øe they came originally from Circa≈ø≈øia, and were brought thither by the Merchants as the former, and ≈øold al≈øo as Slaves to the Kings of Egypt, who cau≈øed them to be al≈øo train'd up as the former, unto whom they ≈øucceeded in the Regal Dignity and Command.

The fourth ≈øort, who are now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, are the Sultans of the Race of Ottoman, who overcame the Circa≈ø≈øian Sultans in the year 922. of the Hegeira; for Sultan Selim Conquer'd this Kingdom in the year 1517.
Egypt is inhabited at pre≈øent by Copties, Moors, Arabians, Turks, Greeks, Jews, and Franks, and other ≈øtrange Nations; but as they are not numerous, they de≈øerve not to be mentioned.
The Copties or Copts are the Natural Inhabitants of the Country, thus called, as we have already ≈øaid, of Coptus the Son of Mi≈øraim, who was King of Egypt after his Father.

The Moors, who are named by the Arabians Aulad il Arab, or Children of the Arabians, are
likewi≈øe as well as the Copties de≈øcended from the ≈øame Father, but they are become Mahumetans, and it may be ≈øince they have Conquered Egypt, there are ≈øome among≈øt them yet that are come from the Arabians.

The Arabians are a people of Arabia, and though they live in Egypt, they have no communication with the Moors, who are originally of the Country. They are of many differing Generations, govern'd by their ≈øeveral Chieftains, whom I ≈øhall mention in the ≈øequel of this di≈øcour≈øe.
The Turks have e≈øtabli≈øh'd them≈øelves there ≈øince Sultan Selimus conquer'd Egypt. The≈øe govern the Country, defend it, and act in all Offices of State.

The Greeks that live there now, and that make yet profe≈ø≈øion of the Chri≈øtian Religion, have been invited thither by the great Trade of Egypt; for there is no ≈øign of the Ancient Greeks, who e≈øtabli≈øh'd them≈øelves there when Alexander the Great conquer'd Egypt; if there be any, they are mingled with the Copties, and are called by their names.

And becau≈øe the Greeki≈øh Emperours that followed the Council of Chalcedonia were glad to incourage a Party in Egypt again≈øt the Copties, ≈øworn Enemies of that Council, they protected there the Greeks that went thither from Greece, that ≈øubmitted to that Council, and gave them means to e≈øtabli≈øh them≈øelves in this Kingdom; ≈øince that time the Greeki≈øh Religion hath been there profe≈ø≈øed.

The Jews have always lived there; at pre≈øent they are very numerous, and are in great repute,
chiefly at Cairo, and in the Maritime Towns: but unle≈øs it be in ≈øuch places there are none to be found, for if their occa≈øions call them into the Country, they u≈øually di≈øgui≈øe and hide them≈øelves; for when the Country-people find them out, they abu≈øe and affront them ≈øtrangely.

The Copties at pre≈øent in Egypt are not numerous, in compari≈øon of what they have been heretofore; for in the days of Amru ibn il A≈ø≈ø, who took this Country from the Greeks, there was of this Nation ≈øix hundred thou≈øand that paid him Tribute: but now, according to the relation of their own Patriarch, there is ≈øcarce ten or fifteen thou≈øand. One of the Cau≈øes of this decrea≈øe, was their con≈øtancy in the Chri≈øtian Religion, in the time of the Romans; their Governours were ≈øo furious again≈øt them for that rea≈øon, that they have put to death millions at a time: for the Hi≈øtories tell us of the Governour under Diocle≈øian the Emperour, who ma≈ø≈øacred in one night, at Chri≈øtmas, four≈øcore thou≈øand; who are buried upon Mount Achmim in the Upper Egypt. And at another time near I≈øna, either the ≈øame Governour, or another, put to death ≈øo many that they were not to be numbred, for they covered four≈øcore Fiddans, or Furlongs, with their dead martyr'd bodies: The Fiddan in Egypt contains 400 Ca≈ø≈øabs or Yards, every Yard is 6 Cubits.

Another Cau≈øe of their decrea≈øe in the days of the Chri≈øtian Emperours, was their ob≈øtinacy in maintaining the Errour of Dio≈øcorus, one of their Patriarchs, concerning one Nature, one Will, and Per≈øon in Je≈øus Chri≈øt, which cau≈øed them to ≈øuffer almo≈øt the ≈øame de≈øtructions as
they had done formerly under the Heathen Emperours for the Chri≈øtian Faith: For when the Greek Emperours offered to force them to leave the Errour of Dio≈øcorus, and to embrace the Faith e≈øtabli≈øhed in the Council of Chalcedone, and when they found them di≈øobedient and inflexible; they made u≈øe of the Sword to compa≈øs their de≈øign. Among≈øt the re≈øt the Emperour Ju≈øtinian, as Macriz ≈øaith in his Hi≈øtory of the Patriarchs, cau≈øed two hundred thou≈øand Copties to be killed at Alexandria for that very purpo≈øe. I ≈øhall not mention the Cruelties of the other Emperours his Succe≈ø≈øors exerci≈øed upon them. So that ≈øuch as ≈øurvived after ≈øuch like Ma≈ø≈øacres, when they ≈øaw the danger that attended the profe≈ø≈øion of this Opinion, and of appearing in the Cities, they retreated into the wilderne≈øs, or withdrew them≈øelves into the Mona≈øteries, in de≈øpair, to lead a Mona≈øtical life, without marriage, or thinking to propagate their Nation.

After this, the Mahometan Kings and Princes, that have governed Egypt ≈øince the Chri≈øtian Emperours, when they found them rebellious again≈øt their Government, have not ≈øpared them. They have killed the Chief, ≈øold for Slaves the Wives and Children of others, ≈øo that the weaker ≈øort have been forc'd to turn Mahometans. By this means, after ≈øo many evils, this Nation is reduced to a very ≈ømall number.
They were anciently Heathens, every City had a God to adore.

Abu≈øir, or the old Bu≈øiris, wor≈øhipped a Calf. Alexandria, the ancient Racotis, adored Serapis of Stone. Achmim, which is the old Panos, acknowledged Apollo. Bana wor≈øhipped a Dog. Ba≈ø≈øa,
or the old Buba≈øtis, had for God a Lion of Stone. Eida adored Serapis. I≈øchemunein, which is the ancient Hermopolis, wor≈øhipped a Man of Stone. I≈øvan, called by the Copties Sevan, reverenced the Tree Lebaca. Cous wor≈øhipped the Moon and Stars. Mindadi the Fig-tree of Pharaoh. Memphis a Calf. Atrib, or the old Atribis, adored a Calf of Stone. Semennut, which is the ancient Sebennis, wor≈øhipped a Calf of Bra≈øs. Sa a Hog of Stone. Tuba had a re≈øpect for the Water and all that is therein. I have taken all the≈øe particulars out of an old Manu≈øcript in Arabick, that I have ≈øeen in the Mona≈øtry of S. Anthony.

But ≈øince the coming of our Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt, they have been ≈øome of the fir≈øt that have embraced the Chri≈øtian Religion, at the preaching of the Apo≈øtle S. Mark. They have continued in the right Faith, till Dio≈øcorus their Patriarch fell into this Here≈øie, That in Je≈øus Chri≈øt there was but one Nature, one Sub≈øtance, one Will, and one Operation. This Errour with its Author was condemned in the Council of Chalcedone, and ≈øuch as receive it are counted as Hereticks by the Church of Rome; therefore they have been per≈øecuted by the Chri≈øtian Emperours in times pa≈øt.

But becau≈øe I treat more amply of their Belief and Eccle≈øia≈øtical Ceremonies in another Book named the Church of Alexandria, which I compo≈øed for that purpo≈øe when I was at Cairo, therefore I will ≈øay no more at pre≈øent.

The Egyptians have often changed their Language. The fir≈øt and ancient Language of the Country was that of the Copties, which was u≈øed
all the time that their Kings reigned in Egypt. But when Alexander the Great had ≈øubdued that Country, they were forced to learn the Speech of their Conquerour, which was the Greek, ≈øince commonly ≈øpoken in Egypt above nine hundred years, till the Arabians had driven away the Greeks. They brought in the Arabian Tongue, which is now commonly u≈øed.

div.head: Of Saida, or the Upper Egypt.
div.p: SAid in Arabick ≈øignifies a Place or a Country, higher and above another: Therefore becau≈øe the Upper Egypt is higher and above the Lower, it bears this Name. The Arabians call it yet Vogh il ard, or the Face of the Country, being ≈øituate on the South of Cairo. The Hogia's or Prie≈øts of Mahomet turn that way their Faces, when they begin to call the Congregation to Prayers, becau≈øe Mecha is towards the South, in re≈øpect of all the Territories of the Ottoman Empire.

Giafer ibn Daleb, an Arabian Hi≈øtorian, ≈øaith, that it is twelve days journey long, as they march with Camels in Egypt; but it is not above four Hours travelling from ≈øide to ≈øide in the Country that is inhabited: for if we ≈øhould comprehend in the breadth the Mountains of Sand on the Ea≈øt and We≈øt, it is a great deal broader than we have ≈øaid.

The City of I≈øvan is the farthe≈øt Confine towards the South, which is in the Ca≈øcieflick of Ibr√Æm. On the Ea≈øt it ≈øtretcheth forth as far as the Red-≈øea, and on the We≈øt as far as the Province of Vah.
The Chief City heretofore was H√∫, whereof I ≈øhall ≈øpeak hereafter more at large; but now the Capital City is Girge, where lives the Sangiac-Bey that governs it.

Anciently certain Princes ruled here in the time of the Arabians, called in their Language Omara Said. They dwelt then at H√∫, which is, the old Dio≈øpolis, ≈øurnamed the Upper, di≈øtant from Girg√© about a days journey, and on the ≈øame ≈øide of the River Nilus as we go up: But when Girg√© was inlarg'd by time, and H√∫ fell to decay, the Princes of Said ≈øettled their abode at Girg√©, which hath been always the Chief City ≈øince that time till now.
About fifty years ago the Turks drove away from thence tho≈øe Arabian Princes, and in their ≈øtead they put the Sangiac-Beys, who are Natural Turks; the fir≈øt was named Soliman-Gianballat.

This puts me in mind of a mi≈øtake of James Albertus in his di≈øcour≈øe of Egypt; he ≈øaith, that Said was about 60 years ago a Kingdom of it ≈øelf, to which the Grand Seignior did u≈øually a≈ø≈øign a Pacha. This Errour hath no ground: Fir≈øt, becau≈øe in all the Hi≈øtories, ancient and new, of the Arabians, the Province of Said is never nam'd Memleke a Kingdom, nor Pachalick the Government of a Pacha, but only Arde Said, i. e. the Country of Said; and its Rulers, were not nam'd Kings, or Pachas, but only Omara Said, or Princes of Said. Secondly, becau≈øe all the Governours of the Turki≈øh Race, who have govern'd it ≈øince the driving out of the Arabian Princes, are never call'd in the Regi≈øters of the Divan, nor of the common people, otherwi≈øe than Sangiac-Beys, two only excepted, who were
named Pachas, becau≈øe they had been Pachas before they were the Governours of this Province; and though they did bear this Title, they were always ≈øubject to the Pachas of Grand Cairo.

It is certain, the Province of Said is very large; and if it were all inhabited, and all manur'd, as is the lower Egypt, its Bey might contend with the Pacha of Cairo for pre-eminence. They have often endeavour'd to free them≈øelves from his Command, but becau≈øe the inhabited Country is very narrow, and the Villages and Towns ruinated, they could never ≈øucceed in their de≈øign.

Neverthele≈øs, the Government is much like that of the Pachas of Cairo, for he hath the ≈øame Officers to attend him, a Chiaoux-Bachi, or a Captain of the Chiaoux, an Interpreter, an Aga of the Janizaries, and other Aga's of the Military Orders, named in their Language Boulouks, who are taken out of the Souldiery of Cairo, and are paid out of the Rever≈øions of the Divan. He hath likewi≈øe his Divan Catebi, or Chancellour; and in truth, he hath all the Priviledges of a Pacha, but he hath not the Title, nor the Quality, nor ever had.

This Bey gives to the Pacha of Cairo, as James Albertus ≈øaith, forty Pur≈øes every year; be≈øides, he ≈øends him fifty Hor≈øes, fifty Mules, and one hundred Camels. He gives al≈øo ten Pur≈øes to his Kehaja, and his Aga: And for the Tax of his Country, he pays to the Divan of Cairo one hundred and fifty Ardebs of Wheat; and when he gives other Grain, he delivers one Ardeb and a half, in≈øtead of one Ardeb of Wheat; and be≈øides, he ≈øends four hundred and four≈øcore
Pur≈øes, each Pur≈øe containing five hundred Crowns: And when he is in the la≈øt year of his Government, he is bound to cau≈øe all the Lands of his Government to be ≈øown which the River hath watered, and for his Expences the Divan gives him an Allowance.

div.head: Of the Ca≈øciefs of Egypt.
div.p: IN regard the word Ca≈øcief is often repeated in this Treati≈øe, I have thought it needful, before I proceed any farther in the general de≈øcription of Egypt, to mention its Origine, and the number and imployment of the Ca≈øciefs: By this means we ≈øhall ≈øee that all Egypt is divided into little Provinces, or Governments.

The word Ca≈øcief proceeds from the Arabik Jickscif, which ≈øignifies to di≈øcover a thing; becau≈øe their Ancient Office was to vi≈øit their Province and Juri≈ødiction, to find out the Arabians, and Thieves, and Per≈øons of an ill life, and to puni≈øh them: But now their Power and Riches increa≈øing, they have rented the Incomes of their Provinces without altering their Names; ≈øo that at this time they are the Petty-Governours of Egypt, and are in number ≈øix and thirty.

In the upper Egypt are twenty four, namely of Sint, where the upper Egypt begins, of Abutig, of Temeh, of Tahta, of Gezire, of Sobaitg, of Min≈øcie, of Tuh il e≈ø≈øirat, of Girg√©, where the Vali is the Ca≈øcief: All the≈øe are on the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, before you come to Girg√©.

The≈øe following are likewi≈øe on the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus; but beyond Girge, namely, the Ca≈øciefs
of Berdis, of Fer≈øciut, of Hu, of Bahgiura, of Jarbuksas, of Arment, and of I≈øne.

The≈øe following re≈øide on the Ea≈øt-part of Nilus; namely, the Ca≈øciefs of Scierkabuet, of Achmin, of Scierkmerg, of Limbir ve il cheijam, of Scierkfau, of Cous, of Kenne, of Luxorein, and of Ibrim.

Six dwell in the middle Egypt; namely, at Momfallot, where the Ca≈øcief Commands the other of Vah; there is the Ca≈øcief of I≈øchmunein that dwells at Minie, the Ca≈øciefs of Behne≈øe, of Fium, of Gize: All the≈øe are at the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus; and on the Ea≈øt there is only the Ca≈øcief of Atfieh, in the middle of Egypt.

There are al≈øo ≈øix in the lower Egypt; namely, of Menuf, of Garbie, which two Provinces are in the I≈øle of Delta. The Ca≈øcief of Beheire re≈øides in the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, as we go to Gize, over again≈øt Cairo. This Province reaches as far as Alexandria, and includes the little Ca≈øcief of Tarane that depends upon it. There is likewi≈øe the Ca≈øcief of Kel, Jub, in the ≈øame ≈øide as Cairo, and the Ca≈øcief of Man≈øoura on the ≈øame hand, near the Province of Keliub, and the Ca≈øcief of Bilbeis, which is on the ≈øide of Crand Cairo.

All the Ca≈øciefs of the inferiour Egypt, and ≈øome al≈øo of the middle, never abide in the Towns of their Juri≈ødictions, for the mo≈øt part, but only eight or nine Months, from January till Augu≈øt. When Nilus begins to overflow the Banks, then they retreat to Cairo, where they dwell till the Waters are gone, and that the Ber≈øim, or Sinfoin, is grown high enough to feed their Hor≈øes.

When the Governours are gone out of their
Towns, there is no a≈ø≈øurance for a Traveller, for the Arabians and Thieves having no body to fear in the quarter, they watch for their prey in the pa≈ø≈øages and high-ways; ≈øo it is not ≈øafe to travel by Land, till they be return'd to their Juri≈ødictions again, which commonly happens at the Fea≈øt of the Epiphany of the Copties.

They ob≈øerve this order in going from Cairo; the Ca≈øcief of Garbie departs the next day after the Epiphany, of Menuf, the day following; the third day the Ca≈øcief of Beheire, the fourth of Man≈øoura, the fifth of Atfieh, the ≈øixth of Keliub, the ≈øeventh goes away Lord of Gize. They all come back again to Cairo, in the Month of Augu≈øt, in the ≈øame order.
This is the Tax that was commonly paid in the year 1634. as James Albertus ≈øaith; I know not whether there is any alteration.

The Ca≈øcief of Beheire pays to the Pacha 30 Pur≈øes, to his Kehaja and Agas ≈øix Pur≈øes, and to the Divan or Trea≈øury of the Grand Seignior, yearly in four portions, four hundred and four≈øcore Pur≈øes. He hath at his Command two hundred men, half Spahis, and half Metferracas; and be≈øides the≈øe, he hires many more to give a check to the Arabians. He is bound to make the water of the River to run into Alexandria, through the Calitz or Conduit of Cleopatra, which conveys the water from a Village called Latf; he is bound al≈øo to entertain Souldiers all along the Channel, to ≈øee that the water be not cut off: he is al≈øo bound to cau≈øe it to be clean≈øed at his own charges. In his Province are one hundred three≈øcore and ten Towns and Villages.

The Ca≈øcief of Menuf pays to the Pacha five
and twenty Pur≈øes, to his Kehaja and Agas four, and to the Divan two hundred four≈øcore and ≈øixteen; and the Divan of Cairo is obliged to entertain one hundred Spahis to keep his Country.

The Ca≈øcief of Garbia pays to the Pacha, as I under≈øtood when I was at Cairo, one and thirty Pur≈øes; two to his Kehaja, to the Emir Achour, a great Officer, eighteen thou≈øand Medins; and in all, one hundred and twenty Pur≈øes. The Divan of Cairo allows him one hundred and fifty Souldiers; he lives at Mohelle Kebire, or the Great Mohelle, the Chief Town of the Province.

The Ca≈øcief of Man≈øoura, as James Albertus ≈øaith, gives to the Pacha five and twenty Pur≈øes, four to his Kehaja and Agas, and to the Divan two hundred four≈øcore and ≈øixteen. The Divan entertains a hundred Souldiers in his Province, and keeps as many more.

The Ca≈øcief of Keliub, which was the old Calliope, ≈øcituated on the Ea≈øt-≈øide of the River Nilus, as Cairo, pays to the Pacha five and twenty Pur≈øes, four to his Kehaja and Agas, and to the Divan two hundred four≈øcore and ≈øixteen. The Divan keeps for him, as for the former, a hundred Souldiers.

When the Ca≈øcief receives the Coftan, or his Commi≈ø≈øion from the Pacha, he ≈øpends about five hundred Crowns. All ≈øuch per≈øons as have been Chiaoux and Metferracas may pretend to this Office: The≈øe Metferracas, among≈øt the Turks, are a Noble kind of Hor≈øemen.

div.head: Of the Sea≈øons of Egypt.
div.p: THough the Copties are much de≈øpi≈øed by all the Mahumetans, they are e≈øteem'd becau≈øe of the computation of the time; for the Mahumetans in all their actions, either private or publick, never make u≈øe of their own computation, but of that of the Copties, as the ju≈øte≈øt and the be≈øt for their bu≈øine≈øs: For example, they ≈øay not, that the Rains fall ≈øuch and ≈øuch a day of their Month, but ≈øuch a day of the Month of the Copties. They reckon Ea≈øter, called Cam≈øins, not after their Beiram, but according to the Ea≈øter of the Copties: So that they govern all their actions, and all their publick affairs, not according to their own, but according to the Copties Calendar.
The Copties divide thus the Sea≈øons of the Year: They reckon the Autumns, called by the Arabians il Charif, from the 15th day of the Month Tot, or September, till the 15th of Kijahak, or December.
Winter, named by them il Scitte, begins on the 15th day of December, and ends on the 15th day of Baramhat, or March.
The Spring, called by them il Auvel rebie, begins on the 15th day of March, and ends the 15th day of Baoni, or June.
The Summer on the 15th day of June, and ends the 15th day of the Month Tot, or September: they reckon for every Sea≈øon ju≈øt three Months.

They begin the year the 8th day of September, according to the Gregorian ≈øtile, or on the 28th of Augu≈øt, according to the Calendar of the Greeks.
They reckon this pre≈øent year 1672. to be the 1398. year ≈øince the Vice-Roy of Diocle≈øian ma≈ø≈øacred ≈øo many Martyrs, at which time they begin their computation.
The≈øe are the names of their Months, and the days in which they begin.

list.item: Tot, or September, begins the 8th day of ours.
Babe, or October, begins the‚Äîof ours.
Hatur, or November, begins the‚Äîof ours.
Kijahak, or December, begins the 7th of ours.
Tube, or January, begins the 6th of ours.
Am≈øcir, or February, begins the 4th of ours.
Baramhat, or March, begins the 7th of ours.
Bermude, or April, begins the 6th of ours.
Be≈øciens, or May, begins the 6th of ours.
Baoni, or June, begins the 5th of ours.
Abib, or July, begins the 5th of ours.
Me≈ø≈ør, or Augu≈øt, begins the fir≈øt day of ours.

div.p: Every Month hath 30 days, which make up 360. and becau≈øe there wants yet five to compleat the year, they add the five at the end of all, and call them Epagomene, which ≈øignifies added, to make up the full year.

The mo≈øt temperate Sea≈øon hath ≈øomething of the Spring and the Autumn; which two Sea≈øons cannot well be di≈øtingui≈øhed in Egypt. Now the mild Weather begins in the Month of September, then the people begin to breath the fre≈øh air; but as about this time the Fields are all drown'd in water, and that there is no walking up and down by Land, the abode is not then ≈øo plea≈øant till the middle of November: Then the Country is dry, the Ways are free, the Waters are run into their u≈øual Currents, the Birds are to be taken by the Fowler, the Air is plea≈øant,
the heat of the Sun is ≈øupportable, the Fields grow green, and the ≈øweet and fre≈øh Gales blow every where. In ≈øhort, the Sea≈øon is then very plea≈øant, and continues ≈øo till the middle of April.

The cold ≈øea≈øon, which is an≈øwerable to our Winter, begins about the middle of December: It is a delightful time, unle≈øs in the ≈øeven days which the Arabians call Berd il agiuz, or the cold of the old Hag; they begin about the 7th of February, and continue till the 14th; the Mornings are then very cold, the Sky is cloudy, the Rains fall, and the Winds are commonly very boi≈øterous.

Though the Winter is there very mild, per≈øons of E≈øtate wear Furr'd Gowns, from the Month of November, till the Month of March, not becau≈øe of any great cold, for there is ≈øcarce any, but becau≈øe then the Weather is variable, and they fear to be incommoded with the di≈øtempers which this changeable weather produceth.

The Summer is the wor≈øt and mo≈øt trouble≈øom ≈øea≈øon, becau≈øe of the exce≈ø≈øive heats of the hot Winds, and the dangerous di≈øea≈øes that are rife, chiefly at that time, which the Egyptians call Cam≈øins, which we name Ea≈øter. This dangerous ≈øea≈øon begins about the Ea≈øter-Monday of the Copties, and ends at their Whit≈øon-Monday. About this time the Winds, called by the Arabians Meri≈ø≈øi, are boi≈øterous; they are ≈øo hot and trouble≈øome, that they are ready to ≈øtifle the breath, and they rai≈øe in the Air ≈øo much Straw and Sand, that the Sky is darkned. This Sand is ≈øo ≈øubtil, that it penetrates through every little chink and hole.

About this time Malignant Fevers commonly reign, Dy≈øenteries, and many other Di≈øea≈øes; the lea≈øt is incurable, if the nece≈ø≈øary Remedies be not applied in time: And when the≈øe winds blow, the bodies that are not di≈øtemper'd, are ca≈øt down, and not well.

The≈øe Southerly winds blow not every day in this ≈øea≈øon, nor every year in the ≈øame manner and fury; for in the year 1672. they blew but twelve times, and the next year but twice, and that very moderately; other fre≈øher and whole≈øomer winds blew the re≈øt of the time. It is not po≈ø≈øible to expre≈øs the joy of the people, when the≈øe Southerly winds favour them, and are mild.

The ordinary time of Rains and Winds, which might be compared with our Autumn, begins in the Month of December, and continues till January, and February; though at Ro≈øetta, and Alexandria, the Rains fall at other times, becau≈øe of the Seas that are ≈øo near. At the Eve of the Penteco≈øt, in the year 1672. the weather was full of Rain at Ro≈øetta, and the next day followed a very thick Mi≈øt. On the 24th day of November, in the ≈øame year, the Rains fell very moderately at Cairo; the Sky was ob≈øcure, and full of wind; and on the tenth, eleventh, fourteenth and fifteenth in the ≈øame Month, very furious Rains fell. By this you may ≈øee, that it is a great errour to ≈øay, that it never Rains in Egypt.

I have often ≈øeen in my Travels, that the weather hath been ≈øo mi≈øty and moi≈øt, that my Beard and Cloaths have been ≈øo wet, that a ≈øhowre of Rain could not have wetted them more; and that which is wonderful is, that this
happened in a ≈øea≈øon that none ever expected it. During ≈øeveral mornings in the Month of April, in the year 1672. in my travelling from Damietta to Cairo, the ≈øame thing happen'd to me in the Month of June at Ro≈øetta; and in the Month of September at Bene≈øuef; and in October, in my return from the Mona≈øtery of S. Anthony.

The≈øe wet Mi≈øts are more frequent about Cairo, than in other places. They begin u≈øually about the Month of November, before the ri≈øing of the Sun, and continue all the Winter. Some happen in other ≈øea≈øons of the year, and many times in Summer, as I have taken notice in the year 1672. in the beginning of Augu≈øt, in my return back from Fium to Mocanan, a Village about four hours travelling from Cairo, I ≈øaw upon the Town ≈øo thick a Mi≈øt, that I could not di≈øcover it, nor the Pyramids that are near, though the Air was clear where I ≈øtood.

In all the ≈øea≈øons of the year, when the nights are ≈øerene, there is ≈øo much Dew that falls, that it may very well be taken for a little ≈øhowre; but when the Sky is cloudy, there falls no Dew. Were it not for the≈øe Dews, there would be no Gra≈øs nor Corn, the Trees would bear no Fruit, the wild Bea≈øts in the De≈øarts could not live where there are no Fountains nor Rivers, and where the Rains fall but ≈øeldom. Thunders are not often heard; in all the time that I was in Egypt, I heard this noi≈øe but twice, on the fir≈øt day of January, and on the fourth of May, 1673.

I have already ≈øpoken of the two chief Winds that blow in Egypt, Meri≈ø≈øi and Maltem. I mu≈øt further take notice, that not only the Southern Winds are named Meri≈ø≈øi, but al≈øo the Ea≈øtern.
They blow commonly twice every year; at Ea≈øter, called (as I have already ≈øaid) Cam≈øin; and from the Month of November, till the middle of February. They are helpful to tho≈øe that travel down the River Nilus, and to the Ships that ≈øail from the Indies and Arabia through the Red-Sea to Sues: But they are contrary to tho≈øe that go up the River: From hence it ≈øometimes happens, that Travellers are 30 days going up from Cairo to Girge, which Voyage is ea≈øily performed in 8 or 10 days when the other winds blow.

The Winds called Maltem or Teij√°b are We≈øterly Winds: They begin about twelve days before the Rain falls, and la≈øt till the Month of November; during that time ≈øcarce any other Wind blows. The Winds called Meri≈ø≈øi are hot, they ≈øpoil the Corn, and are hurtful to every thing; but the≈øe nouri≈øh and refre≈øh, not only the Corn, but are comfortable to Man and Bea≈øt, for they are cooling, and give ≈øtrength.

They ≈øtop the Mouth of the River, and cau≈øe the Waves to ≈øend back the water of Nilus, which makes it to ≈øtop and ≈øwell over the Banks to water the Earth, and fill all the Channels with water. In their ≈øea≈øons they begin to blow about Noon, and continue till midnight; but between midnight, and the Noon of the next day, they ≈øeldom blow, or very faintly.

div.head: The De≈øcription of the Egyptians.
div.p:
THe Egyptians generally are of an Olive-colour, and the farther their Country is di≈øtant from Cairo towards the South, their skin is
the more tawny; ≈øuch as live next to Nubia are all blacki≈øh, as the Nubians.

Their ordinary Vices are Idlene≈øs and Cowardi≈øe, which is ≈øo natural to them, that they are all toucht with them, whether they be Mores or Copties: Their ordinary imployment every day is to ≈ømoak Tobacco, and drink Coffee, to ≈øleep, or lye in a place idle, or ≈øit talking together. They are very ignorant in all manner of Sciences and Knowledges; they are very proud and vain-glorious; and though they all know that they have lo≈øt their Nobility, their Country, all knowledge and exerci≈øe of Arms, their Language, their chief Books, and publick Hi≈øtories, and that in≈øtead of a famous and valiant Nation that they were heretofore, they are become meer Slaves, an odious and a contemptible people; neverthele≈øs they are ≈øo proud, as to think that they have need of nothing. They are di≈øplea≈øed when we Francs advi≈øe them to ≈øend their Children into our Country to learn the Arts and Sciences, and to under≈øtand how we live and behave our ≈øelves.

The common people are Thieves, Lyars, treacherous, and ≈øo greedy of gain, that for the love of a Meidin they would kill their own Fathers. They are very negligent of their bu≈øine≈øs, and changeable, trouble≈øome in di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øo uncon≈øtant in their promi≈øes, that there is no heed to be taken of their words, nor of their Oaths. In a word, they are very proper to be imployed in all evil actions; my Conver≈øation with men of that Nation of all ≈øorts, hath cau≈øed me to di≈øcover them to the bottom.

The Women of the Country are u≈øually of a
low ≈øtature, of a brown Complexion, all their Beauty con≈øi≈øts in a lively eye; their di≈øcour≈øes are trouble≈øome, and their cloathing is not hand≈øom. The Wives of the better ≈øort, brought from other parts of Turkie, are better bred, and more plea≈øing in all re≈øpects.

div.head: Of the River Nilus.
div.p: THe di≈øcovery of the Springs of Nilus, which hath cau≈øed ≈øo many Di≈øputes among≈øt the Ancient Philo≈øophers, and for which ≈øome great Per≈øons were at va≈øt expences without any ≈øucce≈øs, ≈øeems to have been left to the Portugue≈øes, who have found them out in our Age.

Father Telles, a Je≈øuite, ≈øaith in his Hi≈øtory of Ethiopia, printed at Lisbon, That in the Kingdom of Gojam, which is about 12 Degrees from the Equinoctial towards the We≈øt, and in the Province of Sacahala, inhabited by the Agaus in a Field of no great extent, incompa≈ø≈øed about with many high Mountains, there is a little Lake over which one may ca≈øt a ≈øtone, full of Bu≈øhes and low Trees, whereof the Roots are ≈øo thick and intangled, that in Summer one may walk upon them. In the middle of this Lake are two great and deep Fountains very near together; from hence i≈ø≈øues out a clear water that runs under the≈øe Bu≈øhes and low Trees in two ≈øeveral Channels: towards the Ea≈øt, and about the di≈øtance of a Musket-≈øhot, they turn to the North; about half a mile from thence there appears a great deal of water, and a con≈øiderable River, into which runs many other ≈øtreams; and about 15 miles from thence, it receives
another bigger water, called Gema, which lo≈øeth then its name: a little farther, turning towards the Ea≈øt, it receives al≈øo two other con≈øiderable ≈øtreams, called Kelti and Branti; near this place is the fir≈øt fall of the River: Not much farther, in running towards the Ea≈øt, it enters into the Lake of the Aby≈ø≈øins, named Bahr Dembea, or the Sea of Dembea: when it is pa≈øt through, without mingling its waters with the waters of the Lake, it receives many other Rivers very great; and namely, the River Tekeze near Egypt.

As ≈øoon as Nilus is out of the Lake Dembea, it turns to the South-Ea≈øt, leaving at the left hand the Kingdoms of Beg-amidr, of Amhara, of Voleca; afterwards running to the South, it hath upon the South-Ea≈øt the Kingdom of Sauva; afterwards turning again to the Ea≈øt-North-Ea≈øt, it hath on the South-≈øide Ganz, Gafata, and Bizamo, and pa≈ø≈øeth through the Countries of Gonga and Gafre, and a little farther by Fa≈øcalo, then it enters into the Country of Funch, or Nubia, and from thence runs into Egypt, as Father Telles affirms.

We mu≈øt con≈øider be≈øides, that when Nilus is fallen down the la≈øt Cataract near I≈øvan, it runs from the South to the North very ≈ølowly, and divides it ≈øelf below Boulac into two great Branches, the one meets the Sea at Ro≈øetta, and the other at Damietta. This latter divides it ≈øelf into another Current at Sciobret il yemen, a Village ≈øcituate on the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, about half-way between Cairo and Damietta, which runs into the Sea at Brullos.

Be≈øides the≈øe three branches, there is a fourth which is artificial, and full of water; but about thirty days of the year, it begins at a Village
called Latf, on the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, in going to Ro≈øetta, about thirty miles from Alexandria, where the waters of this Current run into the Sea; therefore the Egyptians reckon it among≈øt the true Mouths of the River Nilus.

I know not whether be≈øides the≈øe four there be any other, as Herodotus and Strabo affirm, for they reckon about ≈øeven. But Egypt is much alter'd; ≈øo that there is no appearance nor remembrance of the ≈øeven Cities where they were, as they ≈øay.

When I was at Ro≈øetta, I enquir'd from the Inhabitants concerning this particular, but they could not give me any account, but only of the≈øe four. Some told me, that be≈øides the great Current at Damietta, there was another artificial Channel at Gaza, where the waters did run into the Sea, but I cannot believe it: but if this were true, Gaza is not in Egypt; therefore it cannot be one of the ≈øeven Mouths of the River Nilus ≈øpoken of by the Ancient Geographers. I could wi≈øh that ≈øome other curious Traveller would enquire them out, and tell us the truth.

This is remarkable of Nilus: 1. That it begins to increa≈øe and decrea≈øe on a certain day preci≈øely. 2. That when it fir≈øt increa≈øeth it grows green. 3. That afterwards it appears red; and 4. That it changeth its Channel ≈øometimes.

The day in which it begins to increa≈øe is yearly the 12th of June of the Copties, or the 17th day of our June, on which day they ob≈øerve the Fea≈øt of S. Michael the Arch-Angel, on which day the drops fall. Now the≈øe drops are nothing el≈øe, according to the judgment of the Inhabitants, but the Mercies and Ble≈ø≈øings of God:
They believe on that day God ≈øends the Arch-Angel S. Michael to cau≈øe the River to be fruitful. This is the common Opinion of the people: But the Learned ≈øay, that the≈øe drops is a kind of a Dew which falls towards the la≈øt quarter of the night, near the morning; and which cau≈øeth the River to be fruitful, purifies the Air from all the infection of Cum≈øin, and gives ≈øtrength and vertue to all things upon which it falls.

The≈øe drops are doubtle≈øs the only cau≈øe of the fruitfulne≈øs of Nilus: this is ea≈øily ≈øeen; for as ≈øoon as this Dew is fallen, the water begins to be corrupt, and to be of a greeni≈øh colour; this colour increa≈øeth more and more, till the River appears as a Lake cover'd all over with Mo≈øs.
This colour is to be ≈øeen not only in its great Channel, but al≈øo in all the Ponds and Branches that come from thence, only the Ci≈øterns keep the water pure.

Some years this green colour continues about 20 days, and ≈øometimes more, but never above 40. The Egyptians call this time, when the River is green, il chad raviat, for they ≈øuffer much, becau≈øe the water is corrupt, without ta≈øte, and unwhole≈øome, and that good water is very rare.

The≈øe drops or Dew purifies the Air, for as ≈øoon as it falls, the Plague cea≈øeth to be mortal, none dies of it; the Air is whole≈øome, all Di≈øtempers cea≈øe, and if any per≈øon grows ≈øick, he never dies.

This Dew gives life to every thing; and when it falls upon the Wheat, it cau≈øeth it to continue many years without corruption, or worms, and is far more nouri≈øhing than that Corn upon which it never falls; For this cau≈øe they never
hou≈øe the Corn of the Grand Seignior in the Barns, till this Dew is fallen upon it, that it might keep the longer without worms.
The increa≈øe of the River proceeds from ≈øeveral cau≈øes; the fir≈øt and the chief is, the fermentation cau≈øed in it by this Dew, which falls at the time mentioned before.

The continual Rains of Ethiopia, that come in July, Augu≈øt, and September, which is the Winterquarter of that Country, and the great Torrents of water that run down from the Mountains into the Rivers that flow into Nilus, may be look'd upon as another cau≈øe of this increa≈øe, for I cannot conceive that the fermentation can continue 100 days, and cau≈øe it alone to increa≈øe ≈øo much as it is wont.

The third cau≈øe, in my judgment, are the We≈øterly winds, called Mae≈øtrals, and by the Egyptians Maltem, which begin to blow, as I have ≈øaid, about 12 days before the Dew falls; namely, the fifth day of June, and continue afterwards about four Months without alteration. They blow ≈øtrait into the River Nilus, and hinder the fre≈øh water from coming out, ≈øo that it returns back, and cau≈øeth the River to ≈øwell.

The≈øe ≈øame Winds have cau≈øed ≈øeveral Travellers, and namely Mon≈øieur Burattini to affirm, that the River ob≈øerves not a preci≈øe day to increa≈øe, but that it happens ≈øome years ≈øooner, others later; becau≈øe before the 17th day of June, the water did ≈øeem to ≈øwell; but this is no real increa≈øe, the winds Mae≈øtrals are the cau≈øes of this appearance.

The Ancient Egyptians a≈øcrib'd the cau≈øe of the ≈øwelling of Nilus to a ≈øuper≈øtitious cu≈øtom.
They bought a young Damo≈øel, adorned her with rich attire, and afterward ca≈øt her as a Sacrifice into the River, on the 12th day of their Baony, or June: But when Amru-ibn il a≈ø≈ø had conquer'd Egypt, and taken it from the Greeks, he aboli≈øh'd this damnable Cu≈øtom; which was ob≈øerved in that time, as Gaznevi a famous Arabian Hi≈øtorian ≈øaith. Amru commanded the Egyptians to forbear and leave that act of cruelty; in that year it happen'd that the River did not increa≈øe, which caus'd the people to ≈øu≈øpect and fear a great Famine, in≈øomuch that they re≈øolved to depart out of the Kingdom. This cau≈øed Amru ibn il a≈ø≈ø to write to Amru ibn il Chottab, a Califf of Mahomet, to de≈øire his advice. This Califf ≈øent him a Letter written with his own hand for the River Nilus, commanding him to read it, and to ca≈øt it into the water; which as ≈øoon as Amru had performed, the waters ro≈øe 16 Cubits in one night, the 14th of September, which is commonly the la≈øt day of its increa≈øe. This was ≈øufficient to water the Country, and ≈øatisfie the people.

Some of the Country that are ignorant of the true cau≈øes of this increa≈øe, imagine that it proceeds from a large Pond in Ethiopia, in the River it ≈øelf, which the Aby≈ø≈øins begin to open about the 12th of June, and by degrees let out the water more and more, till the 14th of September, at which time they begin to ≈øhut it again; but this is a fooli≈øh fancy of the Copties.

As ≈øoon as the green colour is gone, the River Nilus begins to become red, and very muddy; 'tis then no doubt but the fermentation is pa≈øs'd, and that the waters of Ethiopia are arriv'd in Egypt,
which are of that colour, becau≈øe of the red Earth which the furious torrents from the Mountains carry into the River; for it is not po≈ø≈øible that the Land of Egypt, which is very black, ≈øhould give it that colour. In the year 1673. in the beginning of July, the water began to be red, which continued till the end of December, the time that the River returns to its ordinary bigne≈øs.

They have an art to make this muddy water as clear as Cry≈øtal. As ≈øoon as the Waterbearers have fill'd their Ve≈ø≈øels, they rub them in the in≈øide with a Pa≈øte made with pounded Almonds, which cau≈øeth the water to become in a ≈øhort time very clear.

In the places where this Pa≈øte is not to be found, they u≈øe for that purpo≈øe the Kernels of Apricocks, pounded in the ≈øame manner. I was told, that the Flower of little Beans could perform the ≈øame effect. The Egyptians believe, that the River Nilus decrea≈øeth al≈øo at a certain day; namely, the 17th of their September, and the 24th of ours, the day which they ob≈øerve in remembrance of the Exaltation of the Holy Cro≈øs. They are ≈øo fully per≈øwaded of it, that if any ≈øhould deny it, he would be look'd upon as ridiculous.
The occa≈øion of this belief, as I conceive, is,

Fir≈øt, Becau≈øe the next day after this Fe≈øtival, all the Banks and Stoppages of the River, on this ≈øide the Cairo, which were before kept ≈øhut, and guarded by armed men, that ≈øuch as need the water for their grounds might not open them, are cut and removed, and the water let into the Country. By this means the River ≈øpreads abroad more than before, and its water returns
not back, which makes them ≈øay, that it ri≈øeth and ≈øwells no more.

Secondly, Becau≈øe the day after the Holy Cro≈øs, they do not take notice of its increa≈øe at the Pillar of Mikias, nor publi≈øh it about the Town, as before; they believe therefore that this is done, becau≈øe the River never increa≈øeth after.

Thirdly, Becau≈øe when the ≈øea≈øons of the year in Egypt are regular, the winds Mae≈øtrals that help to make the River ≈øwell, cea≈øe after the 17th of September, and the Southerly winds ri≈øe, driving the waters out of the Fields.

Though the≈øe rea≈øons appear ≈øtrong enough, to prove the Opinion of the Copties, one cannot without offending them ≈øay, that the River may yet increa≈øe after that day, becau≈øe the winds Mae≈øtrals, and the rains of Ethiopia, may ≈øome years continue a longer time than ordinary, and ≈øo the River may increa≈øe a little, not to be perceived: for the≈øe winds have blown till the Month of November. In the year 1672. at the Calliz of Cairo it was vi≈øible, that the water was ri≈øen three fingers higher than the day before, in the night of the Exaltation of the Holy Cro≈øs. It may be ≈øaid, that this increa≈øe was not real, but only cau≈øed by ≈øome ≈øtoppage at the pa≈ø≈øage of the River, or at one of the Bridges of the Channel out of the City: For my part, let every one believe what ≈øeems mo≈øt likely.

From hence we may ≈øee how much ≈øome Travellers have been mi≈øtaken, when they have endeavoured to per≈øwade us, that the River Nilus never increa≈øeth above 40 days: For if you reckon the beginning of its increa≈øe, from the
17th of June till the 14th of Septemb. the day of its decrea≈øe, you ≈øhall find that it increa≈øeth during 100 days at lea≈øt.

There cannot be a greater Te≈øtimony of this, than the Cu≈øtom of the Copties, who in their Rubrick have a form of prayer for the increa≈øe of the River, which they ≈øay from the 12th day of Baoni, or June, till the 8th of Babe, or October, which is in all 120 days. In which prayer they de≈øire, that God would cau≈øe the River to ri≈øe to its nece≈ø≈øary height, to water ≈øufficiently the Country, as Abulbaracat, a famous Author among≈øt the Copties, ≈øaith in his work called Mo≈øbah iddolme, which I have brought from Egypt.

The Copties altogether ignorant, a≈øcribe this ordinary decrea≈øe to a Miracle. They ob≈øerve the Fe≈øtival of the Exaltation of the Holy Cro≈øs, at which time they ble≈øs a Cro≈øs at the Celebration of the Ma≈øs, which they ca≈øt into Nilus, and imagine that this Cro≈øs ≈øtops the increa≈øe of the River.

Their Patriarch was wont to perform this Ceremony with great pomp and ≈øtate; but becau≈øe the Mahumetans ≈øuffer them not to go in Proce≈ø≈øion about the Cities publickly, their Prie≈øts ob≈øerve this Cu≈øtom every one in his own Village.

The waters of this River have ≈øeveral Operations. 1. They cau≈øe a Loo≈øene≈øs to the newcomers, if they drink of them at their fir≈øt arrival, which continues about eight days. 2. They cau≈øe an itch in the skin, which troubles ≈øuch as drink of them when the River increa≈øes. This itch is very ≈ømall, and appears fir≈øt about the Arms, next upon the Stomach, and ≈øpreads all
about the Body, which cau≈øeth a grievous pain. This Itch comes not only upon ≈øuch as drink of the River, but ≈øuch as drink of the waters of the Ci≈øterns filled with the River water. It la≈øts about ≈øix Weeks. 3. About the Month of June, July, Augu≈øt, and September, it turns into a ≈øwet, but is not ≈øo in any other time of the year. 4. When this water covers the Earth, it fats the Land with the ≈ølime that it leaves behind. Mon≈øieur Th. is mi≈øtaken in his Travels into the Levant, when he ≈øaith, that this ≈ølime makes the ground ≈øo fat, that if they did not mingle Sand with it, the ground would rot, and choak what is put into it; and that in Egypt they take as much pains to carry Sand into the ground, as we do to carry dung. This is not generally ≈øo; for they never u≈øe Sand, but for Melons, Cucumbers, and ≈øuch like Fruits, which grow only in ≈øandy ground; they never u≈øe Sand for other Fruits and Grains.

When the River runs over, it makes a great de≈øtruction; it carries away not only great pieces of the Bank, but de≈øtroys ≈øometimes Towns and Villages near to it. This may ea≈øily be perceived by the ruines of the Hou≈øes, and the old Walls, ≈øeen all along the ≈øides of the River.

Sometimes it alters its Channel. I have read in the Mekkin, an Arabian Hi≈øtorian, that about the time that the Arabians conquer'd Egypt, the water was ≈øo high, as to touch the Walls of the Ca≈ø≈ør I≈ø≈øc√©mma, a part of the old Cairo; and that it ran near the Church of Mary Moncure, which is in that of the Patriarchs, in the Street called in that time H√°ret il bahr, The Street of the River;
whereas now it is above a mile off from this place.

One day as I was walking out of the old Cairo in the Fields, near the Church of S. Michael, the Copties ≈øhewed me a Garden near adjoyning, which was about 10 years ago upon the Banks of the River, but at pre≈øent it is above a Musket ≈øhot off, becau≈øe the River hath taken as much ground on the other ≈øide, as it hath le≈øt on this.

Now let us ≈øee whether the Kings of Ethiopia are able to divert the cour≈øe of the River, and cau≈øe all the Inhabitants to peri≈øh with hunger, as ≈øome imagine. I am of this Opinion, though the Father Telles ≈øuppo≈øeth and alledgeth many difficulties in his Hi≈øtory of Ethiopia. The≈øe are the Rea≈øons that oblige me to believe it po≈ø≈øible.

1. A Letter of David, King of Ethiopia, ≈øirnamed Con≈øtantine, written to Abu ≈øeid Barc√∫k, King of Egypt, in the year of the Martyrs, 1193. I have a Copy of it written in Arabick, in which he threatens him in two di≈øtinct places of his Letter, to turn a≈øide the River Nilus, and hinder it from entering into Egypt, to cau≈øe all the Inhabitants to peri≈øh with hunger, if he continues to vex the Copties, whom he names his Brethren. He ≈øaith, that he hath received from God this priviledge, which he had not di≈øcover'd to any of his Predece≈ø≈øors.

2. Becau≈øe the Kings of Ethiopia have hindred the Current of Nilus, and turn'd it out of Egypt, in the days of Mo≈øtan≈øir, one of the Califfes of Egypt; which obliged him to ≈øend the Patriarch of the Copties with rich Pre≈øents to the King of Ethiopia, to intreat him to take away
the Bank which he had rai≈øed to turn a≈øide the River. The King of Ethiopia having granted him this reque≈øt for the Patriarchs ≈øake, the River increa≈øed in one night three Cubits, which was ≈øufficient to water the Fields with that water that was there before; as we may ≈øee in the Hi≈øtory of the Mu≈øulmans of George le Mekkin.

The fir≈øt thing that Strangers may take notice of in ≈øailing upon the River, is the great number of I≈ølands, whereof ≈øome be very great, 20 miles in compa≈øs: They proceed fir≈øt from the ≈øhipwrack of Ve≈ø≈øels that have ≈øtuck in the mud. This happens frequently through the unskilfulne≈øs of the Mariners, and the mud of the River, the ≈ølowne≈øs of the Current, the dirt and mire gathers immediately about any thing that ≈øtops there; by this means the≈øe places increa≈øe into I≈ølands. Almo≈øt every day new I≈ølands are di≈øcoverable: And becau≈øe the State of Egypt never chang'd ≈øince the Conque≈øt of Sultan Selim, and that the≈øe I≈ølands have been made ≈øince, they are not recorded in the Rolls of the Divan of that time. From hence it is that they pay nothing to the Grand Seignior, but belong to the Pacha, who lets them out to the Ca≈øciefs of the Province, where the≈øe I≈ølands are ≈øcituated, or to whom he plea≈øeth.
Several Pillars have been erected in divers times to mea≈øure the ri≈øing of the River.

The fir≈øt was at Menuf, or Memphis, built by Jo≈øeph Jacob≈øon. When this fell to ruine, a rich Lady of the Copties, named Deluca, erected two others; one at In≈øine, or Thebe, and the other at Achmin. When this la≈øt decayed, the Greeks built one at Ca≈ø≈ør I≈ø≈øcemma, whereof the Ruines are yet to be ≈øeen, as ≈øome ≈øay.

Ater that Amru ibn il A≈ø≈ø had conquered Egypt, he cau≈øed one to be built at In≈øine for the ≈øame purpo≈øe. This remained entire till the days of Abd il aziz ibn Mervan, a Califf of Egypt, who cau≈øed one to be built at Helvan, a place where he delighted to dwell.

The la≈øt of the≈øe Pillars ≈øtands in the Roude, an I≈øland, where it remains to this very day. It was erected by the Command of Azamed ibn zid, il Nettuchi, as we may ≈øee in the Macrizi, in the Serrur, and other Arabian Hi≈øtories.

div.head: Of the Pillar of Mikias, and in what manner they take notice of the Rivers increa≈øe.
div.p:
THE Name of Mikias, in its right ≈øignification, is nothing but a place where ≈øomething is to be mea≈øured: But when at Cairo Mikias is named, they under≈øtand only the Pillar which is in the Palace of the Roude, an I≈øland, which ≈øerves to ob≈øerve the increa≈øe of Nilus. This I≈øland is named Roude, or Garden, becau≈øe it is a delightful place, and full of many plea≈øant Gardens. It ≈øtands over again≈øt Grand Carro, from whence it is di≈øtant about a Musket-≈øhot. This Pillar is in the Palace of the I≈øle Roude; and to come to it, one mu≈øt pa≈øs by a great and a beautiful Mo≈øqu√©e: Therefore it is a difficult matter for a Chri≈øtian to ≈øee it, becau≈øe the Mahumetans do not ≈øuffer them to enter into their Mo≈øqu√©es, chiefly in Egypt, for they believe that they would by their entrance defile and profane them. For this
cau≈øe I could not have the liberty to ≈øee it; therefore I cannot give any other de≈øcription than that of Amer ibn il verdi, and of Macrizi, famous Hi≈øtorians of the Arabians.

It is, as they ≈øay, of white Marble, of an Octogone figure, ≈øtanding in a Pond of water, into which the water of Nilus enters in by a large Channel. It is divided upon the eight Angles into two and twenty Cubits, from the top to the bottom: The fir≈øt is divided into 24 equal parts, called Fingers; the ≈øecond is not divided; the third is divided as the fir≈øt; thus alternatively, till the eleventh Cubit. The fir≈øt Cubit of the ≈øecond ≈øide is not divided, the ≈øecond is divided into four and twenty thumbs, the third is not, thus, till the eleventh, which with the others, to the bottom, are divided into eighteen fingers or thumbs. All the other ≈øides are divided in the ≈øame manner; ≈øo that all the Cubits which are divided in a ≈øide, an≈øwer to the Cubits which are not divided in the other ≈øide. The increa≈øe of the River is di≈øcerned from the top to the bottom. The Copties ≈øay that John Mekaukes, a famous Man of their Nation, and a Governour of Egypt, for the Emperour Heraclius, laid the Foundations of this Palace, and of the Church which is near a Mo≈øqu√©e.

When Chri≈øtianity flouri≈øh'd in Egypt, it belong'd to one of their Prie≈øts to examine the increa≈øe of the River; which action was performed three hours after midnight, and after Ma≈øs. This is very likely. The la≈øt Prie≈øt of the Copties that mea≈øured it, was named Raddat, who continued in that Office by making him≈øelf a Mahumetan, that none but his Po≈øterity might have this
Office. Ibn Raddat, who now executes this Function, is de≈øcended from him, and is a Caddi by Profe≈ø≈øion.

Though the Mahumetans are Enemies of the Copties, they ob≈øerve ≈øome Cu≈øtomes now which were then kept, when their Prie≈øts did mea≈øure the River; for they do this about Even-≈øong, that is, about three hours in the afternoon. They that mu≈øt examine the increa≈øe of the River, mu≈øt be Cadis, or Judges, an Eccle≈øia≈øtical Function among≈øt the Mahumetans. They do it after they have fir≈øt purified them≈øelves, and ≈øaid their prayers of the Even, as the Copties after Ma≈øs.

When Ibn Raddat hath taken notice of the number of the Fingers that ≈øignifie the increa≈øe of the River, he takes three times the water in the hollow of his hand, and flings it as often into the air: He repeats afterwards the Chapter of Fatha, and departs with the news of the ri≈øing of the water to the Pacha.

On the 29th of June, the Fe≈øtival of the Apo≈øtles of S. Peter and S. Paul, they begin to publi≈øh abroad this increa≈øe through the City of Cairo; the manner of this publication is ≈øufficiently de≈øcrib'd by Mon≈øieur Thevenot. This day is the 26th of Baoni, or the June of the Copties, which is the Fe≈øtival of the Angel Gabriel. They call this day in their Language, Be≈øciaret innil be Ma≈ø≈ør; or, The day of the publication of the River Nilus at Cairo.

They that are imployed in this bu≈øine≈øs, ob≈øerve a particular Cu≈øtom: They never declare exactly the number of the fingers of the increa≈øe, but always keep back ≈øome, till the time
comes that the Calitz is to be cut. For example, if Nilus be increa≈øed ten fingers the fir≈øt day, they will declare but ≈øeven or eight the next day, and will conceal three or four: if in another day it increa≈øeth twelve fingers, they will di≈øcover but eight or nine, and keep back three or four. Thus they continue 20 days, till the time comes that the Bank is to be cut that hinders the River from running into the Channel of Cairo; then they reveal ≈øome of tho≈øe fingers which they conceal'd. All which they con≈øtantly perform, until the day comes that they cry out Ouf Alla, that the River is come to its perfect increa≈øe to water all the Fields of Egypt. They ob≈øerve this method, as they ≈øay, to cau≈øe more rejoycing in the people, by di≈øcovering a great many fingers at once, at the time when the Bank is cut. This makes them expect a year of Plenty.

div.head: Of the Well of Argenus.
div.p: I Have taken notice of one particular thing concerning Nilus, worthy of the knowledge of our Learned Wits, which never any Traveller of Europe hath yet given any account of. At Argenus, or Gernus, as ≈øome call it corruptly, a Village near Behne≈øe, a Town ≈øcituate in the middle of Egypt, there is a Mona≈øtery of Copties, with a Church dedicated to the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, where there is a Well whereof the waters increa≈øe and ≈øwell every year, that ≈øame night in which the Dew falls, in ≈øuch a manner, that from thence it is ea≈øie to gather how many Cubits the River will ri≈øe that year above ≈øixteen. To know this, they ob≈øerve this Cu≈øtom.

The Evening before the Dew falls, the Cadi, together with the Elder of this Town, goes to the Church with a little Cord of Cotton, having eight knots di≈øtant from one another about a thumb; at the end there is a piece of Lead, which they let down into the Well in the pre≈øence of a crowd of people. As ≈øoon as the Lead touches the top of the water, they tye the ≈øtring, and ≈øtop the Well, ≈øealing it with their Seal: Afterwards they go to the Church, and continue there till the morning, at which time they examine how much the water is ri≈øen that night, for at break of day they take away the Seal, they open the Well, and draw up the Cord. Now by the ri≈øing of the water in the Well, and the number of the knots that are wet, they can Progno≈øticate how many Cubits the River will ri≈øe that year above ≈øixteen. They reckon a Cubit for every knot that is wet: For example, if there be four knots wet, they under≈øtand that the River will ri≈øe four Cubits that year, that is in all twenty; ≈øo they judge of the re≈øt.

Neverthele≈øs, I know not whether this be true, or whether it be but a Cheat, as the late holy Greek at Jeru≈øalem of Ea≈øter-Eve, as the appearing of the Saints at Gemiane. I could not go upon the place to ob≈øerve this pa≈ø≈øage; yet I can ≈øay, that all the Hi≈øtorians of Arabia ≈øpeak of it as mo≈øt true; as we may ≈øee in George le Mekkin, which is in the Kings Library.

div.head: Of the Fi≈øhes of the River Nilus.
div.p: THe chief Fi≈øhes found in this River, which I am acquainted with, here follow.

The Fi≈øh called Variole is the be≈øt; ≈øome are taken weighing three hundred pounds: next is the Buni, and the Houd; the latter is without Scales, the Fle≈øh is of no good ta≈øte, becau≈øe it is grea≈øie and ≈øoft.

Here are al≈øo other Fi≈øhes, called Ke≈øchue, Abeide, Mi≈øcht, Taaban-me, or Eels, Lebis, Schilan, the Crocodile, Ker≈øche, Tir≈øe, Buri, or Mullet, which they pickle, Kelbe me, or the Sea-dog. The Bulti next to the Variole is the be≈øt Fi≈øh of Nilus, it hath Scales. There is al≈øo the Fere≈ø-me, or the Sea-hor≈øe, the Sebuga, the Focaca, or the Orbis marinus, which turns him≈øelf round when he ≈øports in the water. There is al≈øo the Reade, or the Cramp-fi≈øh. All the≈øe Fi≈øh are not ≈øo plea≈øing to the ta≈øte as the Variole, or the Bulti, becau≈øe the fle≈øh is ≈øoft, which proceeds from the mud of the River.

div.head: Of the Crocodile.
div.p:
THE Crocodile, in Arabick called Tim≈ø√°h, is the mo≈øt remarkable and mo≈øt curious Animal belonging to the River Nilus. I have therefore thought that it de≈øerv'd a particular De≈øcription among≈øt the Fi≈øhes of this Current. That it might be the more punctual and exact, I ≈øhall fir≈øt repeat what Pliny ≈øaith, and afterwards add what I have taken notice of. This Learned
Naturali≈øt tells us that The Crocodile is an Animal with four Legs that makes a grievous de≈øtruction both in the Water, and out upon the Land. Of all the Creatures that live upon the Earth, this alone is without a Tongue, and this alone moves the upper-jaw in eating. It hath two ranks of great Teeth, and commonly it is longer than 18 Cubits. It produceth Eggs about the bigne≈øs of a Goo≈øe-Egg, that it ≈øits upon them out of the Water, and lays them at the place unto which the Water is to ri≈øe that Year, when it is at its highe≈øt; as if it had a knowledge of this before-hand. It is the only Creature that ri≈øeth from ≈øuch a ≈ømall beginning, to ≈øuch a prodigious bigne≈øs. It is Armed with Claws to defend it ≈øelf. Its Skin on the Back is ≈øo extraordinary hard that no Weapon, never ≈øo ≈øharp, is able to enter it. In the Day-time it lies upon the Ground, and ≈øpends the Nights in the Waters. When its Belly is very full, it ≈øleeps upon the Bank with its Mouth open; then there comes a little Bird, named Trochilos, To eat the remains of the devoured Prey which ≈øticks between the Teeth: with this Food it nouri≈øhes it ≈øelf, and by the picking of the Teeth it gives the Crocodile a plea≈øure, which cau≈øeth him to fall a≈øleep in this po≈øture. At that time the Ichneumon takes notice of the Crocodile at a di≈øtance, and when it ≈øees its time it enters into the others Mouth, ≈ølides down the Throat into the Belly, and gnaws the Entrails; with this the Crocodile dies. In the River Nilus are al≈øo, as he ≈øaith, Dolphins which have a very ≈øharp Back, with which they kill the Crodiles that pur≈øue them continually. For that purpo≈øe the≈øe Dolphins ≈øeem to be afraid of the ravenous Bea≈øt, which cau≈øeth them to hide them≈øelves in the Waters under the Crocodiles; then, with their ≈øharp backs, they rip open the others belly. This Creature,
≈øaith he, is very bold and daring to them that run from it, but timerous and fearful if it be pur≈øued. It is very weak-≈øighted in the Water, but out of the Water it is quick. In the Winter it ≈øpends four Months in ≈øome Cave, without eating. It lives long, and grows continually till it dies.
This is the account that Pliny gives of the Crocodile. We will a little examine what he ≈øaith, and to that we ≈øhall add our own ob≈øervations.

It is true that the Crocodile is a very dreadful Creature in Egypt, becau≈øe of the great de≈øtructions that it makes in the Water, and out; for it devours not only all the Fi≈øh that it can catch in the River, but al≈øo the Camels, the Hor≈øes, the Sheep, the wild Beeves, the Dogs, and little Children. In ≈øhort, all that it can catch upon the Land, it draws into the River, and eats it.

Concerning its length, which Pliny ≈øaith is commonly above 18 Cubits, I mu≈øt needs confe≈øs that I know not how many Inches are his Cubits; for, many Hunters of Crocodiles have a≈ø≈øured me that it grows never above a Cubit in length in a Year; and when it comes to twelve years old it grows no more: ≈øo that, according to this account, the longe≈øt Crocodile is not above 12 Cubits in length. If this be true, the Arabian Author, whom Ibn Beitar mentions in his Book of Animals and Plants, is mi≈øtaken, when he ≈øaith, that there are ≈øome Crocodiles that have their Tails 6 Cubits long, their Head two, and the re≈øt of their Body 8.

The Eggs that he lays, which are ≈øometimes in Number 30, never 100, as a certain Traveller affirms, are as big as the Eggs of Au≈øtriches;
three-times bigger than Gee≈øe-Eggs. As ≈øoon as they are out of its Body, it carries them into ≈øome I≈øland of Nilus, and puts them into a hole made with its fore-feet, it covers them with Sand, and ≈ømooths the place where they lye that no Per≈øon might di≈øcover them. In this condition it leaves them, till by a natural In≈øtinct it knows that the young are formed. It goes then and opens the hole and breaks the ≈øhell with its Mu≈øle for the young to creep out. As ≈øoon as they are in the Air, they run ≈øtrait to the River. And becau≈øe ≈øome of the≈øe Eggs are rotten, it is from this corruption that a certain Lizard, nameed by the Arabs, Varal, is ingendred. We ≈øhall ≈øpeak of this Serpent in the ≈øequel of our Di≈øcour≈øe.

That which Pliny ≈øaith of the Trochilos requires a further inquiry; for one might ask an hundred years in Egypt, what this Bird is, and yet none is able to give an account. Beitar ≈øaith this of it, when the Crocodile is full with the devoured Prey, he goes out of the Water to ≈øleep in the Sun; and becau≈øe its Teeth are full of ≈ølime and filth, in which the Worms are ingendred; a certain Bird, as little as a Teitavi, enters between his Jaws, eats up the ≈ølime, and the Worms, if there be any; and when the Crocodile feels that all is clean, he ≈øhuts his Mouth to eat the Bird al≈øo. But Nature hath provided an expedient to ≈øecure it; there are two ≈øharp pricks on the top of the Birds Head, which when the Crocodile feels, he opens his Jaws again for the Bird to e≈øcape out.

I inquired from ≈øeveral Moors, whether they knew any Bird that had any pricks on the Head?
They an≈øwered, they knew none. They told me, that there is in Egypt the Saksak, a Bird that keeps the Crocodile always company, which I have ≈øeen very often, and which lives upon the filth that ≈øticks about, and between, the Crocodile's Teeth. Whether therefore the Saksak of the Moors, and the Bird mentioned by Beitar, be the Trochilos of Pliny, I leave to the Reader to judge.

Concernining the Ichneumon, named by the Arabians, Nims, by the Italians, Sorca di faraone, and by the French-men, Rat d' Egypte. It is very true that it creeps into the Mouth of the Crocodile, enters into its Belly, which it gnaws to the very Entrails; the like happens to the Camels, and wild Beeves, and other Animals, when they ≈øleep in the Fields.

That which Pliny ≈øpeaks concerning the Dolphins is not likely, for there be none in the River. But it may be it is the Tir≈øe, which is the only Fi≈øh that a≈ø≈øaults the Crocodile. This Tir≈øe is as round as a Buckler which eats the young Crocodiles when it can meet them.

That the Crocodiles can live a long while without eating, as Pliny ≈øaith, is a truth which I have ≈øeen by experience by two that I have kept alive a long while. I had one in my Clo≈øet about a Foot long, and another ≈øix in my Cellar. I cau≈øed the latter to be tied with a great Cord about the Jaws, that it might not offend ≈øuch as came to ≈øee it. They lived both about a Month without eating. The Moors told me that they could ≈øub≈øi≈øt forty days without any nouri≈øhment.

They have, in all, three-≈øcore and twelve great Teeth, very ≈øharp; ≈øix and thirty in the upper-jaw, and as many in the lower: So that Ibn Beitar
