is mi≈øtaken, when he ≈øaith in his Hi≈øtory of Animals, which I have ≈øent to the King's Library, that they have three≈øcore in the upper-jaw, and forty in the lower; and that between every two ≈øharp and great Teeth, there is one ≈øquare and little one; for I have ≈øeen many alive and dead, but have never found this difference in the Teeth, but rather I have always found them to be ≈øharp and uniform.

Its four Paws are furni≈øhed with great Hooks, or Claws, very ≈øharp; the two Fore-feet having five di≈øtinct, ≈øeparated the one from the other; the two hinder but four, which are all joined together by a very thin skin, as are the Feet of all Sea-fowl, as Gee≈øe and Ducks.

The Arabian Authors ≈øay, That it ca≈øts out its Excrements by the Throat, becau≈øe it hath no hole under the Tail, and its Stones have the ≈ømell of Musk; but as I have had no experience neither of one nor t'other, I refer my ≈øelf to their Relation.

Becau≈øe the Crocodile cannot well turn it ≈øelf upon the Belly when it lies upon the Back, and that it is needful that the Female be in that po≈øture when the Male covers her. The Male takes care when he hath laid her upon her Back and performed his duty, to turn her again upon her Belly, for fear of the Hunters.

I have al≈øo taken notice, that from the City Cairo, towards the upper Egypt, there are many Crocodiles to be found, where they do much mi≈øchief; but from thence towards the lower Egypt are very few, and they ≈øay, that they be not dangerous.

The Moors give two Rea≈øons of this; they ≈øay,
That one of their Saints, named Sidi Ibrahim il Zuphi, or The Lord Abraham of Zug, hath conjur'd them to hinder them from pa≈ø≈øing beyond the City Cairo, and bound them to hurt no body. The other Rea≈øon is, as they ≈øay, becau≈øe under the Pillar or Mikias there is a Tali≈øman that kills them as ≈øoon as they draw near.

But it is mo≈øt certain that there are ≈øome on this ≈øide the Cairo to be ≈øeen, though not ≈øo frequently as on the other. This proceeds, as they ≈øay, from the Tali≈øman that is turn'd up-≈øide down in this Pillar, and therefore lo≈øeth its greate≈øt vertue; therefore they can pa≈øs beyond it, ≈øwimming upon their Backs.

div.head: An exact Account of all the Pacha's that have Govern'd Egypt ≈øince Sultan Selim, who took it from the Mammeluc Circa≈ø≈øians, till the year 1673.
div.p: I Think that this general De≈øcription of Egypt would be imperfect, did I not add a Li≈øt of all the Pacha's, or Turki≈øh Rulers, that have Govern'd Egypt till this pre≈øent time, ≈øince Sultan Selim gain'd it with his Sword from the Circa≈ø≈øians. I have taken it from an Arabian Hi≈øtorian of good credit, named il Serr√ªr; I have brought his Book from Egypt.

div.head: Of the Sangiac-Beys of Egypt.
div.p: IN Egypt, as well as in other Countries ≈øubject to the Grand Seignior, there are ≈øeveral Sangiac-Beys, who be Governors of great Provinces.

They are ≈øo called in the Turki≈øh Tongue from two words, Sangiac, which ≈øignifies an En≈øign, and Bey, a Prince; becau≈øe when the Grand Vizier, or the Pacha, makes them, he delivers into their hands an En≈øign, as a mark of their Dignity.
They that may pretend to this Dignity are the Agas of the Boulouks, the Chieftains of the ≈øeven Orders of the Militia of Cairo, and the Metferracas.

The greate≈øt part of the≈øe Lords are Melte≈øim√≠ns, or Farmers of the Provinces that they hold from the Divan, at the rates mentioned in the Rolls: heretofore ≈øome Beys have Farmed four≈øcore Villages, or Towns. They Lett the≈øe Villages to under Farmers, and the u≈øual Rent of every Town, is known to every one, chiefly to the Meba≈øcicr√≠ns, or Scrivners of the Copties.

About twenty years ago this honour was purchas'd with the expence of twenty Pur≈øes, or thirty: This was called Chidmet il Sangiakie. And as ≈øoon as any Per≈øon was made Bey, the Divan did allow him half a Pur≈øe every Month, as his Sallary; and when he travell'd to any Place, for the ≈øervice of the Grand Seignior, at his return to Cairo the Divan did give him half a Pur≈øe more for his Reward. In that time the≈øe Beys wore in great Credit, and Power; for when they declar'd their opinion in the Divan, the Pacha's
were afraid to contradict them. They did ≈øometimes depo≈øe them, when they did not amend their manners after a reproof. They were wont to be ≈øix and thirty in Number.

But now they are a great deal le≈øs, and are reduc'd to that condition, that they are not much e≈øteem'd. This Honour now co≈øts them fifteen Pur≈øes, and their Allowance given to them by the Divan is one thou≈øand A≈øpers every day. So A≈øpers is 4 s. 6
d.

Their Office is, to Conduct the Hazna, or Trea≈øure, of the Grand Seignior to Con≈øtantinople, or to Command the Caravan that travels towards Mecha; and to go to War, when required. Four of them are to watch always round about Cairo, with a Company of Jani≈ø≈øaries. The fir≈øt keeps Guard at Adel√≠a, where the way leads to Sues; the ≈øecond at Caraffa; another at the ≈øecond Bridge of the Calitz, near its Mouth; another watches at the old Cairo, to prevent Tumults and Murders.
In the Year 1672, when I was at Cairo, there were ≈øixteen Beys, here be their Names.

Sulfucar was Bey of Girge, but he was ca≈øhier'd in the Month of September in this Year. Jezbee was made Bey of Carge in his ≈øtead. Mohammed Abu Sciav√°reb, or Mahomet with the great Whiskers. Mohammed Abu-Gura. Gazem, Bey of Sues. Ju≈øeph of Con≈øtantinople, who was Emir-hag, or Commander of the Caravan to Mecha. Ju≈øeph of Cairo. Delaver, who carried the Grand Seignior's Trea≈øure to Con≈øtantinople. Mohammed il ghindi, who had Rented B√©be. Ali. Omar, Hu≈ø≈øein of Con≈øtantinople. Canzo, who was Serdar, or Colonel. Torna Mu≈øtapha, the Ca≈øcief of Dekahlie.
Eivaz, who had been Trea≈øurer of Egypt. Abdolla, who was Trea≈øurer this Year 1672, of all Egypt.

div.head: Of the Trees, Plants, and Birds of Egypt.
div.p: I Shall now ≈øpeak ≈øomething of the rare≈øt Trees, Plants, and Birds of Egypt, which are come to my knowledge; for this belongs to the General De≈øcription of this Country: I ≈øhall afterwards return to my Journal.

div.head: Of the Trees.
div.p: IN Egypt are to be found ≈øeveral Trees very rare, which are not in Europe. Lebaca is one which, as the Copties Stories relate, wor≈øhipped our Saviour Chri≈øt when he came fir≈øt to I≈øchemunein, a City ≈øcituate in the middle Egypt near Melave, towards the North. This Tree is now very rare; for I have not ≈øeen any in all my Travels.

The Hil√©lgie is a great Tree full of prickles. I have ≈øeen one in the Mona≈øtery of Abuhennis, ≈øcituate in the middle Egypt, almo≈øt over again≈øt Melave. I was told that it bears a Fruit like to yellow Da≈øies. The Sycamore, named by the Arabians, Gomeize, is one of the ordinary ≈øort of Trees; as al≈øo the Fig-tree, which is of four ≈øorts, 1. The common Fig-tree; 2. The Fig-tree of Fium; 3. Of Europe; 4. Avodlis. The Palm-tree, in Arab. Temer, is one of the mo≈øt vulgar Trees; it bears above fifty differing ≈øorts of Fruits. There is al≈øo the Nebeca, a kind of
Gum-tree. Zante, which is called Acacia. The Ma≈øtick, I have ≈øeen too in the Mona≈øtery of St. Anthony. Carobis, Atles, and Tamrhennes. There is al≈øo a Tree called Seiials, a wild kind of Acacia. The Cinamon-tree, named in Arab. Cheiiar Scembar. The Pomgranate, Orange-tree, the Lemon-tree, the Cedar, the Quince-tree, the Sefsafs, a kind of Withy, the Apricock tree, the Almond-tree, the Cypre≈øs-tree. The Tree called Mocheits, or Sebe≈øte; the Fruit whereof is good for Food, and to make Glue. The Tree called Alats, the Myrhe, the Fig-tree of Adam, named in Arab. Mouz. The Kebbads, a Tree that bears Oranges of a ≈øtrange bigne≈øs. The Keffe Mariam, or the holy Virgin's Hand.

The Doum, or the Gum-tree, is a rare Tree in Egypt; I have never ≈øeen but three in all my Travels: one in the Mon≈øtery of St. Athana≈øe, di≈øtant from Siut about three hours travelling, towards the South. In this Tree are two things remarkable: 1. That its Leaves bur≈øt forth only at the end of its Branches, and in the thick Bunches. 2. That they are ≈øo equal, and even at the end of the Branches, that to look upon them one would think that ≈øome have cut, and even'd them with Sci≈ø≈øers. The Leaves are very thin and long, and are like the Leaves of the Palm-tree. The Body of this Tree hath many Branches of a con≈øiderable bigne≈øs, from them proceed others of a le≈ø≈øer ≈øize; every one is forked, and the end of the≈øe Leaves appear in Bunches, as we have ≈øaid.

div.head: Of the Plants.
div.p: AMong≈øt all the Curious Plants of Egypt, I have taken notice of the≈øe following.

Bel≈øen is a Plant, or Herb, that bears a Medicinal Grain, good to heal Wounds. Sabbara; the Leaves whereof are very thick, and full of ≈øap; there are two ≈øorts, the Male, and the Female. Vudne is like Pur≈ølan, but its Leaves are very great, and its ta≈øte is fouri≈øh, and it's eaten raw. Sedab, is Rue; Filfil, Garden-Pepper. Ge≈øalaht is a Plant that grows as big as a Tree. Verdhomar is our Ro≈øa a≈øini. Morian is called in Latin, Halicacabus. Kilu, otherwi≈øe named Alcali. Rabl is an Herb of a fragrant ≈ømell, full of Oyl; growing upon Hills. Barnub is a Plant that contains a Powder that Dyers u≈øe; I ≈øhall ≈øpeak of it in the ≈øequel of this Journal. Here be al≈øo Je≈ø≈øemins, both ≈øingle and double. Katife, or the Virgins-Bower, whereof there are two ≈øorts; the ≈øingle, and the other named in Arab. Katife Kod≈øi, or the Virgins Bower of Jeru≈øalem. Rihan is our Origanum. There are ≈øeveral ≈øorts; 1. Of Kod≈øi, or Jeru≈øalem: 2. Sciami of Dama≈øcus: 3. Hindi of the Indies: 4. Miski, of the ≈ømell of Musk: 5. A≈øcickrihan, or the lovely Origanum. Leblab is another Plant, called by the Italians, Convolvolo; by the French, Li≈øeron, and by the Engli≈øh: Bengiar, are our Beets. Mentur, otherwi≈øe named Chobeize, are our Mallows. Here are al≈øo Gilly-flowers, Lillies, and Ro≈øes of all colours, and in abundance. Merdeku≈øch is our Marjoram. Mer≈øci√©nn√© ‚Äî Li≈øan-hammel is our Plantain. Li≈øant Tor is our Buglo≈øs. Neane, Mint:
Bamie, and Meluchie are ordinary Pot-herbs in Egypt. Amberboy, is Amber. Se≈øeban is a tall Plant, ≈øown about the Sugar-Fields; it ≈øerves in≈øtead of a Fence. Sciebeh, is Rue of Rome. Che≈øchach is the Pavots. Hendal, or Colocinthis; Helbe, named by the French, Fenugrec by the Engli≈øh. They have a Proverb in Egypt, that ≈øaith, Ble≈ø≈øed are the Feet that walk upon that Ground where the Helbe is ≈øown. They eat it raw, and ≈øodden. Carrots, called in Arab. Gi≈ø≈ør, are no bigger than Radi≈øhes. Succory, called in Arab. Hindibe. Lettuce, called Chas Melieh. Pea≈øe. Tormus, are Lupins. Ber≈øim, or Sinfoin. Il Nile, is Indigo. Scich, is Ab≈øynthium Ponticum. Gabbar was an Herb that I found in abundance upon the Mountains, near the Mona≈øtery of Abuhennis. Homos gebeli, are the wild Pea≈øe of the Mountains; for they are like Pea≈øe. Roiet ga≈ø≈øal, or Harts-Foot: ≈øo called, becau≈øe it is like the Foot of this Animal, and both are oily. Selguem, called by the Germans, Rub≈øamen: Zabuz, Oats, Saffron, Sim≈øim, or the Se≈øame, Heb-il-≈øode, called Jugeolin. Tabacco, Rice, Sugar, Linni; Coulangian, called in Latin, Gulange; and in French, Galangu.

div.head: Of Birds.
div.p:
THE rare≈øt Birds that I have ≈øeen in Egypt, are the≈øe; Sciamta is the bigge≈øt, next to the Au≈øtrich. It is ≈øo ≈øtrong, that ≈øome ≈øay, it can carry up a Man into the Air. Next to the≈øe are the Eagles, the Vultures, named in Arab. Akab, which are very big. Gaddafs, Havams, Baz, Heddahs, Sakers,
Sciahins, Ba≈øcieks, Rachms; all the≈øe are ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Vultures, Faulcons, and Hawks. There be al≈øo Mezaz, and Begas, otherwi≈øe called Gemel il Bahr, or the River-Camel; or the Pelican. The Saksaks have a Bone ≈øtrong and ≈øharp, at the joint of each Wing. The Guinney-Hens, Cranes, Wild-Gee≈øe, and many other Birds; which are ordinary among≈øt us.
There are al≈øo many Au≈øtriches, and chiefly in De≈øarts, that lead to the Mona≈øtery of St. Anthony, I have ≈øeen there Herds together.
I have read in an Arabian Manu≈øcript, called Giauharet innefi≈ø≈øe, a remarkable thing concerning the Au≈øtrich, which I cannot pa≈øs over without publi≈øhing.

When it intends to Hatch its Egs, it ≈øits not upon them, as other Birds; but the Male and the Female Hatches them with their Eye only; and when either of them hath need to ≈øeek for Food, he gives notice to the other by crying; and the other continues to look upon the Egs, till it be return'd: likewi≈øe when the other hath the ≈øame de≈øire to ≈øeek about for Food, he gives the ≈øame notice, with the ≈øame ≈øhriek, that its Companion might remain ≈øtill to look upon the Egs, till they be all Hatch'd: For if they did but look off a moment, the Egs would ≈øpoil and rot.

The Church of the Copies hath learn'd an excellent Cu≈øtome from the Practice of this Bird: They hang up a lighted Lamp, between two Egs of an Au≈øtrich, over again≈øt the Prie≈øts that officiate, to advi≈øe them to be attentive about their Devotions; that their Prayers might be more efficacious, and might not lo≈øe their ≈øtrength, for want of attention.
It is now time to bring back my Reader to my Journal, to Damietta, where I left him; that I might give him fir≈øt a General De≈øcription of Egypt.

div.head: The Continuation of the Journal.
div.p: I Set Foot in Diametta the 18th day of Feb. 1672. where I abode till the 8th day of the next Month: Sometimes lodging in the City, ≈øometimes in the Barque that had brought me, becau≈øe it was loaden with Wine for the Con≈øul, and French Merchants of Cairo: And the Aga of the City would not ≈øuffer the Wine to be carried a-≈øhore, nor into the Haven, until the Pacha had ≈øent him an expre≈øs Order to that purpo≈øe. He dealt in this manner, becau≈øe the Grand Seignior had ≈øent very ≈øtrict, and ≈øevere orders, to forbid the Importation of Wines in all his Dominions. And Becau≈øe I was in the company of a Servant of the French Con≈øul, whom I could not leave with Civility, becau≈øe he could not under≈øtand the Arabian Tongue; I was therefore ingaged to be his Interpreter, by the Obligations that he had laid upon me in my Voyage: For his, and his Ma≈øters ≈øake, I abode with him till the orders were come, and a Jani≈ø≈øary to Guard the Wine to Cairo. They loaded therewith two great Barques, and we departed immediately for Damietta, on Saturday, the 8th of April; and were at Boulac, a Suburb of Cairo, the Eve of Wedne≈øday before Ea≈øter.

Here follows the mo≈øt remarkable Pa≈ø≈øages, and the De≈øcription of the Towns, and Places, which are from the Mouth of the River at Damietta,
as far as Grand Cairo, as they lye in order.

As ≈øoon as we enter into the River, from the Sea, we find on the Ea≈øt-≈øide, at the Mouth, an old Ca≈øtle ruinated, but ≈ømall; which, as the Francs ≈øay, was built by S. Lewis, the French King, when he had Damietta. It is ≈øquare, and divided into four round Turrets, upon which ≈øome Artillery have been planted to command the Pa≈ø≈øage, and where a few Moors are upon the Guard.
A little further into the River ≈øtands a poor Village, named Bogas, or Mouth of the River; becau≈øe it is there ≈øcituated. The Arabian word Bogas ≈øignifying ≈øo much.

In this Village dwell the Owners of the Germes (being Long-Boats made to un-load Ships and draw them out of the Sands) that guide and tow along the Ships that ≈øail in or out of the River; and di≈øcover to them the Banks of Sand, which are very ordinary in this Road.

In this Village is to be ≈øeen the Foundation of another ≈øquare Fort, the Walls whereof are not yet fini≈øh'd, and never likely to be. There are al≈øo here two Calitz, or Artificial Channels, full of the River-water all the year; made on purpo≈øe to water the Fields.

About an hundred Paces from this Village, on the other ≈øide, is another Ca≈øtle to command the Mouth; ≈øo that the two Ca≈øtles that are there planted for this purpo≈øe, are not over again≈øt one another.

div.head: A De≈øcription of the City of Damietta.
div.p: DAmietta, called by the Arabians, Dami√°t, a famous City of Egypt, is ≈øcituate upon the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, about eight Miles from the Mouth. Next to Cairo it is the greate≈øt, mo≈øt beautiful, the riche≈øt, the mo≈øt populous, and the fulle≈øt of Merchants of all Egypt; for the conveniency of Trade draws thither a great number of People form all parts of Turkie.

It is built upon the River Nilus, in the form of an half Moon. The Waves of this River that wa≈øh the Foundations of their Hou≈øes on that ≈øide, and the great number of beautiful Mo≈øques, together with the Fleet of Ships and Barques that ride in the Haven, yield a mo≈øt delightful Pro≈øpect.
There are no Walls, nor Fortifications, only a round, and very high Tower, that ≈øtands at the end of the Town towards the Sea; where there is neither Watch nor Ward, nor Guns.
In this City there is great Trading in Linen, Rice, Coffee, and Stuffs. I was told, that every year, about five hundred Ships go out of this Haven, ≈ømall and great, loaded with Rice for Turkie.

Here are made many beautiful ≈øorts of Linen of all kinds and colours, which are Tran≈øported to Foreign Countries. Here is al≈øo a great deal of Fi≈øh ≈øalted. The Mullet that are here pickled are highly e≈øteem'd all over the Levant.

The Town is Governd by an Aga, ≈øent thither from the Pacha, and therefore nam'd by the Turks,
Pachaga≈øi, or the Aga of the Pacha. Be≈øides his other Incomes, he takes from every Tavern of Aquavitae ten Pora's, in the City are a great many ≈øuch Taverns. From every Carache (it being a little Ship) he receives five Pora's; and from greater Ships ≈øix and thirty, and forty, when they go out of the Port: Be≈øides many Ca≈øualties which amount to a great deal, through his extortion, as the manner of the Turks is: for, out of our Ship he took ≈øix Barrels of Cyprus-wine, containing each ≈øix Metres, and every Metre holding twenty Pots, though this was not his due. I had ≈øome difficulty to ≈øave from his greedy hands a Box of excellent Wine of the Country of Ke≈ørovan.
The Souldiery, and chiefly the Jani≈ø≈øaries, are very in≈øolent. There be but two hundred, and about twenty Spahins.
Of the Chri≈øtians, the Grecks are the mo≈øt numerous. They be about two hundred Families, and have a con≈øiderable Church.
Of the Copties there be about eight Families. The Turks, about a year ≈øince, took Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their Church, becau≈øe they had not paid them a certain Tax that they had laid upon them.

There are no Francs that dwell there in the City for want of Trade; becau≈øe this Haven is at a little di≈øtance from all the Chri≈øtian Countries, and becau≈øe they are ≈øettled at Ro≈øetta, which lies more convenient for them, and nearer. There is only a Chamber which the Franci≈øcans of the holy Land have hired in the Apartment of the Greek Patriarch, which is a little Hou≈øe, very filthy, yet they Lodge there when they pa≈øs to and fro from Jeru≈øalem to Cairo. The greate≈øt Traffick in this City, by Sea, is of Wood and Timber which
is Imported as well for Fewel as for the building of Hou≈øes and Ships; for Wood is very ≈øcarce in Egypt, chiefly in the Inferiour.

During my abode in this City I met with an old Ship-Captain, by Religion a Maronite, who told me, that between this City and the Town of Bogas, the River Nilus grew ≈øhallower every year; and that he had taken notice, that about fifteen years ago it was fifteen Cubits deep; but now ≈øcarce fifteen Foot. This proceeds from the Earth, which the Water loo≈øens from its ≈øides and wa≈øhes into the middle; about the Mouth of the River there the Earth ≈øtops. He gather'd from thence, that it was to be fear'd, that in this River great Ships would not be able, one day, to pa≈øs from the Mouth to Damietta.

The Town of Man≈øoura, i. e. Victorious, the abode of the Ca≈øcief of Dekahlie, is a great and beautiful Town, ≈øcituate upon the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus. Its Hou≈øes are not builded as tho≈øe of Damietta, upon the Water, but there is a large Street between them for to walk; but becau≈øe we Landed not then in that place, I had not the opportunity to view it, nor to give an exact De≈øcription of it.

I ≈øhall only ≈øay this of it, That in this Town the French King, S. Lewis, was taken Pri≈øoner by Sultan Saleh, negm iddin, eiiub ibn il Kamel. All the particulars of the end, and carrying on of this War, are to be ≈øeen in the Macrizi, and in Ibn Zulak. I could wi≈øh the≈øe Hi≈øtories of the Arabians were Tran≈ølated into any known Languages, for here are ≈øeveral remarkable Circum≈øtances mentioned in them, with which we are not acquainted. Here are likewi≈øe many Ver≈øes full
of Wit, but Satyrical, made then by the Moors, upon the taking of S. Lewis, and the conclu≈øion of this War, ≈øo happy for their Nation.

Between Damietta and Grand Cairo, are to be ≈øeen, upon the River ≈øide, a prodigious number of Pigeon-hou≈øes, which is here remarkable, becau≈øe there are not found ≈øo many in any other part of Egypt, nor builded in the ≈øame manner.

The≈øe Pigeon-hou≈øes begin at Mitbedri, a Village near Man≈øoura, on the ≈øame ≈øide, in ≈øailing towards Cairo. In one days Journey and a half I ≈øaw ≈øo many, that I wondred at it; for there is ≈øcarce a Hou≈øe in all the Villages but there is one, or more Pigeon-hou≈øes. At the Foundation the Walls are of Earth only, and round on the top, very ≈øpacious within, full of Earthen Pots for the Pigeons Ne≈øts; and without are many Poles for them to pitch on, and re≈øt them≈øelves. It is ea≈øie to judge whether the ≈øight, and Pro≈øpect of ≈øo many Pigeon-hou≈øes be not very delightful.

The Moors that were in our Boat told us, that in the≈øe Villages fifteen Pigeons were commonly ≈øold for one Para; forty Para's make 4 s. 6
d. So that I reckon, that about two hundred and forty Couples were ≈øold for that Money.

Semennut is a great Town, ≈øcituate on the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, in the Ca≈øcieftik of Garbie, not far from Mohelle Kab√≠re, or the great Mohelle. It is built in a Triangular Form; the lower part ≈øtretches it ≈øelf along the River. The Barques that ≈øail towards Cairo are bound to ≈øtop here, and pay Cu≈øtome: The Cu≈øtome-hou≈øe is built upon a Ship, in the River, at which the Ve≈ø≈øels never ≈øtop above an hour.

In the middle Way, between Diametta and Cairo, is Mitgamr, a very beautiful and large Town, ≈øcituate upon the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus. We landed, and I found there many fair Hou≈øes, and a ≈øpacious Bazar, or Market-place, where all manner of Provi≈øions were to be ≈øold. Here are al≈øo a great many Chri≈øtians of the Copties.

Over again≈øt Mitgamr, that is on the We≈øt-≈øide Nilus, is Sitfe, a beautiful and big Town, belonging to to the Ca≈øcieftik of Mohelle Keb√≠re; where we beheld a pur≈øuit of ≈øome Pea≈øants, whom the Ca≈øcief of that Province chas'd. They were come to demand a certain Tribute, which he was wont to pay them: and upon his denial of it they ro≈øe up in Arms again≈øt him: But as ≈øoon as he had ≈øent out the Spahins again≈øt them, they ran all away. The≈øe poor Caitiffs being on Foot, and finding them≈øelves followed by Hor≈øe-men; that they might not fall into their hands, they ca≈øt them≈øelves, in ha≈øte, into the River to ≈øwim over; ≈øix were unhappily drown'd before our Eyes.
In the upper Egypt is a Village, named al≈øo Sitfe; which I ≈øhall mention in another place.

The 12th of April, about two a-Clock in the Afternoon, we left one of the Branches of Nilus that leaves the main River and runs to Damietta, and entred into the Bogas, or Channel of Boulac. The clear Weather gave me the liberty to take notice of the ≈øeparation of the two Branches of the River: I found that the Branch that goes to Ro≈øetta ≈øtretches it ≈øelf to the North-Ea≈øt, and that of Diametta to the North. In re≈øpect of this la≈øt, Cairo ≈øtands to the South-Ea≈øt, and its Ca≈øtle to the South.

At this Bogas the two great Pyramides of Egypt
are fir≈øt di≈øcover'd: They appear here to be equal, though one is far higher than the other.
From this ≈øeparation, or divi≈øion of Nilus, as far as Boulac, there is but an hour and a halfs travelling, though Mon≈øieur Thevenot tells us of ≈øix Leagues.

We landed at Boulac, the Wedne≈øday before Ea≈øter, at Night. I ≈øtaid there till the next Morning, and entred into Cairo about Noon. At my entrance I paid a Crown, at the Cu≈øtome-hou≈øe of Boulac, which is an ordinary Tribute demanded of all Francs many years ago.

div.head: A De≈øcription of the City of Cairo.
div.p: MY de≈øign at fir≈øt, was to publi≈øh a large De≈øcription of all the Rarities of this great and famous City, before I proceed on in my Journal: But ≈øince I have con≈øidered that great Volumes are wont to nau≈øeate, rather than to delight the Reader, chiefly in the≈øe days that Men are pleas'd with the reading of ≈øhort and ≈ømall Volumes: I have therefore taken notice of tho≈øe things only which other Travellers have omitted, and could never know perfectly for want of an in≈øight into the Arabian Tongue. He that will know more, may peru≈øe the ≈øecond Part of the Chottats of Macrizi.

The City of Cairo borrows the Name from the Planet Mars, called by the Arabians, Kaher; which Name was given to it, as ≈øaith the Serr√∫r, an Arabian Hi≈øtorian, becau≈øe the Foundation of its Walls were laid when this Planet was in its a≈øcent; which hapned unhappily in this manner.

Giauher, the General of Meez le d√≠n all√°, one of the Cailiffs of Egypt, having re≈øolved to build a new City for the abode of his Lord, in the Year 362 of the Hegira; he gave orders to the A≈øtronomers, to ob≈øerve the time of the ri≈øing of a good Star, when the Foundation might be laid; that the City might be the more happy, and of a longer continuance.

The A≈øtronomers accordingly encompa≈ø≈øed about with Ropes, all that ≈øpace of Ground that was to be ≈øhut into the Walls; tying to the Ropes a great many little Bells, to give notice to the Builders when they were to ca≈øt the Foundation: The ≈øignal was, the ≈øounding of the Bells; which was to be given when they ≈øaw the ri≈øing of a good Star.

By chance it happen'd, that a Crow pitch'd upon the Ropes that was ≈øtretch'd along, when Mars was in its ri≈øing; and with the motion of the Ropes cau≈øed the Bells to ≈øound: As ≈øoon as the Ma≈øons heard the ≈øignal given, they ca≈øt all, with one con≈øent, the Foundation: which when the A≈øtronomers had under≈øtood, they declar'd by unlucky ri≈øing of Mars, that govern'd at that In≈øtant, that the City ≈øhould be one day taken by a Conqueror that ≈øhould come out of Romania, where Mars governs: Which hath proved true about five hundred and three≈øcore years after, when Sultan Selim came from Con≈øtantinople, the chief City of Romania, and took not only the City, but the whole Country; and de≈øtroyed the Race of their Kings, by hanging the la≈øt.

Though they conceived that this Star would prove unlucky, they called the City neverthele≈øs Kahera, or Cairo, as we name it in Europe:
which Name continues till this day. This City is become very rich, powerful, and great, by its Trade; in≈øomuch, that of all the Cities of the Levant, this alone hath de≈øerv'd the name of Great.

It is ≈øcituate in a Champain, very delightful, at the Foot of a Mountain of Sand, named in Arab. Gebel il mokattam, or the Mountain cut through, which ≈øtands on the Ea≈øt-≈øide, and incommodes the City; becau≈øe it deprives it of the benefit of the fre≈øh Winds that blow from thence. This City hath another inconveniency, it is far from the River.

There is nothing in the World more delightful, than to take a pro≈øpect of it from ≈øome eminent place: for you might from thence view an infinite number of Hou≈øes, which, in≈øtead of Coverings, have Turrets; and ≈øee an innumerable company of Mo≈øques with their various colours of differing Buildings intermingled, and ≈øurrounded with Palm-trees, and Gardens; all which together repre≈øents a mo≈øt beautiful Pro≈øpect.
It hath ≈øeven Gates. The Names are, 1. Bab zucile; 2. Bab inna≈ø≈ør; 3. Bab il fet√∫b; 4. Bab il K√°ntara; 5. Bab i≈ø≈øcia a r√≠e; 6. Bab i≈ø≈øaade; 7. Bab il mahr√∫k.

There are eight Lakes, very large, that belong to it: 1. Birket ittem√°lgie; 2. Birket ina≈ø≈ør√≠e; 3. Birket ibn il ademe; 4. Birket il fil; 5. Birket il kar-a; 6. Birket il ferrain; 7. Birket il Ezbekie; and 8. Birket il ka≈ø≈øarin.

There is a Channel cut through this City, from the We≈øt, to the North-Ea≈øt, called the Calitz of Cairo. It is very ancient, Ibn abd il hokm, an
Arabian Hi≈øtorian, ≈øaith; That Tar≈øis ibn Malia, one of the Pharaoh's; and, as he believes, the King that took the Wife of Abraham when he was in Egypt, cau≈øed it fir≈øt to be cut. Since the Arabians conquer'd Egypt, and took it from the Emperour Heraclius, they have named it Calitz Emir il Muminin, or The Channel of the Prince of the faithful, becau≈øe of Amru ibn Chottab, the ≈øecond Califf after Mahomet, who was the fir≈øt ≈øirnamed The Prince of the faithful, becau≈øe he commanded Amru ibn a≈ø≈ø to lead him as far as Colzim, a Town ≈øcituate near the Red-Sea, that he might convey the Provi≈øions of Cairo as far as this City, and from thence by the Red-Sea to Mecha; where there was, at that time, a great want of Food. It continued in this manner till the Year 150 of the Hegira, when Ciafer il Man≈øur, a Califf of Egypt, of the Race of Abbas, cau≈øed it to be ≈øtopt on that ≈øide which is towards the Sea.

Now it is called Calitz il Hakemi, or the Calitz of Hakem; becau≈øe Hakem-be amr ille, another Califf of Egypt, cau≈øed this Channel, which was decayed through the negligence of his Predece≈ø≈øors, to be repaired. It is called al≈øo Merachemi, or the Calitz paved with Marble; as we may ≈øee by ≈øome Pa≈ø≈øages of the Serr√∫r, an Arabian Hi≈øtory which I have brought with me from Egypt.

In my Relation of Egypt, Printed in Italian at Paris, 1671. I ≈øaid that the Turks, Copties, and Jews, open, in their turns, this Channel every Year: but I under≈øtand ≈øince, that this Office belongs only to the Souba≈øchi of Cairo, who ≈øtrikes the fir≈øt three, or four blows upon the Bank that hinders the River from entring into the Channel,
afterwards all that will work have liberty granted.

The Copies have but two Churches at Cairo; one in the Street named Haret Zuele, and the other in the Greek's Street. The fir≈øt is Dedicated to the Virgin Mary, and was built by a renowned Phy≈øician, named Zabulon. He lived about two-hundred-≈øeventy years before the Arabians became Ma≈øters of Egypt. He is yet famous for his wonderful Riches. They ≈øay that he hid them in a Well which is in the ≈øame Church, and ≈øecur'd them with a Tali≈øman, that none might have them after his decea≈øe. The Patriarch of the Copties Hou≈øe is joining to this Church.
The other in the Greek's Street is Dedicated to S. Barba. It is but ≈ømall, and ob≈øcure. I went to ≈øee it the 4th of November 1672.

Heretofore they had many Churches, and Mona≈øteries; and a Bi≈øhop in the Chandak, an old Suburb of Cairo, but now ruinated. But now they have but two; one Dedicated to the Arch-Angel Gabriel; the other to the Abbot Mercurius, ≈øirnamed Roes. Here the Copties of Cairo have a Burying-place.

Of the many Mo≈øques at Cairo, that which is called Giama ill a≈ø≈øar is the riche≈øt, and the greate≈øt. It was built by Giauher, the fir≈øt Founder of the City: It is yet the Cathedral, where the four Mouftis, or Doctors of the Mahometan Law re≈øide. It is a Refuge for Offenders, and a School for to teach the Law of Mahomet, with its Revenues it entertains no le≈øs than eight hundred Per≈øons of that Profe≈ø≈øion; and receives for that purpo≈øe two thou≈øand Ardebs of Corn, from the Store-hou≈øes of the Grand Seignior; and ≈øeven
thou≈øand more from other Benefactors.

There are four Mouftis at Cairo that borrow their Names from the four chief Sects of Mahemet: 1. Of Sciaffe√≠ 2. Of Maleki; 3. Of Hambali; 4. Of Hanefi. They are all equal in Dignity, becau≈øe their Sects, whereof they are the chief, are likewi≈øe equal.

They have power to excommunicate the Pacha's when they attempt to do any thing again≈øt their Religion, or their Mo≈øques. For In≈øtance, they excommunicated Pacha Ibrahim in the year 1672, becau≈øe he offered to take away ≈øome of the Gifts, and Rents, belonging to the Mo≈øques of Cairo: By that means they hinder'd him from executing his ≈øacrilegious de≈øign. When the Excommunication prevails not, they ≈øhut the Gates of this Mo≈øque, which cau≈øes the People to ri≈øe up in Arms; and they never are quiet, till they have kill'd the Offender.

In Cairo, and in its Suburbs, there are nine publick Shambles belonging to the Grand Seignior: 1. That of Ha≈ø≈øen√≠e, which is the greate≈øt: 2. That of Haret Jeh√∫d, or of the Street of the Jews: 3. That of Bab illuk, or of the Whore's Quarter: 4. That of the Lions Bridge: 5. That of old Cairo: 6. That of G√≠ze: 7. That of Haret il ≈øakkain: 8. That of Telun: 9. Two that are at Boulac; whereof, in one the Oxen are killed; in the other, the Sheep and Goats.
The Heads, and the Skins of all the Bea≈øts that are kill'd in the≈øe Markets, unle≈øs it be of the Goats, belong to the Grand Seignior: out of this Cu≈øtome he receives a great profit.

It is very true, that in Cairo are ≈øeven differing Orders of the Militia. Among≈øt the≈øe, the
Montro≈ø≈øes, and Gunners, are not reckon'd; but only the Metferracas, three Cornets of Spahins, which be il Gi√∫mulli, il Tefak≈øchi, and il C√©rca≈ø≈øi. The Jani≈ø≈øaries, the Chiaoux, and the Azapes, belong to them.

The Jani≈ø≈øaries, the Spahins, the Azapes, and the Gebegis, are paid only every three Months; but the Chiaoux, and Metferracas, the Jetams, or Orphelins, the Giavalis, the Ke≈øcie, and the Metkaeds receive their pay every Month, without any delay.

div.head: A De≈øcription of Old Cairo.
div.p: OLD Cairo, ≈øo called erroneou≈øly by the Francs, is named by the Arabians, Ma≈ø≈ør, from Ma≈ø≈ør, or Mizraim, the Son of Cham, and Grand-child of Noah, that cau≈øed it to be built. It is the anciente≈øt City of Egypt, next to Memphis; after the de≈øtruction of this, Old Cairo became the chief. It is ≈øcituate on the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, over again≈øt the place where Memphis ≈øtood, next to New Cairo. It was heretofore a ≈øtately City, but now it is almo≈øt all ruinated.

In the 18th year of the Hegira, which is about 1033 years ≈øince that Amru ibn il a≈ø≈ø, General of Amru ibn Chottab, a ≈øucce≈ø≈øor of Mahomet, took this City. John Mekaukes, a noble Coptie, was then Governour for the Emperour Heraclius. When Amru had taken it, he made Peace with Mekaukes, upon condition that every Coptie ≈øhould pay him, and all his Succe≈ø≈øors, two-pence a-year as a Tribute; and that he ≈øhould give entertainment, for three days, to all the Arabians that
≈øhould pa≈øs through Egypt; as may be ≈øeen more fully in the Macrizi.
This City hath been increas'd many times, as the Conquerors, and Lords of the Country, did think convenient to pitch upon a more plea≈øant place for their abode.
The places where the Fo≈øtat, the Ca≈ø≈ør i≈øc√©mma, the Quarter of the Patriarch of the Copties, Babylon, Cateia, the Caraff, and others.

Fo≈øtat is a Greek Name, which ≈øignifies a Tent of Goat-skins. The Arabians name one ≈øide of Old Cairo thus, becau≈øe the Tent of Amru ibn il a≈ø≈ø, of this ≈øub≈øtance, was planted there when he was bu≈øie in Conquering Egypt.

The ≈øame Amru cau≈øed it to be inclo≈øed in with Walls; after that he had taken the City of Alexdria, he ≈øettled there his abode, and that of his Succe≈ø≈øors: Alexandria, that had been the Royal City of the Greeks for about nine hundred years, was then for≈øaken; and the Fo≈øtat was the chief City of Egypt. It continued ≈øo till Ahmed ibn Toulon built Cateia very near Fo≈øtat. His Succe≈ø≈øors of his Race for≈øook it, and ≈øettled them≈øelves in Cateia.

But when this Race was extinct, and Grand Cairo being built by Giauher, as we have ≈øaid, the Califfs cho≈øe it for their abode, cau≈øing Fo≈øtat to be burnt, that the new City might be ≈øtronger, and fuller of People; and they left Cateia, as we may ≈øee in Macrizi.

Ca≈ø≈ør I≈ø≈øc√©mma, is a Ca≈øtle, or Suburb, inclo≈øed with Walls, near adjoining to Fo≈øtat, built by Artaxerxes, King of Per≈øia. Now only Chri≈øtians inhabit there. They have many Churches which we ≈øhall de≈øcribe in this following Journal; for I
went to ≈øee them on the 18th day of July, 1672.

There are two differing Opinions concerning the Origine of this Name. Some would have it written, Ca≈ø≈ør iggiama; that is, the Ca≈øtle of the A≈ø≈øembly: for they ≈øay, that here the great Wits did meet to increa≈øe Learning; but this Opinion is not well grounded. Others write it Ca≈ø≈ør i≈ø≈øc√©mma; this is likely to be the true≈øt; for I find it thus written by all Arabian Hi≈øtorians.

The Granaries and Store-hou≈øes, of the Grand Seignior, are adjoining to this Ca≈øtle. They are named by the Arabs, Sci√≥ne. The Provi≈øions of Corn, and other nece≈ø≈øaries for the Food of the Malitia, are here kept; not only for the Malitia of Egypt, but al≈øo for all the other Countries that depend upon Egypt.

And that this Corn might be better di≈øtributed, there are four Aga's, or Officers, named in Arab. Agavat beta il ghel√†l, or Aga's of the Stores in the upper Egypt: One dwells at Bene≈øuef, another at Minie, the third at Momfallat, the fourth at Girge. Their Office is, to gather up the Provi≈øions of Corn, and to ≈øend them to the Emin il Sci√≥ne, the Ma≈øter of the Store-hou≈øes of the Grand Seignior, who upon a certain day of the Month, cau≈øes the≈øe Provi≈øions to be di≈øtributed according as the Divan appoints.

But becau≈øe ≈øometimes this allowance is not ≈øufficient, every one hath liberty to buy more, by paying for every Ardeb a thou≈øand Meidins. When this Money is once paid, every year one may fetch this allowance, during the Buyer's life.

Near this Ca≈ø≈ør i≈ø≈øcemma, on a ≈øide of Cairo, is the Quarter of the Patriarch of the Copties,
named in Arab. Haret il Batrak. It is ≈øeparated from this Ca≈øtle with an high Wall, with which it is inclo≈øed. The Patriarch hath his Abode a little above the Church of Mary Moncure; concerning which, I ≈øhall take notice of ≈øome curio≈øities in the ≈øequel of this Di≈øcour≈øe.

Babylon was further towards the South of Cairo. Now there appears nothing but great Mountains of its Ruines, and three Churches of the Copties; one dedicated to the Virgin Mary, another to S. Theodorus, the third to S. John Abak√Ær.

The Church of the Virgin, as the Copties relate, was the fir≈øt that was built at Cairo, after the coming of our Saviour Chri≈øt. They ≈øay that S. Mark hath preach'd there; and that S. Peter mentions it at the end of his Epi≈øtle, when he ≈øaith, that the Church elect which is in Babylon Ma≈ø≈ør, or Babylon near Cairo, ≈øalute you, as well as my Son Marcus. I did not go into it at this time, but I ≈øaw it, and lay there one Night in my fir≈øt Voyage to Egypt, in the year 1664.
Cateia was built near Fo≈øtat, by Ahmed ibn Toulon, Prince of Egypt, as we have already ≈øaid.

The Caraffa is the Burying-place of the Mahometans; highly e≈øteem'd, becau≈øe there be ≈øome Kindred of Mahomet, and ≈øome of their Saints, buried. In the flouri≈øhing days of Egypt there were above three hundred and ≈øixty Tombs, and Mo≈øques of Great Men; every one endowed with a ≈øufficient allowance for poor People, and the Pilgrims of that Religion that came thither. So that a Pilgrim, at Cairo, could have ≈øub≈øi≈øted a whole year without ≈øpending an A≈øper, by vi≈øiting every day the Mo≈øques and Tombs of this
place; but in proce≈øs of time the Revenues being devoured, by the wickedne≈øs of the Pacha's, the Tombs and Mo≈øques are ≈øince gone to decay.

div.head: The Continuation of the Journal.
div.p: THE 16th of April 1672. Saturday before Ea≈øter, the French Con≈øul went to vi≈øit the Pacha, who was then in a Garden at the Village Be≈øe≈øtein: he went to ≈øpeak to him about a bu≈øine≈øs of his Nation. I took this occa≈øion to offer him my Letters of re-commendation which I≈øhac, Pacha of Seida, had given me to deliver to him. In con≈øideration of them, he promis'd me his protection and favour.

div.head: The way of Hatching Chickens at Cairo.
div.p: The 21≈øt of this Month I went to ≈øee the Ovens where the Chickens are hatched. The≈øe Ovens are builded in the ≈øame manner as the Ovens of France, made to bake Bread, only with this difference; they are not ≈øo high, nor ≈øo big as ours, nor of burnt Brick, but of Brick dried in the Sun. They have al≈øo, on the top, a round hole, as big as the circumference of a French Hat, through which the heat mounts up and goes out, which Ovens for Bread have not.

In the Hou≈øe where I ≈øaw them, they were plac'd in this manner. There were four and twenty: twelve on the right hand, and twelve on the left; ≈øix one upon another. At the fir≈øt ≈øight one would have thought them to be ≈øo many Sleeping-cells of Monks: but the Alley that was between
was ≈øo narrow, that when I enter'd in, the ≈ømoak and heat that came out had almo≈øt ≈øtifled me.

Now, to cau≈øe the Egs to be hatch'd, they put them all in the lowermo≈øt Ovens; and in the uppermo≈øt they kindle a ≈ømall Fire, for eight days, with Straw. Afterwards they ≈øtop them, and leave them ≈øo ≈øix other days: Then they take away the Egs from the lowermo≈øt Ovens, and ≈øeparate the good from the bad, by examining them in the Sun-≈øhine. Afterwards they ca≈øt away the addled, and put all the good in the uppermo≈øt Ovens; making, with Straw, a ≈ømall Fire in the lowermo≈øt, for two days. They leave them in that condition one and twenty days, without medling with them: at which time the Chickens begin to break the Shell; ≈øo that in two and twenty days they bring forth Chickens in this manner.

This is not to be practis'd, but during four Months in the Year; namely, from the Month of December, till the Month of April: The other part of the Year is not fit for this purpo≈øe, becau≈øe of the exce≈ø≈øive heats.

div.head: Of the Pyramides.
div.p: IN my fir≈øt Voyage to Egypt I had ≈øeen the Pyramides; but, having another opportunity offer'd to me, I went thither to view again the≈øe rare Monuments of Antiquity, to ≈øee whether I might not ob≈øerve ≈øomething more than I have taken notice of in my fir≈øt Relation.

On the 27th of April I went thither, in the Company of the French Con≈øul, and many other
Merchants, and with almo≈øt all his Hou≈øhold: we had with us three Jani≈ø≈øaries to guard us, ≈øo that we were in all about fifty Cavaliers, well mounted upon A≈ø≈øes; taking with us Provi≈øions ≈øufficient for three days.

When we were come to the Pyramides, and had ob≈øerv'd exactly every thing: I took notice that the place where they ≈øtood was a Burying-place. This is plain to any that ≈øee the place; and doubtle≈øs it was the burying-place of the old City Memphis; for all the Arabian Hi≈øtories inform us, that this City ≈øtood where the Pyramides now are, over again≈øt Old Cairo.

2. I took notice that all the Pyramides have an entrance that leads to a low Alley, which is very long; and at the end is a Chamber, where the ancient Egyptians did place the Bodies of tho≈øe Per≈øons, for whom the Pyramides was built. This entrance is not to be ≈øeen in every one of the Pyramides, becau≈øe the Wind hath ≈øtopt them with Sand. I ≈øaw upon ≈øome of them ≈øome Hierogliphick Characters, but I had not time to write them out.

3. I took notice that all the Pyramides were builded in very good order; and that each of the three greate≈øt were at the head of ten le≈ø≈øer, which are not well to be di≈øtingui≈øhed, becau≈øe of the heaps of Sand: one may yet imagine, to ≈øee the place, that in former Ages there have been here one hundred Pyramides, little and great.

4. I took notice that they are all builded upon an even Rock, covered over with white Sand; ≈øo that it is very probable that the Stones have been taken from the place, and not brought from
far, as ≈øome Travellers imagine, and old Writers: for the greate≈øt is nothing but a Rock cut as a Pyramide, and covered over with a Wall of Stone.

5. I took notice that of all the Stones of the greate≈øt, there is ≈øcarce one entire, but either worn out with the Weather and Time, or broken by ≈øome other Accident; ≈øo that, though one may a≈øcend on all ≈øides to the top, yet not in all places with the ≈øame ea≈øe.

6. I have taken notice that none of the Pyramides are alike, or perfectly ≈øquare; but that all have two ≈øides longer than the others. I intended to mea≈øure the greate≈øt: for that purpo≈øe I had with me a String of about thirty Landyards; but becau≈øe the Winds have heap'd about it Mountains of Sand, I could not po≈ø≈øibly draw a Line ≈øtrait from one Angle to the other.

On the 28th day of December I went to ≈øee the Pyramides the third time, with ≈øome ≈øtrangers. In our way we were mightily troubled with a very thick Mi≈øt, which la≈øted till ten a Clock in the Morning; and we found a great deal of Mud in the Trenches and Ditches, which was not yet dry ≈øince the retreat of the River; ≈øo that we were carried over upon the Moors backs that were with us.

At this time I went up to the top of the great Pyramide; and I ob≈øerv'd, as at the fir≈øt, that the place where the Pyramides ≈øtand, is a pure Rock, cover'd over with white Sand; which appears ≈øufficiently by the Ditches and Caves round about the Pyramides cut in the Rock.

2. The Rock is to be ≈øeen, upon which ≈øtands the greate≈øt Pyramide, by a hole at one of the
Angles, between the Ea≈øt and the North ≈øides.
3. The Pyramides are not builded with Marble, as ≈øome ≈øay; but with a white ≈øandy Stone, very hard.

4. The greate≈øt hath but two hundred and ≈øix ≈øteps; and though Mon≈øieur Th. ≈øaith that it hath two hundred and eight, this proceeds from his not taking notice that two ≈øteps are broken into four.

5. On the top of the greate≈øt Pyramide there was anciently a Statue, or Colo≈ø≈øe. This appears, becau≈øe it is not ≈øharp as the others, but plain: And there are yet to be ≈øeen great Pits, which were to keep fa≈øt the Colo≈ø≈øe from falling.

At pre≈øent there is nothing on the top but many Letters of the Names of Per≈øons or all Nations, who have left them to witne≈øs that they had been there. There is no ≈øign of the Play at Mancala, which a Coptie told me was there imprinted in the days of the Pharaoh's.

6. The Stones of the bigge≈øt Pyramide are not equal; for ≈øome of the undermo≈øt are four Foot high, ≈øome three Foot and an half, and five Foot long. The Stones of the middle are three Foot and five Inches high, and the uppermo≈øt Stones are but two Foot high, and three and an half long.
7. The ≈øides of the Pyramides are not equal; for in the greate≈øt it is vi≈øible, and ≈øo in the others, that the North-≈øide is longer than that which ≈øtretches from Ea≈øt to We≈øt.
8. In all the Pyramides there are very deep Wells cut in the Rock, ≈øquare; as I have ≈øeen in more than ten.

On the 26th day of June I went the fourth time
to ≈øee the Pyramides, in the Company of Mon≈øieur Sabatery, Vice-Con≈øul of Alexandria.

In the Pa≈ø≈øage to Old Cairo, on the other ≈øide of the River, I took notice of one thing very remarkable in its Channel: The Water was perfectly green, as a Cake covered over with green Gra≈øs. This was the fir≈øt time that I ≈øaw it of this colour; which cau≈øed me to ask of the Boat-men, what this green colour was? They told me, tint the River Nilus did then putrifie, that it had continued ≈øo fifteen days, and would be ≈øo five more. Some of them ≈øaid, that there was none could remember to have ≈øeen the River ≈øo green as that year, 1672.

To return again to the Pyramides: I went up this time to the top of the highe≈øt Pyramide: I enter'd into the Chamber, but ≈øaw no new thing which could cau≈øe me either to change, or add to my former Ob≈øervations. It is needle≈øs to ≈øpeak of its Dimen≈øions, ≈øeeing ≈øo many Travellers have already publi≈øh'd them, as Mon≈øieur Thevenot in his Levant Travels.

From the Pyramides we went to take a view of the Caves that are adjoining. There are many, all cut in the ≈øide of a Rock: Their out-≈øides are out of order, without any proportion; but their in-≈øide very equal, and polli≈øh'd. In every one there is a deep Well ≈øquare, cut in the Rock, where the Egyptians did put the Body of that Per≈øon, for whom the Cave was made; for it was their Sepulchre. The walls of many of the≈øe Caves are full of Hieroglyphick Figures, carved in the Rock. In ≈øome they are but ≈ømall, in others very lively. In one I number'd ≈øixteen great Figures, that repre≈øented eight Men and eight
Women, holding one another by the hands; with many other ≈ømall Figures, or Shapes, on both ≈øides.

div.head: Of the Sphinx.
div.p: WE ≈øaw next the Sphinx, near the Pyramides, on the Ea≈øt-≈øide. On the top ≈øtands the Head of a Woman of an extraordinary bigne≈øs and height. The Arabians call it Abulhon, or Abul-houl.

Pliny ≈øaith that it was the Tomb of King Ama≈øis. I imagine that this Sphinx was a Sepulchre, but we cannot under≈øtand that it belong'd to Ama≈øis; for all the Records and Traditions of this Sphinx are lo≈øt.

That it is a Tomb may appear, Fir≈øt by its ≈øcituation, which is in a place which was in former Ages a Burying-place; and near the Pyramides, and mortuary Caves. Secondly it is to be imagined that it was a Sepulchre from its building. In the hinder part is a Cave under ground, of a bigne≈øs an≈øwerable to that of the Head, into which I have look'd by an entrance that leads into it; ≈øo that it could ≈øerve to no other purpo≈øe but to keep a dead Corps.

Some Francs have, out of an exce≈øs of curio≈øity, climb'd up by the means of Rope-Ladders, to ≈øee whether this Head was hollow, or ma≈ø≈øie; and they have found it to be hollow, but filled at pre≈øent with Sand.
The Neck is worn out round about, which cau≈øeth Men to imagine that it will not be able to ≈øupport the weight of that great Head.

div.head: Of the Wells where the Mommies are.
div.p: WHen we had fully viewed this Sphinx, we took the Road that leads to Sacc√°ra, a Village, at four hours travelling from the Pyramides, and about eight from Cairo towards the South. The Burying-place of the Mommies is near adjoining to this Village.

And becau≈øe it was very late, and that we were to agree with the Arabians of the Village about the Price, the Number and Quality of the Wells that they were to open for us. We ≈øtopt there all Night, and the next Morning we took with us twelve Hor≈øe-men, to Guard us, of the Arabians; with them we went to this Burying-place, where the Mommies are in Caves under ground.

The fir≈øt Well that we ≈øaw was that of Birds Embalmed. When we had cau≈øed the Sand that ≈øtops the Wells Mouth to be removed, through which we were to go down, and from thence to enter into the Cave; we cau≈øed our ≈øelves to be let down one after another, by tying a double Rope about our middles. As ≈øoon as we were at the bottom, and that every one had lighted his Taper, and ≈øeveral Matches that we had brought, we went into the Cave creeping upon our Bellies. The Cave is an Alley in the Rock, about the height of a Man, and about the breadth of a Perch; and of an extraordinary length. We found there many other Alleys on both hands, cut in the Rock; where were many large ≈øtores, full of Earthen Pots, covered over with Coverings of the ≈øame ≈øub≈øtance. In the≈øe Pots were Embalmed Birds
of all kinds, every Bird in its own Pot. And as I thought that the remembrance of a Cu≈øtom ≈øo ancient, and ≈øuper≈øtitious, was worthy of our notice, I brought about half a dozen with me; ≈øome I have ≈øent to the King's Library. We found al≈øo ≈øome Hens Egs, empty, but entire without any ill ≈ømell or crack.

When we had viewed ≈øufficiently this Cave, we returned up in the ≈øame manner that we went down, and found another open'd, called the Virgin; which is, that was never open'd before: According to our orders to the Arabians, Mon≈øieur Tiger and the others went down in the ≈øame manner as into the former; I alone could not follow them, becau≈øe of a Quartain Fever which had troubled me fourteen months, and took me at that very Moment: But I lo≈øt nothing by that: for the≈øe Gentlemen told me at their return, that they found an horrid ≈øtench, and a clo≈øe air, that put out their Candles, and their Matches al≈øo, every time that they endeavour'd to light them; which cau≈øed them to get up again without entring further. They told me that this Well was much deeper than the former.
We cau≈øed another to be open'd, which was not a Virgin Well, as the former, becau≈øe it was not ≈øo deep. I ventur'd into that, notwith≈øtanding my indi≈øpo≈øition.

We found there two Mommies, a great one, and a little one of a Child, both in Coffins, the greate≈øt was of Marble; upon the Covering it had the likene≈øs of the Per≈øon for whom it was made: We caus'd the≈øe Biers, or Coffins, to be open'd, but found nothing extraordinary; therefore we made no account of them, and left them where we found them.

We went down next into a Cave, called The Church, which was not ≈øo deep as the former. It was nothing but a long Alley under ground, well Plai≈øter'd, and Painted all over with Hieroglyphick Figures round about the ≈øides. It was almo≈øt all full of Sand, which cau≈øed us to creep along upon our Knees.

If the Reader de≈øires a Pro≈øpect, and a De≈øcription of this ancient Burying-place, let him think upon a boundle≈øs Champain, even and covered over with Sand; where neither Trees, nor Gra≈øs, nor Hou≈øes, nor any ≈øuch thing is to be ≈øeen: Let him repre≈øent to him≈øelf the Superficies of this large Field full of dry Bones of Arms, Legs, Feet, and Heads; full of ≈øcattered pieces of Wood of Coffins, of little Idols, ≈øome of Wood, others of Plai≈øter embolli≈øh'd with green, and mark'd before and behind with Hieroglyphick Letters. The≈øe Idols the Arabians have taken from the broken Mommies which they have ca≈øt away. In ≈øome places you may ≈øee great Tomb-≈øtones, full of Cyphers and enigmatical Figures that repre≈øent ≈øomething of Chymi≈øtry, and of other Sciences and My≈øteries; and full of ≈øtrange Characters that are no Hieroglyphicks. Whiles I was looking upon this Spectacle the Arabians brought me two, whereof I cau≈øed the Coppies to be drawn as ≈øoon as I was returned to Cairo.

You have here a De≈øcription of ≈øome Relicks of the Grandeur and Vanity of the ancient Egyptians, and the mournful ≈øigns of Man's Mortality. The fir≈øt ≈øight is able to da≈øh a Per≈øon newly arrived, out of Countenance, and to affright him: I mean the ≈øight of ≈øo many Bones all ≈øcattered
up and down, one would think that here hath been a grievous fight.

In this Champain, or Field, here are fifteen Pyramides: three are of an extraordinary bigne≈øs, which ≈øeem to have been favour'd by Time; for they appear entire without much decay. Here is al≈øo an entrance in every one, that ≈øhews a long Alley which leads to a Chamber; Mon≈øieur de Tiger went into that which is farthe≈øt from the Village, commonly named The Pyramide of Rodope, where he found nothing in the Chamber.

This Pyramide is built as a Pavillion. The Francs ≈øay that Rodope, a famous Strumpet, caus'd it to be built with the Money that ≈øhe had gotten with the lo≈øs of her honour. But this is doubtle≈øs an error, if it be true what Pliny ≈øaith, That the Pyramide of Rodope was but ≈ømall, though very beautiful; therefore this which is one of the greate≈øt in all Egypt cannot be that of Rodope. The≈øe are the words of Pliny: Supremumque illud ne quis Regum opes miretur, minimam extiti≈ø≈øe laudati≈ø≈øimam √† Rodope meretricula factam. Ae≈øopi fabularum Philo≈øophi con≈øerva quondam, & contubernalis haec fuit, majore miraculo tantas opes meretricio e≈ø≈øe conqui≈øitas quae≈øtu.
For the others that are in the ≈øame Field, Time hath almo≈øt worn them out; for they are but ≈øo many heaps of Sand, which have ≈øcarce the ≈øhape and ≈øhadow of what they have been heretofore.

Here is al≈øo a ≈øquare heap of very great hewn Stones. The Arabians name it Ma≈øtabet Faraoun: for they ≈øay, that when the Pharaoh's, Kings of Egypt, were to declare and give a new
Law to to the People, they ≈øtood on the top of this heap. But the≈øe are the Traditions of the poor Arabians that have nothing of certainty.

To return to the Wells of the Mommies: as ≈øoon as the Francs have vi≈øited any, the Wind, or the Arabians, fill the entry again full of Sand, to get a little Money at the ≈øecond opening. This is the greate≈øt gain of the≈øe Wretches. The lea≈øt they take for to open a Virgin Well is thirty Pia≈øters, becau≈øe they that make the Well to be opened, have the liberty to carry away all the Curio≈øities and Mommies that he finds there.

We return'd, after two days ab≈øence, to the City Cairo again; and the 6th of May I went to vi≈øit the Greek Arch-Bi≈øhop of Mount Sinai, who was then re≈øident at Cairo about ≈øome concerns of his Mona≈øtery. Among≈øt other things, he told me that he had a Manu≈øcript of the Council of Florence, differing from all tho≈øe Copies that are Printed in Europe. Mon≈øieur de Tiger hath a Copy of this ≈øuppo≈øed Original.

The Monks of this Mona≈øtery have a priviledge from Mahomet, ≈øigned according to the Cu≈øtome of that time by the impre≈ø≈øion of his Hand, which frees them from the Carach, or Tax, which the Mahometans require of the Chri≈øtians ≈øubject to them. This was the cau≈øe wherefore Mahomet granted them this favour, as the Arch-Bi≈øhop told me, to expre≈øs his thanks to that Hou≈øe for the kind entertainment which he had received at the hands of tho≈øe Monks when he kept, and watch'd over their Camels.

We di≈øcours'd afterwards concerning the Plague of the former Year. He told me, that it had ≈øwept away ≈øix hundred and four≈øcore thou≈øand
Per≈øons, but that it had ≈øcarce medled with any but the poor; and that of the richer fort ≈øcarce four hundred were dead.

This cau≈øeth me to ≈øpeak a word of Father Elzear of Nants, a very worthy Per≈øon; and his Comrade, Father Portais; both of the Capuchin Order, and zealous Mi≈ø≈øionaries, whom this Plague carried away. The fir≈øt was buried out of the City Cairo, in a Field where the poor Copies are buried, for who≈øe Conver≈øion he was intended.

To honour the Memory of his Vertues, there is an Epitaph in Arab. and Latin, upon a little Stone fixed upon his Grave; and becau≈øe I was well acquainted with him in my fir≈øt Voyage which I made into Egypt, by the Orders and Commands of Erne≈øt, Duke of Saxa-Gota, in the Year 1664. I went to ≈øee his Grave, and to repeat for the repo≈øe of his Soul, and as a Te≈øtimony of my remembrance and e≈øteem of his rare Qualities, the Prayer De profundis.

div.head: A Journy to Gemiane.
div.p: WHen the time was come that the Copties ob≈øerve the Fe≈øtival of the Aparitions of the Saints at Gemiane; becau≈øe I had not ≈øeen it in my fir≈øt Voyage, I went from Cairo on Monday the 9th of May, with a Servant of Mon≈øieur de Tiger, named Leonard, that could Paint very well, with ≈øeveral Copties who came in our Company, becau≈øe they had nothing to di≈øcharge the expence of this Journy. We went aboard at Boulac, and ≈øet ≈øail for the Town of Man≈øoura, where we landed the 12th of the ≈øame Month.

The next day we left Man≈øoura, taking a Boat for Dia≈øt, a little Village ≈øcituate upon the We≈øt-≈øide of Niltus; for here all Travellers that go to Gemiane from Cairo are wont to land. It ≈øtands about four hours journying from Man≈øoura. At our landing we left our Boat and went by Land to Bo≈ø≈øat ino≈ø≈ø√°ra, a little Mile di≈øtant from the River, in the Land; we ≈øpent there the Night, and lodg'din the Church of S. George, with ≈øeveral other Copties whom we found there, who were bound al≈øo, as well as we, for Gemiane.

The 14th day very early we proceeded on towards the third branch of Nilus, which begins, as I have already ≈øaid in the De≈øcription of this River, at Sciobret il Yemen; which it hath pa≈øs'd near the Town of Mohelle Keb√≠re, or Great Mohelle, and near Gemiane it di≈øcharges it ≈øelf into the Sea at Brullos. We march'd on into the Country, and when we came to this Branch of the River we found ≈øeveral Boats ready to carry us with the Current to Gemiane, where we landed about the Evening, not without ≈øuffering many cro≈ø≈øes, and inconveniences; becau≈øe the Ma≈øter of the Boat, an Arabian, was a wicked Rogue.

Gemiane is a famous Church of the Copties, built in a large Champain; very even and boundle≈øs to the Eye, but very unfruitful, in the Province of Garbie in the I≈øle of Delta. It ≈øtands near the place where was anciently the City Degue, called by the Copties Tekebi. On the We≈øt it hath the Great Mohelle, on the Ea≈øt the Branch of the River that enters into the Sea at Brullos, and on the North the Mediteranean Sea. This Church hath five and twenty Arches, or I≈øles, that yield at a di≈øtance a very beautiful Pro≈øpect,
though they be not in order nor equal in bigne≈øs.

The Church within is not yet fini≈øh'd, and there is but one Chappel whited with Lime, namely that where the ≈øuppo≈øed Apparition happens: there is al≈øo but one Altar, as in all other Churches of the Levant. All the Iles, or Arches, ≈øerve to adorn the Church, and to give light to it; for in every one there is a Window, and in ≈øome two. The Chappel where the Apparition happens is on the North-≈øide, on the right hand as one enters in, and over again≈øt the Door.

During three days I examin'd this Apparition, and the cau≈øes from whence it proceeds as exactly as I could po≈ø≈øibly; and found it to be nothing el≈øe but the reflection of the Objects that went by the Church at a convenient di≈øtance, which being carried into the Chappel, by the Air, through the two Windows that give light. It repre≈øents, over again≈øt upon the Wall, the Shadow which is like the Object that goes by: For Example; when a Hor≈øe-man goes by, there is to be ≈øeen upon the Wall, in a confu≈øed manner, a Shadow of a Man on Hor≈øe-back. If it be a Woman that hath a Child in her Arms, one may ≈øee the Shadow of that appearance; and ≈øo is it with all other things. Now the People being ≈øuper≈øtitious and of a dull apprehen≈øion, not knowing how this happens, fancy that the Saints appear to them.

They know and di≈øtingui≈øh them, according as they are painted in their Churches: For Example, when they ≈øee the Shadow that repre≈øents a Cavalier, they ≈øay that it is S. George; for the Copties, as well as the other People of the Ea≈øt, repre≈øent him as a Man on Hor≈øe-back, killing a
Dragon. When they ≈øee a Woman carrying of an Infant in her Arms, they ≈øay that it is the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, becau≈øe they ≈øee her thus repre≈øented in the Pictures of their Churches. When they ≈øee the Shadow of a Man on foot of a reddi≈øh colour, they ≈øay that it is S. Menna, becau≈øe they paint him with a red Habit. They di≈øtingui≈øh the other Saints in the ≈øame manner. They are ≈øo much bewitch'd with the fancy of the reality of the≈øe Apparitions, that if any Per≈øon ≈øhould offer to deny it, he would be in danger to be knock'd on the head.

It is in vain to an≈øwer that the Shadows that appear in this Chappel cannot be formed by the reflection of the Objects, becau≈øe the Windows, through which they come in, are at the North-≈øide of the Church which never enjoys the Sun≈øhine; and that therefore they be true and real Apparitions.

To this I reply, that it is not needful that the Church be enlighten'd on that ≈øide; but it is ≈øufficient that the Objects that pa≈øs by be enlighten'd. Now if the Church had the light of the Sun on that ≈øide, the brightne≈øs of the light would di≈øcover too plainly the Shadows, and would take away all cau≈øes of admiration.

If any will ≈øay that ≈øome ingenious Per≈øon among≈øt them hath built this Chappel, according to the Rules of the Optick Art, to deceive the People with the≈øe Apparitions; I de≈øire him to take notice that the Copties are ≈øo ignorant that they know not what this Art is. This Chappel, as the other Churches, hath been built in this manner without any de≈øign to cozen the World; therefore this Reflection, which they name Apparition
of the Saints, hath been di≈øcover'd by chance. Experience hath taught me this in other Churches which have not been builded no more than this to deceive the World with vain Apparitions. I have taken notice of it in the Church Bo≈ø≈øat ino≈ø≈ø√°ra, where I was on the 13th of the ≈øame Month, in the company of ≈øome Copties that were going to Gemiane‚ñ™ There I ≈øaw the ≈øame Shadows, which two days after at Gemiane, they called S. George, the Virgin Mary, and S. Menna; ≈øo that when the Copties perceived them they knew not what to ≈øay. By this we may judge, that this Church hath not been built by the Optick Rules of Art, and that only by chance the≈øe Shadows have appeared, and been taken notice of.

This Apparition continues three days following; in which time there is ≈øuch a great concour≈øe of People, that one is ready to be ≈øtifled. I perceived that they did call every Saint according to their devotion and re≈øpect, without order: And when they ≈øaw ≈øome Shadows upon the Wall which had a relation with tho≈øe Saints that are painted in their Churches, they cry out for joy, in their Language, Selam lak Kaddis Filan; I ≈øalute you √¥ Saint N. N. To this they add an Hymn proper to the Saint, and Prayers, tying upon the Wall ≈øome little cro≈ø≈øes of Wax. Of all the Saints that their Church wor≈øhips, I have heard none called upon but the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, S. George, S. Menna, and S. Porter.

On this Fe≈øtival day all the Arabians thereabouts meet here, out of an ancient Cu≈øtome, to be treated for three days with the Revenues of this Church: When I was there, they could make up near five hundred Hor≈øe, and five hundred
Foot. The Hor≈øe-men were Armed with a Lance, the Foot-men with a Club upon their Shoulders, pointed with Iron.

This Cu≈øtome of feeding the Arabians thereabouts is very ancient; it comes from their pretending to be the Lords of the Country round about where this Church is built, and therefore for this con≈øideration they hinder not the Chri≈øtians, as they are able, from coming to this Fe≈øtival.

Therefore the Epitrope, or Trea≈øurer of the Church, hath care to provide all things needful for their entertainment. He kill'd that year ≈øeven young Cows, two every day: He provided for them Rice, Bread, and Barly for their Cattel: He had a care al≈øo to ≈øend for Cooks, and all Implements nece≈ø≈øary for a Kitchin; ≈øo that the Arabians had nothing el≈øe to do here, but to eat and drink and divert them≈øelves.

Twice every every day, the≈øe Arabians performed their War-like Exerci≈øes, to ≈øhew their jolly humor, and to give ≈øport to the A≈ø≈øembly. The Hor≈øe-men played at Girit, or the Dart, by ca≈øting it to one another, riding one again≈øt another and fencing therewith with much dexterity: The Footmen likewi≈øe skirmi≈øh'd one again≈øt another very plea≈øantly with their great Staves.

The third day of this Fe≈øtival the Arabians have nothing given them but a Dinner, as ≈øoon as they have eaten it they are to depart; ≈øo that if two hours after any of them was found there, and that the Beys Lieutenant hath any knowledge of him; he will cau≈øe him to be puni≈øh'd, either by the Pur≈øe, or a Ba≈øtinado: ≈øo that none have liberty to ≈øtay there that day, but Chri≈øtians whom the Epitrope treats in the ≈øame manner as he doth the Arabians.

I was one of the chief Per≈øons invited, the Trea≈øurer entertained me under his own tent with an extraordinary Banquet, only Wine was wanting; and Spoons, Forks, Knives and Napkins were not u≈øed: The Meat was to be torn in pieces between the Fingers, according to the Cu≈øtome of the Country. Afterwards, out of the Tent, a long Skin of Leather was ≈øpread upon the ground for the ordinary People, where they were very well treated. I ≈øhall fini≈øh this Relation with an advice to all Francs that intend to ≈øee this Fe≈øtival. They ought to take the ≈øame Way as we have done, becau≈øe it is the ea≈øie≈øt, the mo≈øt commodious, and the le≈øs dangerous. Let them get a good Tent; for there are no Lodgings, but in the open Air: Let them carry Wine, Strong-waters, Meat, Hens, Bread, and other things for nouri≈øhment during the Fe≈øtival: Let them al≈øo carry with them the Furniture of the Table, a Carpet, a Cu≈øhion to ≈øit upon, and ≈øome Coverlets for their conveniency, and to appear hand≈øomly. Water and Wood, are here plenty: There is Fi≈øh al≈øo to be ≈øold; for the Fi≈øher-men of Nilus, that is near adjoining, bring hither a great deal. I was provided with all the≈øe things, therefore I appeared very decently.

There is here no danger of being robb'd; for the Lieutenant of the Bey of Mohelle is al≈øo at this Fe≈øtival with a good Guard of Spahins, to prevent Di≈øorders, Quarrels, and Robberies which might happen among rude and barbarous People: So that in this place one may be with as much ≈øafety as at Cairo in a Hou≈øe. Upon this account there happen'd a plea≈øant Accident; a poor Arabian had taken from a Chri≈øtian a handful of Barly to give
it to his A≈øs, he was taken upon the Fact: The Chri≈øtians immediately dragg'd him with a great noi≈øe, to the Beys Lieutenant to have him puni≈øh'd: Whiles they were leading him a great Tumult of People ran to ≈øee him; ≈øome upbraided him with his boldne≈øs and impudency to ≈øteal, without apprehending the puni≈øhment of the Saints that appear'd in their Church, and did ≈øo many great Miracles; another ask'd him whether he did not fear that God would puni≈øh him? At which words he an≈øwer'd, Ane Baaref rabbene; that is, What, do I know that there is a God? or, I know not what is God. This cau≈øed me to wonder, both at the Copties ≈øettled per≈øwa≈øion of the real Apparition of their Saints, and at the ignorance of the Arabians, ≈øeeing that ≈øome of them know not that there is a God. At la≈øt this Wretch was ≈øhut up in a Cage, and I know not what happen'd to him afterwards.

It is time to prepare to depart when the Company withdraws it ≈øelf; and if one de≈øires to return to Cairo by another way, one may go by Land to Brullos, from thence to Ro≈øetta; by this means one may go through the lower part of Delta: a curious Journy which I never heard that any Franc hath made. But in ca≈øe any danger is likely to be in this way, one may go from Gemiane to Great Mohelle, where the ways are full of People; and from thence one may go by Land to Cairo, and ≈øee all the Antiquities that be in Mohelle and all along the wav.

I went away on Wedne≈øday morning when every one was departing, and returned to Cairo the ≈øame way that I came, becau≈øe the other ways ≈øeem'd to be dangerous. I arrived at Cairo the
20th of the ≈øame Month, eleven days after my departure.
The Repre≈øentation of this Church is in the Cabinet of Mon≈øieur C.

On the 27th of May I went to vi≈øit the Patriarch of the Copties, called Muallim Mattaos, or Ma≈øter Matthew, whom I had ≈øeen in my fir≈øt Voyage. I intreated him to give me a Letter to recommend me to the Mona≈øteries of Saint Macarius, whither I intended to go, which he granted me very willingly.
The 30th of this Month a Bey of Con≈øtantinople arrived at Cairo, bound for the I≈øland of Suaquen, ≈øcituated in the Red-Sea, where he was to Govern as Pacha.

At the ≈øame time came Don Pietro, an Aby≈ø≈øin, whom I had known at Rome, and who had given me the Manu≈øcripts of the Synods, and the Old Te≈øtament written in the Ethiopian Language. He, and another of the ≈øame Nation named Peter of Con≈øtantinople, went with this Pacha, with an intention to get into their own Country. I heard ≈øome time after that this Pietro was become a Mahometan at Sues, to e≈øcape the Fire unto which he was condemn'd for ≈øtriking a Moor.

div.head: A Voyage to Ro≈øetta.
div.p:
ON Monday the la≈øt of May, I went out of Cairo de≈øigned for Ro≈øetta, with the ≈øame Leonard who had been with me at Gemiane, and a Nubian Slave that I had. I went thither on purpo≈øe to ≈øpend there the time of the violent heats, which are not ≈øo fierce in that City as at Cairo;
as al≈øo to ≈øee the Mouth of the River Nilus at that City, and to ≈øatisfie a doubt that I had about the Water, of Maad√≠e; for I knew not whether it was a Gulph, or a Mouth of the River Nilus: with an intention from thence to go to Alexandria to ≈øee its Curio≈øities.
We were four days going from Cairo to Ro≈øetta; an extraordinary long time, becau≈øe the winds Maltam, or Mae≈øtraux, that blow again≈øt tho≈øe that go down the River, oppo≈øed our Voyage.
The mo≈øt remarkable Towns in this way are, Fuva, Sindiun, Teirut, Motubis, and Tf√©ni, by the River ≈øide.

Fuva, called by the Greeks Metelis, and in the Copties Dictionary Me≈ø≈øil, is a very ancient, great, and con≈øiderable Town, ≈øcituated upon the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, ≈øeven hours travelling from Re≈øetta. Its Territory is very delightful, becau≈øe of the plea≈øant Fields and Gardens round about. It bears Fruits that are much e≈øteem'd in all Egypt.
Geziret Iddahab, or the I≈øland of Gold, is over again≈øt this City.

Heretofore the River was ≈øo deep from the Mouth as far as this Town, that great Barques loaden were able to ≈øail hither; at that time the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe was kept here. But in time the River becoming here ≈øo ≈øhallow that the Barques being not able to come ≈øo far, the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe hath been ≈øince e≈øtabli≈øh'd at Ro≈øetta, where it continues yet.

Sindiun and Teirut are two other Towns ≈øcituated upon the Banks of Nilus over again≈øt one another; as are al≈øo Mot√∫bis and Tf√©ni: the fir≈øt ≈øtands on the Ea≈øt-≈øide, the other on the We≈øt-≈øide.
At Ro≈øetta I lodged with Mon≈øieur Reynaud, Vice-Con≈øul of the French in this City; he is a very hone≈øt Man: He imployed all his credit to procure me the ≈øight of the Curio≈øities round about.

For the information of all European Travellers, I have taken notice that of late there is a Carrier ≈øet up at Ro≈øetta, who goes by Land to Damietta, when any de≈øires to travel that way, which conveniency was not formerly; for when any intended that Journey, he was to run many hazards and inconveniences. I had fir≈øt de≈øign'd to go thither, but in≈øtead of that Journey I went to vi≈øit the Mona≈øteries of the De≈øart of S. Macarius, where I expected more ≈øatisfaction.

I have long doubted whether the Waters of Maad√≠e, or the Pool, that is half-way between Ro≈øetta and Alexandria was a Branch of Nilus, or el≈øe a Gulph of the Sea. In another Relation of Egypt which I Printed in Italian at Paris in the Year 1671. I have ≈øaid that it was a Branch of Nilus; but ≈øince I have under≈øtood the truth that it was nothing but a Gulph, or Pool: for, 1. Its Waters are very ≈øalt as far as Etku, its uttermo≈øt bounds; which Town, as I conceive, is the ≈øame with Motubis. 2. This Water comes not from Nilus, neither hath any Corre≈øpondency with this River. True it is, when Nilus overflows it becomes ≈øweeter, becau≈øe of the mixture of the River's-water with the Water of this Gulph. It retains this ≈øweetne≈øs about two Months, until Nilus leaves the Fields; and as ≈øoon as the Tramontane, or We≈øterly Wind blows, the Waters of this Pool return to their wonted ≈øaltne≈øs and acrimony.
The 10th of June I went to the Mouth of the River Nilus, about an hours ≈øailing from Ro≈øetta, to take the De≈øcription of it.

I took notice that Nilus hath there two Branches, or Mouths, though they be reckoned but one. That which runs into the Sea towards the Ea≈øt, and is called the Ea≈øterly Mouth; and that which runs into the Sea towards the We≈øt, and is named the We≈øterly Mouth. They take the fir≈øt to ≈øail to Brullos, to Damietta, to Seyda, and Con≈øtantinople, &c and by this la≈øt they go to Alexandria, and other We≈øtern Parts. This ≈øeparation proceeds from a low I≈øland, very ≈ømall, which ≈øtands in the middle of the River next to the Sea.

The Mouth of Nilus next to this City, is Guarded with two Ca≈øtles; one ≈øtands at the Ea≈øt-≈øide of the River, and the other at the We≈øt. That which is about a Mile and a half from Ro≈øetta is ≈øquare, encompa≈ø≈øed about with ≈øtrong Walls, built according to the old Model, having four Towers. In the middle is a high Dungeon to retreat at la≈øt. One hundred four≈øcore and four Jani≈ø≈øaries are there in Gari≈øon. They lye every Night in the Gari≈øon, but in the Day-time they have liberty to go into the City to work for their living. It is furni≈øh'd with three≈øcore and fourteen Pieces of Cannon, ≈øeven are of an extraordinary bigne≈øs. The Aga that Commanded here in chief, was a Spani≈øh Renegado.

The other Ca≈øtle is but a Mo≈øque, before it ≈øtands ≈øeven Pieces of Artillery on the Ground: Here Commands al≈øo an Aga over a Company of Moors, who examine all that go in, or out of the City. When I attempted to go out, they came
to my Boat and obliged me to return into the City again, though the Jani≈ø≈øary that was with me, and well acquainted with them, offered to an≈øwer for me. They treated me in this manner, for fear of a Pirat of Malta that ≈øailed before the Haven at that time; they were afraid that I had ≈øome intelligence with him, to give him notice of ≈øome Ships that were ready to ≈øet ≈øail loaden from Ro≈øetta: Neverthele≈øs I had another opportunity to take the De≈øcription of this Mouth al≈øo. It is now in the Clo≈øet of that Per≈øon of Quality who hath the others.

div.head: A Journy by Land from Ro≈øetta to Alexandria.
div.p: THE 14th of June I went, in the Evening, from Ro≈øetta towards Alexandria, with a Moor recommended to me by the French Vice-Con≈øul of this City: We had two Mules to carry us, for which I paid ≈øeventeen Meidins for the whole Journy.

About Midnight we came to the Water, named by the Moors Maad√≠e. After a little ≈øtay in the Han, or publick Inn, we proceeded on in our Journey in a Moon-≈øhining Night towards Alexandria; where we arriv'd the next day about eight or nine a Clock. From Ro≈øetta to Alexandria there is ten hours travelling for a Hor≈øeman; the mo≈øt part of the way is along the Sea-Coa≈øt, ≈øo that the Bea≈øts have a long way their Feet in Water.

The Country is ≈øo even, that there is no trouble for Travellers; and unle≈øs it be the Han,
in the Mid-way, there is neither Village, nor Tree, nor Gra≈øs to be ≈øeen: It is nothing but a plain Champain of Sand, altogether unfruitful.

Every Franc is bound to pay, at the entrance into Alexandria, at the Gate of Ro≈øetta, three Para's; half to the Beduins, or Boemiens, and half to the Jani≈ø≈øaries, becau≈øe they are there upon the Guard.

At my fir≈øt arrival at Alexandria, on the 15th of the ≈øame Month, I went to ≈øalute Mon≈øieur Laurens, Vice-Con≈øul in this City for the French; who expre≈øt a great deal of civility to me, and offered me his Table and a Chamber in his Hou≈øe; but in regard I was recommended by Mon≈øieur Brou≈ø≈øon, the Factor of the Levant Company, to Mon≈øieur Sabatery, his intimate Friend, and Factor there, and in regard he had a convenient Lodging which he offer'd me, to content them both I lodg'd with Mon≈øieur Sabatery, and made u≈øe of the Vice-Con≈øul's Table all the time I ≈øtaid at Alexandria.

I went next to vi≈øit an intimate Friend, with whom I had an acquaintance in my fir≈øt Voyage to Egypt; he was called Komos Jean, Arch-Prie≈øt of the Church of S. Mark of the Copties: He is an under≈øtanding, and an hone≈øt Man, and hath informed me much concerning the affairs of Egypt.
