I under≈øtood from the French Merchants of this City, that their Fondego hath been built by the Grand Seignior's order for their Lodging; and ≈øince their e≈øtabli≈øhment in this City the Turki≈øh Emperours were wont to pay to the French Con≈øuls ever Year two hundred Crowns for the Reparations of this Hou≈øe, but of late they don't
≈øee this Money: The cau≈øe is not well known.

On the 16th of this Month I went to a Jews Hou≈øe, with an intention to buy of him a curious Hieroglyphick Stone that ≈øtands at the Thre≈øhold of his Door. It is about an Ell and a-half long, and about a Foot broad, of a Marble colour; upon which are graven three lines of Hieroglyphick Letters in very ≈ømall Characters, which are to be read from the left hand to the right.
This Stone was de≈øired by Mon≈øieur Thevenot, who endeavoured to buy it; he offered, as I was told, thirty Pia≈øters to this Jew for it; but the other ask'd an hundred.

All the People of the Levant have this fooli≈øh Cu≈øtome to rai≈øe the Price of their Commodities; when they ≈øee that a Franc de≈øires any thing, though it were but a trifle, the others de≈øire makes them think it to be unvaluable; they prize it therefore at ≈øuch a rate that none dare meddle with it: They are ≈øo ≈øimple to ≈øuffer the Commodity to lie upon their Hands and ≈øpoil, rather than to ≈øell it to a Franc at the ≈øame rate that they would give it to a Man of the Levant.

Neverthele≈øs I expected that the Jew had chang'd his mind ≈øince that time; I offer'd him the ≈øame Price that this Franc had offer'd before: but when I ≈øaw that my offer render'd him more proud, re≈øolved in his fir≈øt demand, I never troubled him afterwards.

The Lodgings of the ≈øeventy Interpreters, who Tran≈ølated the Hebrew Bible into Greek, are yet ≈øtanding in this City, almo≈øt entire, with the Clo≈øets where they performed their Work. The Turks have made a Mo≈øque there, which they name
Giama il garb√≠e, or the Mo≈øque of the Levant. It is to be ≈øeen with Money: Mon≈øieur Brue, chief Interpreter of the French Con≈øul of Cairo, hath gone in.

The 19th of June, being Saturday, I went to ≈øee the Salt-pits of the Grand Seignior, which are out of the City near the Calitz or Channel of Cleopatra, from whence they have their Fre≈øh-water when the River runs over the Banks, and near the Garden of a Moor often vi≈øited by the French Merchants, which is call'd Gheit il chavagie, or the Merchants Garden.

In the≈øe Salt-pits I have taken notice of two things very remarkable: Fir≈øt, that the Water of Nilus, the ≈øweete≈øt Water and the fre≈øhe≈øt in the World, makes a Salt, not only whiter than ordinary, but very excellent. Secondly, that this Salt hath the ta≈øte of Violets.

They that have the care of tho≈øe Salt-pits cau≈øe a certain quantity of the River-water to run into the Salt-pits; and ≈øour or five days after the Water is turn'd into a Salt the mo≈øt beautiful to the Eye, afterwards they carry it in Baskets to dry in the Sun; then it is fit to be ≈øold.

Salt is al≈øo to be made of the Lake Sebaka, named by the ancient Latins, Palus Mareotis, which is at the South-≈øide of this City; but its Water is naturally ≈øalt, and its Salt is bitter when it is made, therefore they neglect it.

This Lake proceeds from the River Nilus when it overflows; the Waters there continue, becau≈øe they have no pa≈ø≈øage out. It is not very deep, but ≈øo large that from one ≈øide one cannot well ≈øee the other.

The Copties of Alexandria, have in their Church
of S. Mark, a Picture of the Arch-Angel S. Michael, drawn by S. Luke, as report goes.

Mon≈øieur Luca≈øole, Chancellor of the French Nation in this City, told me that the Venetians had carried away this Picture ≈øome time-≈øince, and ≈øail'd with it five times out of the Haven, but could not proceed on in their Voyage, becau≈øe they were ≈øtopt by an invi≈øible Hand every time that they intended to ≈øail away, and could never depart till they had carried back the Picture.

The report of this Wonder being ≈øpread abroad in the City; the Beduins, or Boemiens as we call them, took a re≈øolution ≈øecretly to ≈øteal it away and ≈øell it to the Francs: Accordingly, when they had broken open the Doors of the Church and pulled it down from the place where it ≈øtood, they could not po≈ø≈øibly get out with it; ≈øo that they were al≈øo forc'd to put it up again in its place as the Venetians had done before, where it remains ≈øtill, I have ≈øeen it.
Mon≈øieur Luca≈øole told me that this is very true, and that he him≈øelf was then at Alexandria.

I have read ≈øomething concerning the Waters of the Ci≈øterns of Alexandria, in the Book of Mon≈øieur de la Ch. that treats of the overflowing of the River Nilus: That they become ≈øalt about the Months of April and May; and that in the Night that the fruitful Dew falls they return to their former ≈øweetne≈øs, and increa≈øe be≈øides with the Waters of the River.

I ≈øhall not offer to deny flatly a thing that may be true, and which Mon≈øieur Burattini, cited by Mon≈øieur de la Ch. ≈øaith hath been ob≈øerv'd by ≈øeveral Per≈øons: But I dare ≈øay that in two ≈øeveral Voyages into Egypt, and during my long abode
at Alexandria in ≈øeveral ≈øea≈øons of the Year; though I have ob≈øerv'd, as exactly as I could, all things, I never heard that the Waters of the≈øe Ci≈øterns did become ≈øalt, or that they did increa≈øe with the Waters of the River, or that they did recover their former fre≈øhne≈øs and ≈øweetne≈øs: I have neverthele≈øs wondred a little to ta≈øte them ≈øomewhat ≈øalt, ≈øo that they ≈øeem not to come from ≈øo fre≈øh a River.

This quality proceeds from the nitrous Earth, which may be known by this Experiment; if a piece of Earth about Alexandria be put in the hot Sun, it will become white as Snow on that ≈øide that is towards the Sun.

div.head: Of the Pillar of Pompey, and of the Caves that are near Alexandria, not far from it.
div.p: THE 21≈øt of June I went to ≈øee the Pillar of Pompey, and other Rarities thereabouts, in the company of Mon≈øieur Truillard, the Elder, a French Merchant, and of the Jani≈ø≈øary that belongs to the Vice-Con≈øul. We went out at the Gate called Babi≈ø≈øidr, where this Pillar ≈øtands upon a little Hill towards the South.

When I drew near, I took notice that it lean'd on one ≈øide; whereas eight years before it ≈øtood very ≈øtreight, when I ≈øaw it. The cau≈øe of this are the Arabians, who out of a per≈øwa≈øion of ≈øome great Trea≈øure hid under, have digg'd and undermin'd it, and have drawn out of its Foundation many great heaps of Stones that held it up; this cau≈øeth it to lean a little on that ≈øide. They had overthrown it, had they not found at the bottom
Stones of a fearful bigne≈øs, and ≈øo great that neither they nor any body el≈øe was able to draw them out.

The De≈øcription and Dimen≈øions of this Pillar are found in the Book of Mon≈øieur Thevenot: Therefore I ≈øay no more of it here, becau≈øe I will not ≈øtuff this Book with ordinary things, mentioned before in other Travels.

After we had well viewed this Pillar, we march'd along the Calitz, as far as the place that is over again≈øt the City Walls, to ob≈øerve the Pa≈ø≈øage of the Waters. We went with this de≈øign on the other ≈øide of the Calitz, over the little Bridge that is near it: When we came to the little Arches that are under the Walls, through which the River enters into the City, we made our ob≈øervations, and took next the way that leads to the Caves that are in the Fields at We≈øt-South-We≈øt of the Gate out of which we came; and about a quarter of a League, in our way towards the Lake Sebaca, we came to the Caves; having left at We≈øt-North-We≈øt a Mo≈øque, in a plain Field, where was buried a certain Schech of the Moors, called Sidi gams il g√°bbari.

At our entrance we went down a dozen ≈øteps into a very large Alley, digg'd in the Rock, but open a-top; it may be the Vault is fallen by length of time. In this Alley are fifteen great holes cut in the Rock, in the fa≈øhion of great Gates; ≈øeven are on the right hand, and eight on the left; through which Men enter into the Caves.

We went into four with our Torches lighted, our Jani≈ø≈øary before us; we found round about the Walls, in the firm Rock, from the top to the
bottom, holes cut in the Rock very orderly; and of a length and breadth fit to hold a Coffin: Many of the≈øe Caves were cut, to open a way to others. This inconveniency we found there, they were almo≈øt all fill'd up with Earth and Sand, which cau≈øed us to kneel for the mo≈øt part: this did not hinder us from taking notice of that which was mo≈øt remarkable. Whiles we were in one, at the end of the Alley, one of our Company perceived, with the light of his Tapers, that one of the holes open'd a pa≈ø≈øage to another Cave; which cau≈øed us to ≈øee whether there was not there any thing worthy of our notice: Though the hole was but ≈ømall and narrow, we crept in upon our Bellies with our lighted Tapers; and one after another we came to the other ≈øide, where we ≈øound one of the ≈øtrange≈øt and mo≈øt curious Caves that we had ever ≈øeen: It was greater, more compleat, and cleaner than any of the others; built long and ≈øquare, and well Plai≈øter'd with Lime; at each ≈øide of the Wall, which is the main Rock, there are three ranks of holes, like to tho≈øe that we had ≈øeen in the former: In the longer ≈øides were fifteen in every rank, plac'd one a top of the other; in all they were forty-five. The two ends, or ≈øides, that were ≈øhorte≈øt, had likewi≈øe three ranks, and three holes at every rank, nine in all. They were all empty and clean, and no ill ≈øcent in all the Cave; unle≈øs it be in one hole, where we ≈øaw the Skeleton of the Body of a Man dried up.

I conceive that the Learned may de≈øire my judgment concerning the≈øe Caves and Holes, and to what purpo≈øe they were made. To this I an≈øwer, that it is not ea≈øie to give a ju≈øt account of
them; becau≈øe Macrizi, who hath ≈øpoken of all the remarkable things of Egypt, makes no mention of the≈øe Caves: Neverthele≈øs it is ea≈øie to be ≈øeen, that they could be for no other u≈øe, but to bury and place the dead. This may be gathered from the fa≈øhion of the holes, which are ju≈øt as long as high, and as large as needs mu≈øt to place a Bier or Coffin; be≈øides, all the other Caves in Egypt were only for that purpo≈øe: it is therefore very probable that this was for no other purpo≈øe, let the Reader think what he plea≈øeth of them.

I do not deny but that they may have ≈øerv'd the Chri≈øtians to meet together, and pray God in ≈øecret, for fear of the Heathens that per≈øecuted them. I find this Opinion in Seid ibn Patrik, a Patriarch of Alexandria, in his Hi≈øtory, p. 399.
The Inhabitants of Alexandria name the≈øe Caves the S√∫k, or the Market-place; but there is no likelihood that they have been employed for that u≈øe.

The Rock in which they are cut, is much eaten and con≈øum'd by time; the holes are likewi≈øe much decayed, chiefly tho≈øe that are neare≈øt to the Door, and in the open air: They receive ≈øome light from above, through little ≈øquare holes that are made on purpo≈øe in the Vaults.

The 22th I went round the City, to take notice of the Walls and Towers. I went into ≈øix of the chief: The fir≈øt is that which is neare≈øt to the French Fondego, or French Hou≈øe, before you come to Bab il achdar, or the green Gate. It is round, and ≈øupported within with three ranks of Pillars of red Stone, ≈øeven in every one.

Next to this Tower, we went to the Gate of the old Haven, which at pre≈øent is walled in, becau≈øe
this Haven is not frequented: both are at the We≈øt-≈øide of the City. From this Gate we went to the Mo≈øque of the ≈øeventy, called Giama il garbis. We went next by the old Ca≈øtle of Alexandria, named Borg Mu≈øtapha Pacha, which ≈øerv'd heretofore to guard the old Haven; at pre≈øent there are three hundred Jani≈ø≈øaries in Gari≈øon.

Till then we walk'd always towards the We≈øt; but when we had left this Ca≈øtle, we turn'd towards the Ea≈øt, and found next a great Tower; where we got upon the Platform, not by any ≈øteps, but by a large way made ≈øloping up.

Next to this Tower, we came to Bab i≈ø≈øidr, out of which ≈øtands the Pillar of Pompey: From thence we went to another, called Bab irra≈øc√Æd, or the Gate of Ro≈øetta, along the Walls of the City. I went out of the City, alone with the Jani≈ø≈øary, to ≈øee where the River Nilus goes into the Channel which an≈øwers to the Ci≈øterns of Alexandria, which I ≈øhall de≈øcribe hereafter.

When I had fully viewed that which I de≈øired, I returned into the Town to my company, that waited for me in the ≈øhade; and all together we walk'd to the Tower of the Indians, ≈øo called, becau≈øe of late there lodges ≈øome Indian Pilgrims. We went into it, and found its make very admirable.

We went next to the Tower of the old Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, or Douane; ≈øo nam'd, becau≈øe when the Sea came to the Walls: of the City on that ≈øide, the Store-hou≈øes of the Cu≈øtoms were there: But ≈øince the Sea is gone from thence, the Gate is ≈øhut, and the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe is establi≈øh'd and ≈øettled in another place.

This Tower is very big, ≈øupported within with four ranks of Pillars of red Stone. Here are many Rooms fit for ≈øtores, for lodgings, and to put Salt in, though much of it is now ruinated. This was the la≈øt Tower that we ≈øaw in our Walk, which continued four hours, reckoning the time that we ≈øpent in viewing the Walls, and climbing up to the Towers.
I return at pre≈øent to the Channel, by which the Ci≈øterns are furni≈øh'd with Water.

It is out of the Gate of Ro≈øetta, about ≈øix Foot high, vaulted in the in≈øide, about a quarter of a Mile from the City: It joins to the Calitz of Cleopatra, that furni≈øhes it with Water from the River Nilus; from thence the Water runs to the Walls, where it meets with another Conduit not fat from this Gate; which Conduit, or Channel, is made ≈øo ingeniou≈øly, that it furni≈øhes all the Ci≈øterns of the City with Water.

We mu≈øt al≈øo take notice, that though the Mouth of this Channel is as high as the re≈øt, almo≈øt the two thirds are wall'd from the top to the bottom; ≈øo that there remains but a ≈ømall hole where the Waters of the Calitz flow in, as through a Window. And becau≈øe they are very ≈øalt the fir≈øt three days, and they would fill the Ci≈øterns with ≈ølime and filth, if the Water did enter in at that time freely: To prevent this inconveniency, they that have the care of the Water ≈øtop this hole, and leave it ≈øo three days; which being ended, they go to the entry of the Channel, followed by a crowd of People, to un≈øtop the hole, and let in the Water to fill the Ci≈øterns. This day is a day of great rejoicing all over the City.

The City of Alexandria hath ≈øix Gates; three are open, namely that towards the South, called Bab i≈ø≈øidr; that which is at the Ea≈øt, named Bab irra≈øc√Æd, or the Gate of Ro≈øetta; that which looks to the North-Ea≈øt, and is named the Sea-Gate. The three Gates that are ≈øhut are, that of the old Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe; the green Gate, called by the Arabs, Bab il achdar; and that of the old Haven.

I cannot po≈øitively affirm whether the Walls and the Gates that are now there, be tho≈øe that Alexander the Great caus'd to be builded, or whether the Califfs have made them. I imagin that the Califfs have erected them, and not Alexander; (though many Travellers are of a contrary opinion.) Becau≈øe there is no Greek In≈øcriptions to be ≈øeen, but all Arab.. Some are written in ≈øtrange Characters, others in the ordinary Arabian Character. The≈øe In≈øcriptions ≈øpeak of the Califf, and Year when they were builded, or re-edified. The Gates being high where the≈øe In≈øcriptions were graven, and the Letters artificially put with other works, I could not di≈øtingui≈øh nor read them. 2. The manner of their building proves this truth; for they are builded as the Gates of Cairo, which were the work of the Califfs, who have been there many Ages after Alexander the Great.

There are two Havens in Alexandria; the one called the old Haven, where Ships enter in with the We≈øterly Wind; but now it is of no u≈øe, but to ≈øecure the Ve≈ø≈øels that ≈øail from the Ea≈øt towards the We≈øt, when the bad Weather obliges them to ≈øeek for ≈øhelter. The other is called the new Haven; there all the Ships arrive,
and where they now ca≈øt Anchor.

The Trade of the French Merchants in this City, is the greate≈øt that they have in all the Ea≈øtern Parts; for there is no place in Turkie where ≈øo many French Ships come as into this Haven; from the beginning of the Year 1672, to the Month of June, there was no le≈øs than nineteen French Ships that came hither; and in the Month of June I reckoned fourteen.

This is a con≈øiderable number, but not to be compar'd with the number of Ve≈ø≈øels that frequented this Haven heretofore: For Mon≈øieur Luca≈øole, that did the Office of Chancellor of the French Nation, told me that he remembers that there have been at Alexandria in one Year, ninety-four French Ships.

Seeing that I am ≈øpeaking of the French Trade in Egypt, I ≈øhall for the ≈øatisfaction of the Merchants, give here an exact account of all the Commodities that are carried from Egypt into Europe, whether it be by the way of Mar≈øeilles, or by that of Legorn, or by Venice, with their ordinary Price in the Year 1673.
The Commodities that are ordinarily carried out of Egypt into Europe, are,

div.p: And becau≈øe we have mentioned in this place ≈øeveral Weights and Monies that are in u≈øe in Egypt, it is needful to give an explication of them, that the Reader may make u≈øe of this Journal with ≈øatisfaction to him≈øelf.
The Ock contains 400 Drams.
The Rotol contains 144 Drams.
One hundred and ten Rotols of Cairo, are 108 pounds weight of Mar≈øeilles.
The Quintal gerouin, contains 217 Rotols of Cairo.
The Abukelb is the Doller of Holland, with the Lion rampant, and is worth 33 Meidins to be chang'd; but in Species 38 Meidins, and ≈øometimes more.
The ordinary Pia≈øter, which is but an imaginary Coin, is worth 30 Meidins; and with it they trade and pay Money in Egypt.
The Reals of Spain are worth 33 Meidins in change, but in Species 40, and ≈øometimes more as they are in reque≈øt.

The Sequin, or golden Ducat of Venice, which next to the Reals of Spain, is the be≈øt Money to be us'd in all the Countries of the Grand Seignior, is worth in trade 100 Meidins; but the Divan of Cairo takes it but for four≈øcore and five.

The Meidin, or the Para, is the ≈øame piece of Money, made by the Pacha's of Cairo in the Name of the Grand Seignior. It is currant in all Parts of Egypt; is worth one Penny Half-penny of France, and about one Penny Farthing Engli≈øh.
A Pur≈øe contains 2500 Meidins, and is worth 500 Crowns of France.
The 23d of this Month, I ≈øaw a Moor return from a Race that he had made, to ≈øhew his ≈øtrength, and to be admitted among≈øt the Po≈øts that carry Letters from Alexandria to Cairo.

He that will be admitted to be Po≈øt, or Me≈ø≈øenger, or Carrier of Letters, mu≈øt carry upon his Shoulders a Fire lighted in an Iron Basket, made as a great Chafing-di≈øh, fa≈øten'd at the end of a great Staff about the length of a Man, to which are tied ≈øeveral Hoops of Iron, all weighing 36 Rotols. With this burden he mu≈øt go twenty-≈øeven Miles in the way to Ro≈øetta, and return the ≈øame day to the City before the ≈øetting of the Sun, in all about 54 Miles; he is to go always loaden with the ≈øame burden. If he performs this, he is not only admitted among≈øt the Carriers of Letters, but he wins the Wager that others have made again≈øt him; but if his ≈øtrength fails him, he lo≈øeth his Wager, and his Employment that he pretends to.

The Man that I ≈øaw returning the ≈øame day to the City, and fini≈øhing his cour≈øe with honour, becau≈øe he was return'd when the Sun was two
hours high, won a Wager of fifteen Pia≈øters, and was admitted among≈øt the Po≈øts, or Carriers of Letters; and gathered be≈øides, about eight Pia≈øters, or thereabouts, from the beholders of his glorious return; but he was in ≈øuch a ≈øweat that one would have judg'd him to be coming out of ≈øome Bath. He was followed by a great Company of People both Hor≈øe and Foot, ≈øome carrying Wood to entertain his Fire, others Water to refre≈øh and cool him; that before I knew the cau≈øe of this Meeting, I thought there had been ≈øome Tumult in the City.

When I had continued ≈øo long time in Alexandria as was needful for my affairs, and having lo≈øt my Quartane Fever that had plagued me ≈øixteen Months, I departed very well ≈øatisfied, for Ro≈øetta, on the Fe≈øtival day of S. Peter and S. Paul. I went this time by Sea, becau≈øe I had been ≈øo often by Land: I went aboard a Ship, and in five hours we came to Ro≈øetta, but not without danger of Ship-wrack at the Mouth of Nilus; for the Waters of the River meet ≈øo furiou≈øly with the Waves of the Sea, that they are able to affright the mo≈øt skilful Pilots of Egypt.

div.head: A Voyage to the Mona≈øteries of the De≈øarts of S. Macarius.
div.p:
ON the 30th of June I went from Ro≈øetta, with an intention to vi≈øit the four Mona≈øteries of the De≈øarts of S. Macarius: for that purpo≈øe I went aboard of a Boat of a Jani≈ø≈øary,
‚Ä¢ amed Reus Ahmed il Curdi, a Man very well acquainted with the Francs, to go with him to
Tarane, or Terenut, as the Copties call it in their Dictionary. It is a little Village in the Ca≈øcieflik of Beheire, four and twenty hours travelling from Cairo, ≈øcituate upon the Ea≈øt of Nilus, the place where Men commonly go a-≈øhore when they de≈øign to travel to tho≈øe Mona≈øteries. But, before I came to that Village, I received many affronts from ≈øome young Turks, becau≈øe I carried with me a little Box full of Wine. A zealous Cadi being troubled in Con≈øcience for being in the company of a Franc that drunk Wine, encourag'd them to ask me ≈øome, that he might have an occa≈øion to quarrel with me, if I did give them ≈øome. The≈øe Rogues having the Authority of a Cadi to countenance their wicked de≈øign, four of the bolde≈øt ask'd me ≈øome very earne≈øtly; for they ≈øaid they knew that I had ≈øome. I excus'd my ≈øelf at fir≈øt, that I could not give them any to drink, becau≈øe they were not to drink Wine; and that I knew very well that it was a great Crime for a Franc to give Wine to a Mu≈øulman, chiefly in a place where many others would be offended at it, and that ≈øuch an action might bring me into trouble. But all the≈øe rea≈øons could not prevail; they would have ≈øome Volens Nolens, threatning that if I denied them they would ca≈øt my Wine into the River. When I ≈øaw my ≈øelf in this danger, I intreated the Reus, unto whom I was well recommended by the Vice-Con≈øul of Ro≈øetta, to defend me. He did ≈øo much by his credit, that he pacified them for that time.

At my arrival at Tarane, whither I was to go a-≈øhore, I hired in the Morning a little Boat to carry me, and my Cloaths and Provi≈øions, to the Village; for our Ve≈ø≈øel was great and well loaden,
and could not at that time go near the ≈øhore, becau≈øe the Water was not deep. Three of the≈øe Turks ca≈øt them≈øelves furiou≈øly into my Boat, taking my Box in earne≈øt to ca≈øt it into the River. I ≈ønatch'd it from them, and run to my Mu≈øquet as if I intended to ≈øhoot at them: my Black-a-moor likewi≈øe, who was couragious, took one by the Neck and ca≈øt him into the River, and with his Sword in his Hand put him≈øelf in a po≈øture of defence; When they ≈øaw that they had to do with Men of courage that were not afraid of them, they went back into the Barque, and very furiou≈øly a≈ø≈øaulted the Reus with their Fi≈øts; be≈øides, they accus'd him, as he him≈øelf told me afterwards, at his return to Cairo, before his Aga, to have drank Wine with a Franc, making him pay, as a puni≈øhment, ten Pia≈øters.

After this Rencounter, I had another Accident that happen'd to me, far more grievous and dangerous. At my landing I wanted a Man to carry my Cloaths to the Hou≈øe where I intended to lodge; I called therefore ≈øome of the Arabians that were newly arriv'd from the De≈øarts of S. Macarius with Nitre, or Salt-Peter: He that carried my Box of Wine finding it to be very heavy, and knowing not what was in it, he thought it had been a Box of Money; therefore being proud of his burden, he told all that he met with in the way, that he carry'd a Box full of Money, that belong'd to a Franc newly arriv'd, that was going to the Mona≈øteries. This lye ≈øpread about the Village, and was believ'd as true, ≈øo that I was in no ≈ømall danger; for there was no other talk in the Town but of the rich Franc that was there, and of the means to get his Money: They thought I had
been ≈øome Con≈øul that travell'd incognito to ≈øee the Country, therefore they re≈øolv'd to wait for me in the way, and to take from me all my Trea≈øure.

In this manner I landed at Tarane, on a Sunday, and went to lodge at a poor Carpenters Hou≈øe, a Chri≈øtian Coptie, the only Chri≈øtian in that Village; he allowed me for my Chamber, a place where he put Straw for his Bea≈øts; it was covered with the Faggots of Palm-trees, heap'd one upon another, to hinder the heats of the Sun: I found there two religious Per≈øons of the Mona≈øteries whither I intended to go, with them I pa≈øt my fears and apprehen≈øions.

When I under≈øtood, from all hands, the Con≈øpiracy that the Arabians had form'd again≈øt me; the danger oblig'd me the the next day, to de≈øire the Ca≈øcief of that place to give me a Guard, to bring me ≈øafe to the Mona≈øteries; and that I might per≈øwade him the ≈øooner, I gave him ≈øome Pounds of Coffee and Loaves of Sugar, which I had brought with me for that purpo≈øe; for it is the Cu≈øtom in Turkie, when a favour is de≈øired from a Turk, to begin with Gifts: But the Ca≈øcief having heard what report went of me, an≈øwer'd me, that a ≈ømall Guard would do me but little good, becau≈øe the Arabians had formed a de≈øign to wait for me in the way, and to cut my Throat, and that it was needful that he ≈øhould Guard me him≈øelf; which he promis'd to do within a few days, after that he had fini≈øh'd ≈øome bu≈øine≈øs of importance.

I was mightily troubled when I heard what the Ca≈øcief offer'd me. It was to no purpo≈øe when I told him that I was no Con≈øul, as the report went of me without any colour of truth, but rather a
poor Franc that went to the Mona≈øteries to perfect my ≈øelf in the Language of the Country; That in this Box there was no Money, but only ≈øome Gla≈øs Bottles of Wine which I carried with me, becau≈øe I was never us'd to drink Water. All this di≈øcour≈øe was to no purpo≈øe, he was ≈øo prepo≈ø≈øe≈øs'd with the fal≈øe report that I could not be believ'd. When I ≈øaw that I ≈øpent my labour in vain, I went to my Lodging without accepting his offer.

At that time I had news that Na≈ø≈ør All√°, an Abbot of one of the Mona≈øteries, that I intended to vi≈øit, was at a Village at the other ≈øide of the River, call'd Tuh ine≈ø≈ø√°ra, not far from Tarane down the Current, about ≈øome concerns of his Mona≈øtery. I ≈øent him a Letter, written in Arabic, by one of the Lay Monks whom I found at my arrival at Tarane, acquainting him with my intention, and all that had happen'd between me and the Ca≈øcief, and Arabians, intreating him to tell me how I ≈øhould get free from tho≈øe People; I a≈ø≈øur'd him that I ≈øhould be for ever oblig'd to him, and that all the favour he ≈øhould ≈øhew me would be plea≈øing to his Partriarch, who was my very good Friend, and had recommended me to the Governours of tho≈øe Mona≈øteries. But this uncivil Abbot was ≈øo far from an≈øwering to my Letter, as I expected, that he kept with him the Me≈ø≈øenger, and would not ≈øuffer him to return back.

When I ≈øaw the Abbots incivility, and being more de≈øirous to proceed on in my Journy, notwith≈øtanding all the≈øe difficulties; I re≈øolved once more to vi≈øit the Ca≈øcief, to intreat him to give me a Guard, thinking to find him of another judgment than he was before when I ≈øaw him fir≈øt, but
I receiv'd from him the ≈øame an≈øwer; He told me that he would not have me venture, unle≈øs he Guarded me him≈øelf; that he mu≈øt an≈øwer to the Pacha for my Life, if any mi≈øchance did happen to me in my Journy, and that he knew that I was but ill accommodated with the Chri≈øtian; he de≈øired me therefore to take a Chamber at his Hou≈øe. I mu≈øt confe≈øs that this ≈øecond offer, as well as the fir≈øt, did ≈øtrangely trouble me: for this earne≈øt de≈øire that he did di≈øcover of Guarding me in his own Per≈øon, was no good Omen to me; be≈øides, his Reputation was but bad in the Village; and when I ≈øhould have had no rea≈øon to fear him, and that his intentions had been very good, the expences I mu≈øt have been at for him and his Company, and the Gifts that I mu≈øt have be≈øtowed upon him for his pains, would have ruined me; for I knew that a Ca≈øcief never ventures out in a Journy without a great train of Hor≈øe and Foot, and without expecting great matters.

When I ≈øaw the danger and trouble that I had in this Journy, I re≈øolved to return to Cairo as ≈øoon as I could. With this re≈øolution I ≈øpent the re≈øt of the day in my Lodging, thinking how I might be able to compa≈øs it. About two hours in the Night I heard knocking at the Door very earne≈øtly, and becau≈øe it was no ≈øea≈øonable time to ≈øpeak with me, and that the Per≈øon knockt very hard, I began to think that I was in danger: That I might not be ≈øurpriz'd, I awak'd the Per≈øons in the Hou≈øe, and took my Weapons in my hand, ≈øending my Black-a-moor to ≈øee who was there; he return'd to me, and told me that it was a Groom of the Ca≈øcief that was de≈øirous to ≈øpeak with me, concerning a bu≈øine≈øs of the highe≈øt importance.
I caus'd him to come in, and found that it was he that had introduc'd me to his Ma≈øters pre≈øence, unto whom I had made ≈øome ≈ømall Gifts: As ≈øoon as he ≈øaw me, he intreated me by his Religion and mine, as the Cu≈øtom of the Country is, to go away immediately, as ≈øecretly as I could; for his Ma≈øter intended to kill me, becau≈øe he thought I was a Man that travell'd up and down only to ≈øeek for the Trea≈øures of the ancient Egyptians: And that he might more conveniently perform this bloody de≈øign, he was re≈øolved to lead me him≈øelf towards the Mona≈øteries to the middle of the Wilderne≈øs, where he would ≈øuffer me to re≈øt, and afterwards cut my Throat: And if afterwards any ≈øhould inquire for a Franc that was gone by Tarane to the Mona≈øteries, he would ≈øay that he is gone to Cairo by another way: He told me al≈øo, that about a Month before that, his Ma≈øter had kill'd a Mahometan Traveller of Barbary, and had ca≈øt his Body into the River, for the ≈øame cau≈øe.

As ≈øoon as I under≈øtood this bad news, I had no more mind to ≈øleep, I gave him the reward that he had de≈øerv'd, and ≈øent to ≈øeek a Camel to carry my Cloaths; and about one of the Clock in the Night I departed to go to the pa≈ø≈øage that leads to Giz√©y, a Village ≈øcituated on the other ≈øide of Nilus, about an hour and a halfs travelling from Tarane down the Water: I agreed there with a Ma≈øter of a Boat to carry me and my Cloaths over; and about break of the Day I went aboard very ≈øpeedily: As ≈øoon as we were lanch'd into the River, from Land, I ≈øaw the Ca≈øcief galloping towards us with about thirty Men on Hor≈øe back to catch me; but he
mi≈øs'd of his intent, for I was out of his reach.

At Giz√©y, as I was waiting for an opportunity to return to Cairo, the Abbot Na≈ø≈ør alla, mentioned before, came thither and offer'd to conduct me to the Mona≈øteries, if I would return to Tarane in his company; but I had no mind any longer to vi≈øit them.

I went from Giz√©y the ≈øame day, being Fryday, towards Cairo; and the next Night we lodg'd at Verdan, a Village ≈øcituate on the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, not far from Boulak; and on Saturday the 9th of July, I enter'd into Cairo, from whence I departed the 7th of June.

Whil≈øt I was at Tarane, the Ca≈øcief's Clark, who was a Coptie and a Chri≈øtian, came to ≈øee me ≈øometimes. I under≈øtood from him what the Lakes of Salt-Peter, or Niter, yield to the Grand Seignior every Year. He told me, that this Year within the ≈øpace of nine Months, they had drawn four and twenty thou≈øand Quintals, and that they mu≈øt take up twelve thou≈øand more to make up the ordinary Sum that is drawn: So that every Quintal being ≈øold for 25 Meidins, this Revenue comes to 36 Pur≈øes, or 18000 Crowns, French Money, by the Year.
As ≈øoon as it is taken out of the Lakes they carry it upon Camels to Tarane, where it is weighed, and from thence ≈øent to Cairo, or Alexandria, to be ≈øold.

For this cau≈øe a Ca≈øcief dwells here, who though he be but little in Authority, and ≈øubject to the Ca≈øcief of Beheire, he is forc'd to buy this employment, and pay for it four and twenty Pur≈øes; one half to the Ca≈øcief of Beheire, and the other half to the Pacha: he keeps al≈øo twenty Spahins
to wait upon him, and guard his Country; he is the Lord of the≈øe Mona≈øteries.
But before I proceed on in my Journal, I will give a ≈øhort account of ≈øome remarkable things in this De≈øart, as I have heard them from one that hath been an Abbot in one of the Mona≈øteries.

Fir≈øt there is to be ≈øeen, between the Mona≈øteries of S. Macarius, and of Amba Bi≈øcioi, and a little further in the Wilderne≈øs, a long rank of little heaps of Earth, a Foot from one another, plac'd as in a way; which, as the Monks ≈øay, was put there by the Angels, that the Hermites might be able to find the way to the Church when they were de≈øirous to hear Divine Service on Sundays; for before they were apt to go out of the way: Therefore this way is called now, Tarik il mel√°ike, or, The way of Angels.

Secondly I have under≈øtood from an old Manu≈øcript in Arab. that in the Wilderne≈øs were heretofore ≈øeven great Mona≈øteries; namely, 1. of S. Macarius; 2. Of S. John the little, ≈øirnamed Igum√®ne; 3. Of Amba Bi≈øc√≠oi; 4. Of S. Ma≈ø≈øine, and Timothy; 5. That of Amba Mo≈øes, ≈øirnamed Black; 6. That of Amba K√©ma; 7. That of the holy Virgin of Syria: and that be≈øides the≈øe ≈øeven Mona≈øteries, there were three hundred dwellings of Hermites, and ≈øolitary People that ≈øerved God in this Wilderne≈øs.

But now, of all the≈øe Mona≈øteries, there are but two remarkable; namely, the Mona≈øtery of the Syrians, and that of Amba Bi≈øcioi. They are furni≈øh'd with very good Water. The fir≈øt hath two Churches; one for the Syrians, and another for the Copties.

In that of the Syrians is to be ≈øeen a miraculous
Tree, growing from the Staff of S. Ephrem. This holy Man left it at the Gate when he went to vi≈øit one in the Mona≈øtery, and immediately it ≈øhot forth Roots downwards, and Leaves upwards, with Flowers. They ≈øay, that there is no ≈øuch Tree to be found in all Egypt be≈øides.

Thirdly, in the Mona≈øtery of S. John the little, which now is much decayed, is to be ≈øeen a Tree that grew likewi≈øe from this Saints Staff miraculou≈øly, when he had fix'd it into the Ground at his Superiors command, and water'd it: Therefore they call it, becau≈øe of this Act of Obedience, Scieigiaret itt√°a, or the Tree of Obedience.

Fourthly, in the way that leads from the Mona≈øtery of the Syrians to the Mountain of the Eagles Stones, is to be ≈øeen the Bed of Bahr Bel√° me, or River without Water; which was dried up, as the Monks relate, at the Prayers of the ancient Hermites that dwelt about its Banks; becau≈øe they were grievou≈øly troubled by the Pyrats that ≈øailed upon it, therefore they obtain'd from God this favour.

Fifthly, in this De≈øart is to be ≈øeen another Curio≈øity, call'd by the Arabians, Lahm iggi√∫f; but becau≈øe I could not well under≈øtand what it was, I could de≈øire that ≈øome other Traveller would enquire it out, that we may better know what to think of it.

div.head: A Walk to the Garden of Ma-T√°rea.
div.p:
THE 12th of July I went, in the Company of ≈øome French Merchants, to the Village of Ma-T√°rea, ≈øcituate on the Ea≈øt of Cairo, about
two hours riding on Hor≈øe-back, to vi≈øit the places which Chri≈øt and his mo≈øt holy Mother have ≈øanctified with their abode, and the Garden where the Balm Plants were ≈øet formerly.

At the entry into the Court which is before this Garden there is to be ≈øeen, at the right hand, a ≈ømall Oratory of the Turks, which one Ibrahim, who was Pacha of Egypt about thirteen years ago, caus'd to be built out of a hatred of the Copties, upon the ruins of a Church which belong'd to them, and where they reverenc'd ≈øome Relicks and ≈øteps of our Lord, and of his mo≈øt holy Mother.

This Pacha chang'd, as we have ≈øaid, this Chappel into an Oratory of Turks, that no Chri≈øtian might have the liberty to enter in and vi≈øit it. But ≈øince the Turks have for≈øaken it one may go in freely without hindrance; therefore it is no longer named an Oratory, but il M√°kad, or the place of re≈øt.

In this M√°kad is a little Ci≈øtern of Marble of divers colours, full of Water, which comes into it by a Channel from the miraculous Well that is near by. The Copties ≈øay, from Tradition, that the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin was wont to wa≈øh in it the Linen of her divine Son; and that whil≈øt ≈øhe was employed in working, ≈øhe laid him in a little hole which is in the Wall of the M√°kad, a place where ≈øome religious Francs have heretofore ≈øaid Ma≈øs, out of devotion.

However it be, I will not deny a Tradition ≈øo ancient; but it is ≈øo hard to reconcile all the Circum≈øtances which they bring to prove it, that when I had done all that I could to under≈øtand the truth, I ≈øound ≈øuch doubts as did rather
contradict, than e≈øtabli≈øh any ≈øuch thing.

Very near this M√°kad, or re≈øting place, is the miraculous Well, very deep. Its Waters are lighter and ≈øweeter than the Waters of Nilus. This is ≈øo well known, that the Pacha's drink of it, and prefer it to the Waters of the River.

The Tradition of the Copties ≈øay, and ≈øome Mahometan Hi≈øtorians agree to it, as Amru ibn il verdi, that our Saviour hath wa≈øh'd him≈øelf in this Well, and by a Miracle he hath given this ≈øweetne≈øs, and extraordinary plea≈øantne≈øs to the≈øe Waters.

Its Sour≈øe, or Spring, is not well known. Some think that it came by a Miracle, others ≈øay that it proceeds from Nilus under ground. But I think it impo≈ø≈øible; 1. Becau≈øe of the great di≈øtance between the River and this Well; 2. Becau≈øe when the Waters of Nilus are corrupt and thick, the Water of this Well is clear, whereas if it proceeded out of the River, it would be as thick as the Waters of Nilus; 3. becau≈øe the Water of this Well never ri≈øeth, nor falls, as the River doth, but is always equal in height; finally I conceive it, from the name given to it, M√°-Tarea, which ≈øignifies fre≈øh Water; this ≈øignifies that it hath a particular Sour≈øe, and a quality not common with the Waters of Nilus.

The Mahometans ≈øay, that it proceeds from the Well Bir i≈ø≈øim≈øim, which is at Mecha; a famous Well, becau≈øe of a pretended Miracle of Mahomet. But this is a Fable invented by ≈øome of their Sciechs, to obtain more credit to their Prophet; for Mecha is di≈øtant from Cairo one and thirty days journy, as the Caravan makes them, therefore it is impo≈ø≈øible that a Well ≈øhould be in Egypt
proceeding from a Sour≈øe at ≈øuch a di≈øtance.

After that we had eaten in the re≈øting place, and drank of this good Water out of devotion, we went into the Garden, where heretofore the Balm trees were Planted, which yielded Balm only when they ≈øtood in this place, and were watered with the Water of the miraculous Well. One may read my Book upon this Subject, called The Church of Alexandria; where many remarkable things may be found, very curious, concerning the≈øe Trees and this Well.

In this Garden was heretofore to be ≈øeen the Sicamore-tree, which, as the Copties ≈øay, ≈øplit in two miraculou≈øly, to hide our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt and his mo≈øt holy Mother, when the Souldiers of Herod pur≈øued him: They ≈øay, that when they hid them≈øelves in this opening of the Sicamore, they ≈øaved them≈øelves from the Souldiers violence, by the favour of a Spiders Web that covered them ≈øuddenly, and appeared very old, though it was made in an in≈øtant by a Miracle: ≈øo that that they imagin'd not that any Per≈øon could be hid within, much le≈øs the Per≈øons whom they were ≈øeeking.

The Franci≈øcans of the Holy Land, that dwell at Cairo, di≈øpute with the Keepers of this Garden, the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this Tree; and ≈øay, that it fell down with old age in the year 1656. and that they gather'd then up the pieces which they keep carefully in their place of Relicks; I have ≈øeen them there. The Gardiners yet ≈øhew in this Garden a Stump which I have ≈øeen, which they ≈øay are the remains of this Sicamore. But this di≈øpute concerns me not much, neither do I think that I ≈øhould oblige tho≈øe Fathers to maintain
their intere≈øt in this ca≈øe that is ≈øo trivial.
When we had ≈øeen this Sicamore, we went out of the Garden to ≈øee the Needle, which is out of the Village, planted in the open Field, where ≈øtood anciently the City Heliopolis.

This Needle is not equally ≈øquare, for there are two ≈øides larger than the others: The large≈øt are each of ≈øix Foot, and the narrowe≈øt of five and a half. There be but few Characters graven upon it, but they be yet to be read; and tho≈øe that are graven in one ≈øide, are al≈øo in the three others. It is of a red Stone, as all other Needles that I have ≈øeen in Egypt, Planted upon the ground without any Ba≈øis to ≈øtand upon.

Near this Needle is a ≈øquare Stone of an extraordinary bigne≈øs, which ≈øeems to have been the Ba≈øis of ≈øome great Pillar; but it is worn on the ≈øides, therefore I neglected to take the mea≈øure of it.
In this Field Sultan Selim encamp'd with his Army, when he engaged in a Fight with Sultan Cajed Bey, the la≈øt King of the Mammelucs; ≈øome of the Trenches of his Camp are yet to be ≈øeen.

I went next alone from M√°-Tarea to M√≠nied Sored, another Village hard by on the We≈øt-≈øide, to ≈øee a miraculous Image of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, which the Copties keep in their Church; of which I have read a Miracle in an Aby≈ø≈øin Manu≈øcript, which I found in the Mona≈øtery of Koskam, near Momfallot in the middle Egypt, at my fir≈øt Voyage into Egypt. As ≈øoon as I had ≈øeen it, I return'd to Cairo.

The 17th of July, Saturday Night, I went to the Mona≈øtery of S. Michael, ≈øcituated out of the Old Cairo at the Ea≈øt-≈øide, about half an hours
riding on Hor≈øe-back, in the Field called, in Arab. Birket ≈øiech Ombarek, or the Lake of the ble≈ø≈øed Sciech; where I ≈øpent the Night to hear Ma≈øs; for the Copties ≈øay it ordinarily after Midnight.

The next day I return'd back to my Lodging, and ≈øaw in my pa≈ø≈øage all the Churches and Mona≈øteries of the Copties which are in Old Cairo; leaving on our left hand the three Churches which are in Babylon Ma≈ø≈ør, which was heretofore part of Old Cairo, but is now totally de≈øtroyed. I began my vi≈øit by the Churches that are in Ca≈ø≈ør I≈ø≈øc√©mma.

div.head: Churches, and Mona≈øteries of Ca≈ø≈ør I≈ø≈øc√©mma.
div.p: THE fir≈øt was that of Ma√°llaca: It is a very ancient Church, ≈øtately and very clear; and I may ≈øay that it is the mo≈øt beautiful that the Copties have in Egypt. It is the Metropolis in which the Patriarch performs his fir≈øt Divine Service.

The Copties bought it of Amru ibn il A≈ø≈ø, as may appear by the Contract written upon the Walls of this Church with the Hand of this Prince, who cur≈øeth there all the Mahometans that ≈øhall offer to take it from them.

There be five Heikels, or Chappels, in a rank; but ≈øeparated the one from the other with little Grates of Wood: ≈øo that five Ma≈ø≈øes may be read at once, and the Prie≈øts need not interrupt one another.

At the entry of this Church a little Image is to be ≈øeen, at the right hand, upon one of the Pillars: which Image, the Copties ≈øay, ≈øpoke to S. Ephrem,
one of their Patriarchs, to comfort him in his affliction, when Me√©z le din alla, the Califf, commanded him to tran≈øport Mount Gebel il moc√°ttam, which now ≈øtands behind the Ca≈øtle of Cairo, from one place to another, to prove the truth of his Religion; becau≈øe our Saviour Chri≈øt ≈øaith in the Go≈øpel, If you had faith as a Grain of Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, you ≈øhould ≈øay to this Mountain, remove thence to yonder place, and it ≈øhall remove; and nothing ≈øhall be impo≈ø≈øible unto you. He threatned him therefore that if he did not remove it, that he would de≈øtroy all his Nation, as a People that profe≈ø≈øed a fal≈øe Religion, and that de≈øerved not to live among≈øt them that were Believers. Becau≈øe this Image ≈øpoke then to their Patriarch, to comfort him and a≈ø≈øure him that he ≈øhould remove the Mountain in ≈øpight of the Jews, who had anger'd this Califf again≈øt them, they highly re≈øpect it.

Next to Ma√°llaca, I went to vi≈øit Sancta Barba; where, as my leader told me, the Body of this Saint re≈øts at the left hand of the Chappel. This Church is great and very light, and therefore ≈øeems to me to be the mo≈øt plea≈øant of all the re≈øt. There be al≈øo three Chappels in a rank.
I ≈øaw next the Church of Saint Sergius, which was built, as Said ibn Patrik ≈øaith in his Hi≈øtory, by a Coptie, a Secretary to Abd ilaziz ibn Meru√°n, a Califf of Egypt.

Under this Church is to be ≈øeen a Cave, in which, as the Copties hold by Tradition, Chri≈øt with his mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Mother have lived a while. It is divided into three Angles, or Parts, by little Pillars. In the fir≈øt, at the entrance, is the Bapti≈ømal Font of the Copties: At the bottom of the middle ≈øeparation is a place in the Wall, and in
this place a Stone, which, as the Copties believe, hath been ≈øanctified with the ≈øteps of our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour. The religious Francs ≈øometimes ≈øay Ma≈øs here. In the third ≈øeparation is another Stone ≈øanctified al≈øo by our Saviour's foot≈øteps.

In the Cave, I remember not well in which ≈øeparation, is to be ≈øeen the Epitaph of a Gentleman of Europe, buried there about two hundred and ≈øeventy five years ago, in Gothick Letters; but the Stone is plac'd up≈øide-down, through the ignorance of the Ma≈øon, as I believe; this is the Epitaph. Hic jacet Nobilis Petrus Louys IX. Neapollonies, qui obiit M.CCCC.II. die. XI. Februarii.

Next to this Church, I vi≈øited that of our ble≈ø≈øed Lady, in the Street called Darb itt√°ka. It is very ≈ømall, and very ob≈øcure. Out of this Church I ≈øaw a little round Stone of black Marble, lying upon the ground; about it were graven ≈ømall Hieroglyphick Letters.

At a little di≈øtance from this Church, through an Alley, is to be ≈øeen the remains of a Per≈øian Temple, called in Arab. Kobbet il fors, or the Temple of the Per≈øians, which Artaxerxes Ochus, King of Per≈øia, caus'd to be built in honour of the Fire; and though the Ruines are but ≈ømall, they di≈øcover yet that this Temple was heretofore very ≈øtately. In the in≈øide, about the Walls, are to be ≈øeen ≈øeveral ≈øtandings, or holes, as high as a Man, in which it is probable they plac'd their Idols.

I ≈øaw next the Church of Mary Girges, or of S. George, which is in the ≈øame Street called Darb itt√°ka, or the Street of the Window. It is very ancient, and of a mean beauty. At the entrance, on the right hand, is to be ≈øeen the Body of Amba Bi≈ø≈ø√∫ra, Bi≈øhop and Martyr, with his Epitaph in Arabick, which I could not place here, becau≈øe the Printer had not the Characters.

Next to this Church I went to ≈øee the Mona≈øteries of the Nuns, among≈øt the Copties, called D√©r il ben√°t, or the Mona≈øtery of the Maids, which was built, as they ≈øay, by a King called Alexander; but it is a place ≈øo filthy and ≈øtinking, that I could not ≈øtay there any time.

The la≈øt Church that I ≈øaw in this Ca≈øtle, was that of the Mona≈øtery of S. George, of the religious Greeks. In this Church is to be ≈øeen an Image of this Saint, that, as they ≈øay, hath the Power to heal and cure Fools. This Mona≈øtery al≈øo is very ugly, and filthy.

div.head: Churches, and Mona≈øteries, in the Patriarch's Quarters.
div.p: IN the Quarters of the Patriarch, named in Arab. Haret il B√°trak, a Suburb of it ≈øelf, on this ≈øide of Ca≈ø≈ør I≈ø≈øc√©mma, is the Church of Mary Moncure. It is very great, high, and built with very ≈øtrong Walls. In this Church the Patriarch of the Copties is cho≈øen and con≈øecrated.

It hath been ruinated by the Mahometans, and turn'd into a Store-hou≈øe of Sugar-Canes. It continued ≈øo to the days of the Patriarch Ephrem,
who, in the Reign of Meez le din alla, having tran≈øported the Mountain called Gebel il moc√°ttam, which now ≈øtands behind the Ca≈øtle of Cairo, to prove the truth of his Religion, and that of the Turks and Jews to be fal≈øe, got an Order from him to the Court of Beit il mal, or Trea≈øure of the Goods of the decea≈øed; that out of this Trea≈øure this Church ≈øhould be re-built with all the Apartments that are round about, and all the little Churches that are above it: Which was accordingly performed, as may be ≈øeen in the Hi≈øtory of the Patriarch's of Macrizi.
Mekkin, an Arabian Hi≈øtorian, confirms this Relation; and a≈øcribes this Miracle to this Saint, as he ≈øaith in his Hi≈øtory.

V√°deh ibn R√©gia, a Noble Man among≈øt the Mahometans, who turned Chri≈øtian; a little while after being very thir≈øty at Mecha, he pray'd to this Saint that he might be carryed into this Church, becau≈øe at that time the River Nilus running clo≈øe by, he might there quench his violent thir≈øt. This Saint carried him immediately into this Church in one Night, a way that the Caravan cannot perform in le≈øs than eight and thirty, or forty days.

At the entrance into this Church, on the left hand, is the Cave where dwelt heretofore Amba Ber≈øum il Eri√°n, or Saint Ber≈øum the naked; which was before the abode of a Serpent that did much hurt to the Inhabitants round about. In the Walls are to be ≈øeen the holes where he hid him≈øelf, but as ≈øoon as the Saint was enter'd in to do Penance, the Serpent ca≈øt it ≈øelf at his feet, to do him homage, and afterwards it never hurt any body. In this Cave is a little Altar to ≈øay Ma≈øs.

A little above this ≈øame Church there is four or five ≈ømall Churches which I had liberty to ≈øee the night of the Fe≈øtival of the Epiphany of the Copties, in the Year 1673. I ≈øtaid there to ≈øee the Ceremony they ob≈øerve, in dipping them≈øelves in the Water, in remembrance of Chri≈øt's Bapti≈øm. The Reader may, in the ≈øequel of this Journal, ≈øee this de≈øcribed in the Month of January, 1673.
Near this Church, is that of Amba Scin√∫de, or of Saint Sennodius; but the Turks have ≈øhut it, to draw from the Copties a ≈øum of Money, therefore I could not ≈øee it.

When I was out of the Patriarch's Quarters, I went ≈øtraight to Cairo to ≈øee the other Churches and Mona≈øteries that are thereabout: when I was come as far as the Bridge called Kantaret iggibs, or the Plai≈øter'd Bridge, I turn'd to my right hand, and when I was pa≈øt the heaps of Ruines and Rubbi≈øh that are there, I came to the Mona≈øtery of Mary Mina, or S. Menna, which is an Ho≈øpital rather, for poor old Men, than a Mona≈øtery.
Within the Walls of this Mona≈øtery are three Churches; one belongs to the Copties, the other to the Armenians, and the third to the Syrians; but it is a filthy place, and the Churches arc but dark.

div.head: A Journey to the City of Fi√∫m.
div.p:
THE Province of Fi√∫m hath been always e≈øteem'd one of the mo≈øt excellent of al ‚Ä¢
Egypt, becau≈øe of its fruitful Fields, of its grea ‚Ä¢
Riches, of its plea≈øant Gardens, which are the rare≈øt of all this Kingdom; and becau≈øe of many wonderful things that are there, I had ≈øo great a de≈øire to travel in it, that I thought I had ≈øeen nothing, if I did not ≈øee this Country al≈øo.

And becau≈øe Egypt is ≈øuch a Country that one cannot travel in it all the year, and in every ≈øea≈øon, for ≈øometimes you are hinder'd by the exce≈ø≈øive heats that burn and ≈øcorch your bodies, ≈øometimes by the overflowing of Nilus that bury all the Fields under water, and ≈øometimes becau≈øe the Arabians are ≈øcattered about the ways; and when the≈øe inconveniencies don't hinder, the Ca≈øciefs or Governours ≈øometimes are wont to fright Travellers, for commonly they be little Tyrants, who live by extortion and oppre≈ø≈øion of the per≈øons that have the unhappine≈øs to fall into their hands: Therefore to accompli≈øh this Journey with more ≈øafety, I waited for the Vintage of Fi√∫m, for then the ways are full of per≈øons that carry Grapes to Cairo, and then the Arabians retreat into the De≈øarts, and there is nothing to be fear'd.
In this ≈øea≈øon I undertook this Journey that I had long de≈øigned; I went from Cairo Monday the 21. of July.

And that I might not fall into the ≈øame danger as at Tarane, I took with me a Janizary, to whom I gave 15 Pia≈øters every Month; and I took my Blackmoor, nam'd Abul Ker√∫n, who≈øe courage I had experienc'd before; for them and my ≈øelf, I hired three Mules that were going back to that City; we went from Cairo the prefixt day before Noon.

At our arrival at the Mona≈øtery of Aduvie,
which is about an hours travelling from Old Cairo, ≈øcituate upon the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, we pa≈øt to the other ≈øide of the River, and from thence we march'd to Mocanan, a very good Town, a place where dwells an Arabian Prince, very famous, called Ibn Chabir; at night we got as far as Kahue Barna≈øcht, a Coffee-hou≈øe built at the entry in of the Wilderne≈øs through which one goes to Fi√∫m.

After that we had re≈øted our ≈øelves a little, we proceeded on in our journey before the Sun-≈øet, marching through the Wilderne≈øs with many others in our Company, who had overtaken as whiles we ≈øtayed.

We ≈øpent nine hours in going through this De≈øart, going all night through a Campane very equal, full of Sand, and houndle≈øs, and in the morning before the Sun-ri≈øing we arriv'd at Tamieh, a very great and con≈øiderable Town, belonging to the Ca≈øcieflik of Fi√∫m, ≈øcituate at the end of the Wilderne≈øs, about five hours journeying from Fi√∫m for a Hor≈øeman.
When we had re≈øted here a while, and drunk ≈øome Coffee, according to the cu≈øtom of the Country, we march'd on in our way, and enter'd into Fi√∫m about Noon.

At my fir≈øt arrival, I lodg'd in a publick Inn called Ocalet Beida, ≈øcituate near the Market, and almo≈øt ruinated, till I could meet with a better and more convenient abode. About ten days after I chang'd my dwelling, becau≈øe I was too much in the eye of the Turks, and caus'd them to be too jealous of me, which a Franc ought to be careful of, that he may not be cen≈øur'd and affronted by them. I took a lodging near the Chri≈øtians
dwellings, at a Turks hou≈øe, called Tatar Sciaban, who was a very hone≈øt man, notwith≈øtanding his Religion.

As ≈øoon as the Turks ≈øee a Franc in a Village or Country, chiefly where they never ≈øaw him before, they imagine immediately that he is loaden with Diamonds and Pearls. They take therefore notice of all his ≈øteps, to find out ≈øome occa≈øion to quarrel with him; and of all places of Turkie, this happens mo≈øt frequently in Egypt.

As ≈øoon as I was in the Town, the report ≈øpread about, that a rich Franc with a great Train was come. The Cadi thinking therefore that he had a per≈øon from whom he might draw a ≈øum of Money, becau≈øe he believ'd that I was a Merchant come thither to buy Wines in the Vintagetime to carry them to Cairo, which Commodity is forbidden in all the Territories of the Grand Seignior, he de≈øired the Naib Gaibe, or Soubachi of the place, to endeavour to find out my de≈øigns, and to let him under≈øtand them; for he promi≈øed to give him half the money that he ≈øhould get out of me, if I did buy any Wines.

For this purpo≈øe the Naib Gaibe, or Soubachi, a Renegade Fleming, who ≈øpoke well his Mothertongue, came to my lodging with two Ruffians, and enter'd into my Chamber whiles I was taking out my Cloaths, and without ≈øaluting any body, ≈øate down in a Corner, which is the place that belongs to the Ma≈øter of the hou≈øe in the Ea≈øt-Countries: The Ruffians ≈øtood at the door, leaning upon their Staves. I was mightily ≈øurpriz'd to ≈øee ≈øuch a per≈øon come to vi≈øit me. I called to my Janizary to know what he would have; he an≈øwered, that he under≈øtood that I was a
Franc, and that he was come to know whether I would buy any Wine, becau≈øe he would recommend me to that which was very good. I reply'd, that if he had no other bu≈øine≈øs, he might ≈øpare him≈øelf the trouble and pains that he took, that I was never a Merchant of Wines, and would not now begin; and that we Francs care not much for the poor Wines of his Country. To this he held his peace.

He enquir'd what Countryman I was; when I had told him that I was of the City of Erford in Germany, he ≈øeem'd to rejoyce, becau≈øe he had found one in ≈øuch a far Country whom he might name his Countryman, for he ≈øaid he was of Am≈øterdam. He promis'd me his friend≈øhip; we eat afterwards together, and I caus'd him to drink Wine as much as he would, which was very plea≈øing to him: when the liquor had a little chear'd his ≈øpirits, he di≈øcover'd to me the de≈øign of the Cadi, and the cau≈øe of his Vi≈øit; by this means he became one of my be≈øt Friends in Egypt, and my ≈øafety whiles I continued in that Town, without whom I ≈øhould not have e≈øcap'd the Train that was laid for me.

After a little re≈øt in my lodging, I ≈øought ≈øome means to ≈øtrike acquaintance with the Bi≈øhop of the place, called Amba Michel, who had a very good repute of an hone≈øt and a learned man, becau≈øe I was de≈øirous to have ≈øome body to conver≈øe with, and to ≈øpend my time with ≈øome advantage to my ≈øelf; I obtain'd this with ea≈øe, for he came a few days after and lodg'd at my hou≈øe: I am much beholding to him for many things that he hath told me concerning their Belief and Ceremonies, which I have in≈øerted in my Church of Alexandria.
Let us now ≈øee the de≈øcription of the Town and Territory of Fium.

The Town of Fium, the chief of the Province whereof it bears the name, is large and full of people: It is built upon the Ruines of the old Ar≈øinoe, which is near adjoyning on the We≈øt-≈øide. Though the mo≈øt part of the hou≈øes are but little, and made of Bricks dried in the Sun, they are neverthele≈øs commodious, and ≈øome, where the Officers and Commanders dwell, are large and beautiful. There be many Copties Chri≈øtians, and a Bi≈øhop, but no Church within the Walls; they perform their Devotions at De≈øie, a Village near by.

An artificial Channel cut from the River pa≈ø≈øeth through this City, from Ea≈øt to We≈øt: They name it Bahr Ju≈øef, or the River of Jo≈øeph, for they believe that Jo≈øeph, Jacobs Son, caus'd it to be made. 'Tis call'd al≈øo Calitz il Menhi, or the Channel of Menhi. This Channel is remarkable, becau≈øe it keeps fre≈øh water all the year, which proceeds from ≈øeveral Fountains there, but it is too ≈øhallow to carry Boats but when the River overflows. It begins about three days journey from Fium, drawing towards the South, near a Village named Tarut I≈ø≈øcerif, where I have been. It runs, when it hath left the Town, into the Lake named Birket il Kern, or the Lake of Charon, where the waters become ≈øalt.

In this Town are to be ≈øeen many Relicks of Antiquity, as Capitals, Antick Works, Pillars of Marble broken. In the Corn-market is to be ≈øeen a great Pillar, entire laid upon the ground, and a great Mill-≈øtone, both of a red ≈øtone; and almo≈øt in all hou≈øes is to be ≈øeen ≈øomething very remarkable for its antiquity.

Here is made much Linen for the hou≈øe, and Canvas to pack up the Commodities of the Country: They have a great deal of Flax, which yields a great benefit; ≈øtrak'd Linen is plentiful here, and very good, with which the Countrypeople cloath them≈øelves. The Leather of this Country is much e≈øteem'd, but chiefly the Blankets that are made here are the fine≈øt of the Levant, and are carried all over the world. Here are al≈øo made Sacks of Network of Cord, to carry upon Camels Straw, or dried Dung to burn, or Stones, or ≈øome ≈øuch thing, for they never u≈øe Carts.

This Territory is very fruitful and plea≈øant, and all that grows here is of a better ta≈øte than in the other Provinces. Here are Fields full of Ro≈øe-trees, and Woods of Fig-trees, which are not in other parts of Egypt. The Gardens are full of all manner of Trees, bearing Fruit; as Pear-trees, Orange-trees, Lemon-tree, Peach-trees, Plumb-trees, Apricock-trees, and many others that are ≈øent to be ≈øold at Cairo, which yields them a great profit.
In Fium only, of all the Provinces of Egypt, are Vineyards; and in the≈øe Villages only, in Fidimin where I have been, in Nacalife, Seliin, Abuke≈øa, Agiamiin, Gerrado, and Tobhar.

They make Wine thus: They pre≈øs the Grapes either with their Feet, or other wi≈øe, into a great Earthen Ve≈ø≈øel; they put afterwards the new Wine into a Sack of cour≈øe Linen, and ≈øtrain it into another Ve≈ø≈øel; from thence they draw it, and ≈øecure it in Jars well pitch'd within, which contain about twelve thou≈øand Drams. Now the≈øe Jars they place in the Sun during ≈øeven days,
leaving them open, that the new Wine might purge it ≈øelf; they ≈øtop them afterwards with Palm-leaves, and cover them clo≈øe with Mud. They leave their Wine in this manner, till they intend to drink it.

This Wine is not much e≈øteemed of by the Francs, becau≈øe there remains ≈øo much dregs that come out into the Cup with the Wine; but if they had but the art of clearing and clarifying the Wine, it would be doubtle≈øs a very plea≈øant Wine, for the Grapes are very ≈øweet, and plea≈øing to the ta≈øte.

I have not ≈øeen a Province in Egypt that is ≈øo much cut into Channels as this: They all proceed from Jo≈øephs River, and they are made to water the Fields with more ea≈øe; and becau≈øe this great number of Ditches would hinder men from travelling up and down, were it not for the Bridges, here be more than in any other part of Egypt. They are all made with burnt Bricks, and very ≈øtrong: The Tradition ≈øaith, that they were builded in the days of the Pharaoh's; and it is the opinion of the Copties, that the≈øe Kings imployed the I≈øraelites in making Bricks for the≈øe Bridges, which is very probable; for it is certain, that almo≈øt an infinite number of men are needful to make ≈øuch a prodigious quantity of Bricks.

This Province of Fium anciently had three hundred three≈øcore and five Towns and Villages, but now there be but three≈øcore and two; all the other have been ≈øwallowed up in the Lake Kern, or de≈øtroyed by the tyranny of the Governours.

The Ca≈øcief dwells in the Town: He pays now to the Pacha five and twenty Pur≈øes, and five
to his Kehaja, or Lieutenant, and to his Agas. He pays for his Province two hundred pur≈øes in four payments. The Divan of Cairo allows him three Cornets of Hor≈øe, or Spahins, to keep his Country, unto whom he pays every ≈øix Months five and twenty Pia≈øters, which is but a ≈ømall allowance; ≈øo that they are but poorly clad, and appear as ≈øo many Beggars, rather than as the Souldiers of ≈øo great an Emperour.

The ancient Town of Ar≈øinoe, ≈øcituated near Fium, on the North-Ea≈øt-≈øide, is now totally ruinated: There remains nothing of it now, but a great many Mountains very high rai≈øed, with the ruines and rubbi≈øh of the Town. They ≈øhew ≈øufficiently, that it was one of the greate≈øt and mo≈øt glorious Cities of Egypt. The people of the Country call it, Medinet Fares, or the Town of the Per≈øian; but I could never under≈øtand the cau≈øe of this name.

They ≈øay that it was de≈øtroyed and burnt by Cats, which the Enemies ≈øet into it when they had tyed Fire-brands at their Tails, which ≈øcattered the fire into every corner of the City, and burnt it to a≈øhes.
The Copties call it in their Books Ar≈øinoe, and Pliny calls all that Province, the Government of Ar≈øinoe.

On the 24th of this Month I went to Fidintin, a Village di≈øtant from Fium about two hours riding, towards the We≈øt, to vi≈øit the Bi≈øhop, who was gone thither out of the Ca≈øciefs ≈øight. I was cloathed in a Turki≈øh habit, with a Janizary and a Negre well armed, upon good Hor≈øes. Our coming put the poor Bi≈øhop into ≈øuch a fright, that he thought him≈øelf already kill'd, when he
heard that three ≈øtrange Hor≈øe-men ask'd for him. He thought at fir≈øt that we were ≈øome ≈øent by the Ca≈øcief to do him an injury. The≈øe poor people are become wonderful timerous, through the continual tyranny of tho≈øe Barbarians, ≈øo that at the lea≈øt motion they tremble and ≈øhake. He was pretty well ≈øatisfied, when I told him that I was a Franc come purpo≈øely to crave acquaintance with him: He entertain'd us in a very poor dwelling, invited us into his Parlour, and treated us with very good Wine of the Country. When we had ≈øpent ≈øome hours in conver≈øation with him, we went to ≈øee the Vines of that Quarter, and in the Evening we return'd home to the City.

The 29th of the ≈øame Month I went to Bijamuh, a Village about half a League from Fium, towards the North, to ≈øee an ancient thing, the Body of a great Statue of a Gyant, of a red Stone, without Head or Arms, ≈øtanding upon a Ba≈øis. This Statue is behind the Village, in a great broad Road.

I could never learn what it is, becau≈øe the Country-people have no Tradition of it; and in the Hi≈øtories of Egypt there is no mention made of it. I have only learnt that the people of the Country call it the Statue of Pharaoh; which I think not to be true, becau≈øe it is the cu≈øtom of the Egyptians to entitle all things of an extraordinary bigne≈øs with the name of Pharaoh, from a conceit they have that they were all Gyants.

The Ba≈øis of this Statue is ≈øquare, of hewn ≈øtones that are very great, every ≈øtone hath two foot and a half in breadth, and almo≈øt ten foot in length; the fore-front hath five Perches in length, that is about thirty foot.
Near this Ba≈øis five others ≈øtand in a Demicircle, but le≈øs, and without any Statue upon them.

The Bi≈øhop inform'd me, that heretofore in this Village was an Agia≈øma, or Fountain of holy Water, called by the Arab. Ein il Mandura; and that every Holy-Thur≈øday a great many Chri≈øtians were wont to meet there to drink of this Water out of devotion, but that the people of the place, who are all Mahometans, have ≈øtop'd it up, to prevent the continuance of this Super≈øtition.

When we had well ≈øeen the≈øe things, we return'd to the Town, and in our way we went over the Ruines of the ancient Ar≈øinoe, where I ≈øaw nothing remarkable, but ≈øome old Walls which my Guide told me were the remains of a Bath.
When we were come near the Town, we left it on the left hand, and went to ≈øee the Needle of Bibig, whereof this is the de≈øcription.
This Needle is placed on the ground, without any Ba≈øis, in the middle of a Corn-field, in a place where is no hou≈øe, nor mark of any that hath been there.
It is di≈øtant from Fium about a long half league, near a Village called Bibig, from whence it borrows the name. This Village is ≈øcituated on the South-we≈øt of Fium, and belongs unto it.

It is built in a long ≈øquare, very high; its large≈øt ≈øides have ≈øix foot, and the narrowe≈øt are of four. This Needle abuts not into a ≈øharp point, as others in Egypt and Italy, but the top is made like an A≈ø≈øes back: On the South-≈øide, which is one of the large≈øt, there are three ranks of Images,
that repre≈øent Men and Women holding one another by the hand: under the≈øe three ranks begin fourteen ranks of Hieroglyphick Characters, about the bigne≈øs of a finger, which are to be read from the top to the bottom; every rank is divided from the other, which is near, with a line that is drawn between, all along the Needle: So that without doubt this Needle is the mo≈øt curious that may be ≈øeen. In every one of the le≈ø≈øer ≈øides is but one rank of le≈ø≈øer Characters, which yet continue very clear and beautiful.

There is one thing to be lamented at, that time hath almo≈øt blotted out the Figures, from the middle of the Pillar to the bottom; and that the Stones have not been able to defend them≈øelves from corruption, being much worn out: It is of a red Stone, as all others.

Its top is like an A≈ø≈øes back, and very large, ≈øit for the Vultures and Hawks to pitch upon it at night: The≈øe Birds have ≈øo whitened it with their dung, that the uppermo≈øt Figures are ≈øcarce to be di≈øcern'd.

I have taken notice, that all the Needles that I have ≈øeen in Egypt, ≈øtand not upon any Ba≈øis, but upon the ground, which makes me believe that the invention of planting them upon a Ba≈øis, is not derived from the Egyptians, but from the Romans, who having taken notice that this kind of Pillar was very u≈øeful, and contain'd great My≈øteries in their Characters, they have rais'd them upon a Ba≈øis, to render them more remarkable and con≈øiderable to the curious. We return'd to the Town about Noon.

div.head: A little Journey to Sennuris.
div.p: S∆≤nday the 31. of July I went to Sennuris, a Village belonging to the Ca≈øcieflik of Fium, ≈øcituate on the North of this Town, and about four hours travelling on Hor≈øeback, to ≈øee the remains of Antiquity that are there, and thereabouts; be≈øides my Servants, ≈øome other Copties Chri≈øtians went with me.

When I had a little re≈øted my ≈øelf at Sennuris, in the hou≈øe of Sciech il Beled, the Chief of the Village, a Moor, where my friends oblig'd me to take my lodging, I went to take notice of the Village, which is great, and very beautiful; and at the ≈øame time I ≈øaw the Church of the Copties dedicated to the Archangel S. Michael, but it is very mean.

Neverthele≈øs, I took notice there of one thing very remarkable, namely, a ≈øquare ≈øtone, where are three little Figures cut the fir≈øt repre≈øents the Archangel S. Michael, the middle repre≈øents the Virgin Mary, who holds in her Arms her Son, and the third the Angel Raphael. The names of every one is written underneath in Greek Letters, in the Copties Language. This ≈øtone is a foot and a half long from ≈øide to ≈øide: The Prie≈øts informed me, that this Stone was heretofore in the Chancel, but when they ≈øaw that the people render'd homage to the≈øe Figures, they plac'd them in a corner of the Church, that they might hinder them from Idolatry. They offer'd it to me for a Pia≈øter and a half, becau≈øe I ≈øeem'd to value it at a high rate; I would not take it, becau≈øe I had no intent to return ≈øo ≈øoon to Cairo, but to go further into Sayda.

At the We≈øt-≈øide of the Village, about a Mu≈øquet-≈øhot from it, is to be ≈øeen a very ancient Bridge of Bricks, made for a Pa≈ø≈øage for the River when it overflows. The People of the Country ≈øay, that Jo≈øeph, Jacob's Son, cau≈øed it to be built. It is apparent by its Ruines, that heretofore it was very great, but now there remains no more but four Arches.
Round about this Village is ≈øown a great deal of Flax, but it is not e≈øteem'd ≈øo good as that which grows in other parts of Egypt.

At that time there was, as well as at, Fi√∫m, a want of fre≈øh Water, becau≈øe the people of the Country u≈øually ca≈øt into the River their Hemp, where they take their Water to drink; this had ≈øo poi≈øoned the Waters, that they did ≈øtink, ≈øo that I was forced to cau≈øe ≈øome fre≈øh Water to be brought from Fi√∫m, which is about four hours di≈øtant from this Village.
In an evening I walk'd to ≈øee the Lake Kern, which is very near Senn√∫ris, on the We≈øt-≈øide.

This Lake is narrow, but long, for I was told that it is about two days travelling for a Hor≈øe, in length. This is doubtle≈øs the Lake Miris mentioned by Pliny, when he ≈øaith, Inter Ar≈øino√Øten Prafecturam, ac Memphiten Lacus fuit, circuitu CCL.M. pa≈ø≈øuum, aut ut Mutianus tradit, CCCCL.M. & latitudinis L. pa≈ø≈øuum, manu factus √† Rege qui fecerat Moeridis appellatus: For there is no other Lake between Fium, which is Ar≈øinoe, and the City of Memphis, or the place where it ≈øtood.
At its Ea≈øtern end is plac'd the Village Tam√≠ch, mentioned before; and in its We≈øt end is the famous Ca≈øtle of Vizir Caron, of which I ≈øhall ≈øpeak hereafter.
This Lake receives all the Waters that run from the Fields when Nilus is overflown, and from the River of Jo≈øeph‚ñ™ they become ≈øalt becau≈øe the Earth is full of Niter.
Here is much Fi≈øh, chiefly a Fi≈øh called is Arab. Houd, which I have de≈øcribed in the Chapter concerning the Fi≈øh of Nilus.

On the other ≈øide of the Lake are De≈øarts of Sand very large; I have heard from Per≈øons worthy to be believed, that there are to be ≈øeen many remarkable Ruines of ancient Towns, particularly of Temeh i≈ø≈øebag, or of Temeh of Lieus; a Town ≈øo named becau≈øe of the Statues of Lieus that were there to be ≈øeen.
Here is al≈øo to be ≈øeen the Ruines of an ancient Mona≈øtery named Deir Abul√≠fe, or the Mona≈øtery of Abul√≠fe.

They told me, that they had ≈øeen the Labyrinth which is at the end of the Lake We≈øterly, mentioned by Pliny, when he ≈øaith, There was a Labyrinth in the Lake of Moeridis, built without any Wood. This Labyrinth is named now by the Egyptians, Ca≈ø≈ør Carun, or the Ca≈øtle of Vizir Caron; a famous Lord in the Hi≈øtories of the Arabians, becau≈øe of his Trea≈øures which are ≈øaid to be here buried, and kept by dreadful Tali≈ømans. They tell me, that this Ca≈øtle hath three hundred and three≈øcore and five Chambers, ≈øo intangled one into another that a man cannot get out, if when he comes in he doth not take notice of the way.

This Report gave me a great de≈øire to venture to ≈øee all the≈øe Wonders at any rate: I had already agreed with the Chieftain of the Village, to have from him a Guard of twelve Men, whom he knew
to be faithful and tru≈øty; but my Jani≈ø≈øary, a timerous Fellow, ≈øpoil'd my de≈øign, by ≈øhewing me the danger there was of the Arabians; he threatned likewi≈øe the Guard, to tell the Ca≈øcief, which would have created me ≈øome trouble.
I conceive that this Relation may beget a de≈øire in ≈øome Traveller to go and ≈øee this Curio≈øity, therefore I will give him a little advice which ≈øhall help him to accompli≈øh his de≈øign.

He mu≈øt know, that he ought not to go to the Labyrinth from Sennuris, or to the other ≈øide of the Lake, but to Senhur, a Village di≈øtant from Sennuris about an hours travelling; for there the Fi≈øher-men of the Lake Caron dwell, who are be≈øt able to carry Men thither: But it is very needful that a Franc, who will undertake this Voyage, be well learn'd in the Arabian Tongue, that he be well cloathed according to the Mode of the Country, that he may not be known, and chiefly let him di≈ø≈øemble his de≈øign as much as he can; for if he fails in any of the≈øe particulars, he will doubtle≈øs be lo≈øt. The Moors, who are very jealous of the Trea≈øures that are ≈øaid to be there, will knock him on the head, that he may not carry them away.

I ≈øtaid three days at Sennuris, for the place did plea≈øe me, and the Inhabitants were very civil. I return'd to Fium, ≈øecond day of Augu≈øt, very much di≈øpleas'd with my Jani≈ø≈øary, becau≈øe he had cro≈øs'd my de≈øign.

On the ≈øecond day of this Month the Water of Nilus enters into the Channel of Jo≈øeph, which pa≈ø≈øeth through Fium, as we have ≈øaid. Then its Waters are purified, and purged from its ≈øtinking qualities which the Flax and Hemp give it:
Then the Ci≈øterns of the Town are fill'd with Water, which the Inhabitants drink all the year long, therefore this inundation makes all the people of the Country round about to rejoice.

div.head: A Walk to the Pyramide of Havara.
div.p: BEtween the Towns of Fium and Bene≈øuef, which are di≈øtant the one from the other about a little days Journey, there be two great Pyramides; the one is near Fium, the other nearer to Bene≈øuef. The fir≈øt is named Haram Havara, the Pyramide of Havara: The other Haram Ilahun, the Pyramide of Ilahun.

Thur≈øday, the 4th of Augu≈øt, I went to that of Havara, ≈øo called from the neighbouring Village Havara. It Stands about an hour and a halfs walking from Fium, on the South ≈øide, ≈øcituated in a ≈øandy Wilderne≈øs, like that which is over again≈øt Cairo, where the Pyramides ≈øtand: when we were gone beyond a certain Bridge of Brick, very old, which is upon the Highway of Bene≈øuef, we left it, to take a ≈øhorter cour≈øe; but we found cau≈øe to repent it, becau≈øe the way was craggy and full of Sand.

We were oblig'd al≈øo to go through the Bahr Belame, or the River without Water, which cau≈øed us to endure much trouble and fear, in regard of the depth that was extraordinary, and our being forced to climb up again. And when we had overcome all the≈øe difficulties, and were near the Pyramide, about ≈øix hundred Paces from it we met with a Ditch of the River of Jo≈øeph, full of Water; we could not get over it, but were forced to ≈øtay
on that ≈øide, and from thence take a vi ‚Ä¢ w, at a di≈øtance, of the Pyramide, to my great di≈øplea≈øure. I took notice, that in its elevation and breadth, it was much like the ≈øecond Pyramide which is at Gize, but the length of time hath almo≈øt reduc'd it to Du≈øt, ≈øo that it appears like a ≈øharp Mountain of Sand, rather than a Pyramide.

The De≈øart where it ≈øtands, is like that of the Mommies which is near Sacc√†ra. Some Wells of Mommies are here to be found, whereof the entry is fill'd up with Sand, and ≈øome are half empty. Upon the ground are ≈øcattered, here and there, Bones of Mommies, broken Wood, and pieces of Coffins; ≈øo that one may ≈øay that it is altogether like that of Sacc√†ra.

But becau≈øe we were without any Guide, and my Jani≈ø≈øary was a very Coward, having none but him with me, he allarm'd me ≈øeveral times with the fear of the Arabians, be≈øides, our Bea≈øts were tired with the deep way; I was therefore con≈øtrain'd to ≈øet bounds to my Curio≈øity, and to return to the Town, pa≈ø≈øing through the River without Water, near its Mouth, leaving on our left hand, near the Pyramide of Havara, the Ruines of an ancient Town, whereof I could never under≈øtand the name; and a little further, on the ≈øame ≈øide, the Village of Havara, from whence this Pyramide borrows the name, and at a little di≈øtance from this Village, a very ancient Bridge, and very high, which is made to give a pa≈ø≈øage to the River Nilus when it overflows: We return'd to Fium again about Noon.

For the other Pyramide, called of Ilahun; the Arabian Hi≈øtorians ≈øay, that Jo≈øeph, Jacob's Son,
cau≈øed into be built. It is ≈øo nam'd from the Village Ilahuis, near adjoining, belonging to the Ca≈øcieflik of Bene≈øuef; but becau≈øe I could not look upon it, but at a di≈øtance, I cannot well de≈øcribe it. The Reader may ≈øee what Macrizi faith of it.

div.head: A Walk to the Mona≈øtery Ca≈øciabe.
div.p: ON the 19th of Augu≈øt I went to the Mona≈øtery of Ca≈øciabe, di≈øtant from Fium about two hours walking, or thereabouts, drawing towards the South-Ea≈øt in the Wilderne≈øs, called by the Arabians, Gebel Naklon, or the Mountain of Naklon.

In our way to this Mona≈øtery we went over ≈øeveral Bridges of Brick, very ≈øtrong, made by the ancient Egyptians: And we left at our right hand at the entry of the Wilderne≈øs, which is about half way, the Mona≈øtery of Deir il azeb; and a little further, at our left hand, the Ruines of an ancient Town overthrown, of which I could never learn the name.

The Mona≈øtery of Ca≈øciabe is very ancient; it is almo≈øt totally ruinated, unle≈øs it be the Church dedicated to the Arch-Angel Gabriel, which is very beautiful, and painted in the in≈øide with the Pa≈ø≈øages of holy Writ. The top of this Church is ≈øupported by Pillars that ≈øtand at a di≈øtance, and of divers Stones.
