Under this Church is another that I could not ≈øee, becau≈øe the Provi≈øions of the Mona≈øtery were there ≈øhut up.

This Church was built by one named ∆≤r, the Son of Ibra≈øcit, a very famous Magician; who,
as the Arabian Hi≈øtories relate, had this Child by a Daughter of an Ea≈øtern King. When at la≈øt this ∆≤r had left the Art of Magick which his Father had taught him, he addicted him≈øelf to Virtue, ≈øo that afterwards he became Bi≈øhop of Fium, and built this Church, and Tradition ≈øaith, that the Virgin Mary laid the Foundation-≈øtone of the Church, and of the Altar, and the Archangel S. Michael mark'd out the Quire, and the re≈øt of the Church.

Many remarkable things happened whiles this Church was building; I mention them not for brevity ≈øake, they that will under≈øtand them, may read the Arabian Manu≈øcript mentioned before, and now in the Kings Library.

On the top of the Mountain, behind this Mona≈øtery, on the South-≈øide, are yet to be ≈øeen the ruines of an ancient Town, which the Copties ≈øay was inhabited by the Patriarch Jacob, and for this cau≈øe they name it yet Mod≈øellet Jacub, or the Tabernacle of Jacob.

A little higher, upon the ≈øame ≈øandy Mountain, are to be ≈øeen many Caves where the Hermits anciently lived; I went into ≈øome of them out of curio≈øity, they are very little, and there is in them nothing extraordinary: when I had taken a view of all that was remarkable, I return'd to Fium in the Evening.

The Country had been ≈øome days dround about Fium, which oblig'd the Commanders of the Militia, and the Ca≈øcief, to retreat to Cairo. And becau≈øe the Robbers are very formidable at this time, and commit many di≈øorders, I was oblig'd to return al≈øo to Cairo. I went from Fium the 16th of Augu≈øt in the morning, and returned
the ≈øame way that I came, and the next day I was at Cairo in the Evening, after five and twenty days abode at Fium.

At my return to Cairo, I began my Church of Alexandria; a very curious work, and very u≈øeful to the world, and chiefly to the Learned that de≈øire to under≈øtand how the Churches of the Ea≈øt agree with the Roman. It contains all the Ceremonies and Doctrines of the Ancient and Venerable Church of the Copties, which is that of Alexandria. I have taken them out of two Manu≈øcripts in Arab. very ancient and rare, unknown to us in Europe before now; the one is called il Mosbah iddolme d' Abulbaracat, and the other, il Giauharet innefi≈ø≈øe fielm il Keni≈øe. I have been very exact and diligent in compo≈øing this Book, that it might render my name immortal. I ≈øhall endeavour to give it to the Pre≈øs as ≈øoon as I ≈øhall be return'd to Rome, where I make my ordinary abode.

The ≈øecond of September, which was the third Friday after the opening of the Calitz, a skilful Swimmer cau≈øed him≈øelf to be admired of all the City, by a very bold action; he had his arms tyed behind his back, his feet tyed at an Iron Chain, which weighed ten pounds: In this manner he ventur'd to ≈øwim upon his back, from the mouth of the Calitz. to the end of the Town, which is about three quarters of an hour walking a-foot.

This cu≈øtom hath been anciently us'd in Cairo: A skilful Swimmer performs this every year, two Fridays following after that the Calitz is open'd. The Pacha gives him for his reward a thou≈øand Meidins, which make three and thirty Pia≈øters.

The Guards of the Soubachi went before him in a Boat, to hinder him from receiving any harm: about five and twenty other Boats full of Spectators followed. He ≈øwum this year but once, becau≈øe Ibrahim Pacha, who loved not ≈øuch u≈øele≈øs expences, commanded him away when he came to demand his ordinary wages; therefore in≈øtead of a thou≈øand Meidins, he gave him but one hundred.

There is another that ≈øwims in the ≈øame manner as this, from the beginning of the Calitz to the end of the City. He had his feet tyed with a Chain, a Di≈øh of Coffee in one hand, and a Pipe of Tobacco lighted in the other, at his mouth. The Pacha u≈øually gives him the ≈øame reward; but becau≈øe the former had not had his u≈øual Salary, this la≈øt would not this year ≈øhew his dexterity. I was told that the≈øe Swimmers eat nothing for three days but Cich-Pea≈øen, and that they ≈øwallow their breath ≈øo long time, which cau≈øeth their Bellies to ≈øwell, and become light as an empty Bladder. I was told al≈øo, that ≈øometimes they kill them≈øelves, or at lea≈øt become very ≈øick.
On the 12th of September the Pacha cau≈øed the Trea≈øure of the Grand Seignior to depart for Con≈øtantinople with its ordinary guard and pomp.

There were one and thirty Mules loaden with Spani≈øh Coyn, and Zequins of Venice. This Trea≈øure amounts u≈øually to one thou≈øand two hundred Pur≈øes, and each Pur≈øe to five hundred Crowns. The Sangiac-Bey that carries it is obliged to expend all the Moneys needful for this Voyage, and it co≈øts him u≈øually one hundred Pur≈øes, or fifty thou≈øand Crowns. The Caravan
begins to march in the beginning of the Moon and arrives at Con≈øtantinople at the end of one hundred days.

This Trea≈øure is taken fir≈øt out of the Carache, or Tribute of the Lands and Villages which the Farmers Rent of the Divan; for all the Lands of Egypt, unle≈øs it be the Patrimony of the Mo≈øques, and the Lands belonging to Micha, are the Grand Seigniors, becau≈øe he conquer'd Egypt with the Sword. 2. It is taken out of the Douanes of Alexandria, of Ro≈øetta, of Bouquir, of Damietta, of Brullos, of Boulak, and of Ibrim. 3. Out of the Chordis. 4. It is taken out of the Lakes and Pits of Nitre, which are in the De≈øart of S. Macarius, and out of the Salt-pits near Alexandria. 5. From the Shambles of Cairo, whereof I have already ≈øpoken. 6. From the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe or Douane of the Bohars, or Spices; and generally from all Merchandizes imported from Mecha, Mocoa, and the Indies. 7 From the Mint. 8. From the Giavali, or Tribute which the Chri≈øtians of the Levant, and the Jems are oblig'd to pay for their Heads. 9. From the Trea≈øure called Beit il mal, which comprehends all the decea≈øed goods. 10. From the Office of Surveyor of the Provi≈øions.
The ≈øame day I ≈øaw the Mo≈øque of Califfe Hakem be amr ille: It ≈øtands out of Cairo upon the Mountain called Gebel il mocattam; but now there appears nothing but the Walls.

The ≈øame Califfe had made near this Mo≈øque a place to ob≈øerve the cour≈øe of the Stars, named in Arab. Ra≈ø≈øad ve Mofatek beta Hakem, which is now ruinated; he made u≈øe of it to make his Tali≈ømans, as art in which he was very skilful.
The Egyptians ≈øay that he could go in and out into all the Caves under ground, where he knew the Trea≈øures of the ancient Kings and Lords of Egypt to be hid, and that he could make u≈øe of them when he pleas'd; and that by the power of Magick, and the extraordinary skill that he had in that Art.
According to the example of tho≈øe great men, a little before his death he buried his own Trea≈øures, and put a Crocodile made by the Tali≈ømanical Art to keep them.

In this Mountain, and near this Mo≈øque, he cau≈øed ≈øeveral Caves to be digg'd wide and large in the Rock, ≈øo as to pa≈øs from one into the other; in the furthermo≈øt he cau≈øe a Pond to be made to keep water in, cut in the Rock; in it is a Crocodile that begins to fly at one as ≈øoon as a man enters in. Moreover, in the bottom of the water, is to be ≈øeen a door which leads to other Caves under ground, where the Records of Egypt declare that his Trea≈øures are hid. No man can imagine from whence this water can come, for the Cave is upon a high Mountain which is very dry always, and in this place is no Spring: And it is not known what this Crocodile is, and how he may be nouri≈øhed, during ≈øo many ages. To take this Trea≈øure, you mu≈øt know how to undo this Tali≈øman, that is, one mu≈øt take away the water, and the life of the Crocodile; for both are the effects of Magick, which depend upon the Art of the Tali≈ømans.

I have been very diligent in Egypt, to ≈øeek for, and ≈øend to Paris, among≈øt other rare Manu≈øcripts, the anciente≈øt and be≈øt Authors of the Arabians, which might give ≈øome light and
knowledge of this Noble Science. I may ≈øay that I have emptied Egypt of ≈øuch kind of Books, with an intent that if I was ever admitted to the ≈øervice of him who had given me this Commi≈ø≈øion, I might have the time and the means to di≈øcover with ea≈øe the admirable ≈øecrets of this Science, and to unfold the Enigms under which it lies hid; and by the ≈øame means to di≈øcover of what con≈øequence tho≈øe Manu≈øcripts are, though they are de≈øpi≈øed by ≈øome that under≈øtand not neither their price nor u≈øe.

The Reader may peru≈øe an Arabian Manu≈øcript in Quarto, called, Eijun it hekajek, ve eidah il terajek, of Meimun the Magician that teacheth the means to de≈øtroy all manner of Tali≈ømans. He may read another in Octavo, called, Kitab gaiet il maareb, Fi menajeh ve il chabaia, ve il medaleb, that di≈øcovers the places of all the Trea≈øures of Egypt, their value, the Figure of the Tali≈øman that keeps them, and how to de≈øtroy them; I have ≈øent them both to the Kings Library.
On the 12th and 20th of September, I went to ≈øee the Great Aqueduct, called in Arab. it Migro, that conveys water from the River into the Pacha's Ca≈øtle.

This Aqueduct is near Nilus in old Cairo; the Mouth there ≈øtands a Ca≈øtle of a Hexagone Figure very high, ≈øupported by as many Arches very lofty. There is an a≈øcent through a large way, open towards Heaven, made ≈øloping about, for the conveniency of the Oxen that draw water out of the River, and cau≈øe it to mount up by ≈øeven Wheels as high as the Platform on the top of the Ca≈øtle, where there is a large Pond
or Ba≈øon to receive the water, and about it ≈øeven great holes like Wells, which have given the name to this Ca≈øtle of the Seven Wells. The water runs from this Ba≈øon into the Aqueduct, which appears, and from thence it goes into the Caraffe, which is at a great di≈øtance, where it meets with the Earth as high as the Aqueduct; and then it ≈øtops there, and runs next into a Channel under ground to the Pachas Stable, from whence it runs into his Ci≈øtern, and furni≈øhes the Ca≈øtle.

This Aqueduct is ≈øupported by three hundred and ≈øeventeen high Arches, and not by three hundred and fifty, as a certain Traveller ≈øaith, for I have exactly number'd them my ≈øelf: They are made as well as the Ca≈øtle of great ≈øquare ≈øtones, cut as we do Diamonds: One of the Supporters on the chief ≈øide is about eight foot nine inches broad, and under the Arch it is only eight foot. The opening of one of the Arches is fourteen foot and a half broad.

The Copties ≈øay that Mekaukes, a famous man of their Nation, and Governour for the Emperour Heraclius, made this Aqueduct, but they are mi≈øtaken; for when this man governed in Egypt, the Ca≈øtle of Cairo was not in being, for it was built four hundred and forty four years after; and therefore this Aqueduct that now ≈øupplies it with water was not then needful; be≈øides, the In≈øcriptions in the Arabick Tongue declare, that this is a work of the Mahometan Kings; if I be not mi≈øtaken, I have read that it was Sultan Gauri, the la≈øt King but one of the Mammelukes, that cau≈øed it to be built.

The Pacha taketh out of the Revenues of the
Grand Seignior all that is needful to keep up this Aqueduct; for that purpo≈øe be nouri≈øheth three≈øcore Oxen, and gives wages to five men and a Ciurbachi that looke after it.

On the 13th of the Month of September, I went to vi≈øit the Patriarch of the Copties, one of my be≈øt Friends; and becau≈øe I had often intreated him to come and dine with me, I reiterated the ≈øame intreaty now again; but he an≈øwered me, that he had not been out of his hou≈øe a year before for fear of the Turks: He complain'd, that all the Patriarchs of the other Sects had the liberty to go about the Town, without fear of being di≈øturb'd by any, to vi≈øit whom they pleas'd, and to travel whither they li≈øted; but he was ≈øo narrowly ob≈øerved by the Turks, that he could not ≈øo much as go out of his hou≈øe, nor talk with any of other Nations openly, much le≈øs travel into any other place, but he mu≈øt give them a jealou≈øie of plotting again≈øt the State; by this means his life would be in danger.

I mu≈øt needs confe≈øs, that there is no Nation in Egypt ≈øo much afflicted as are the Copties, becau≈øe they have no body among≈øt them who de≈øerves to be honoured for his Knowledge, or feared for his Power and Authority‚ñ™ for all that were rich and wealthy, are de≈øtroyed by the cruelty of the Mahometans: therefore the re≈øt are now look'd upon as the Scum of the World, and wor≈øe than the Jews. The Turks abu≈øe them at their plea≈øure; they ≈øhut up their Churches, and the doors of their Hou≈øes when they plea≈øe, upon light occa≈øions, altogether unju≈øt, to draw from them ≈øome ≈øums of Money.

There was ≈øuch a tyrannical Action practi≈øed
upon them in this Month of September; for certain Jani≈ø≈øaries cut the Throat of a Whore, and ca≈øt her Body into the Lake Ezbekie. Upon that the Soubachi nailed up the Doors of all the Hou≈øes of the Copties round about, and cau≈øed them wrongfully to lay down the Sum of two thou≈øand Pia≈øters for this blood ≈øpilt, before they could have their Hou≈øes opened again, and freedom for their lives.
They endured another Cruelty in the ≈øame Year; for Pacha Ibrahim increa≈øed their ordinary Tax in this manner.

Till this Year they were not all obliged to pay the ≈øame Sum of Money. They were not all bound to pay it into the Trea≈øury of the Grand Seignior; for ≈øome were bound to pay it to certain Mo≈øques, othere to Sciech il Becri, who is a great Lord, and comes from Abn Becr, Califf, or Succe≈ø≈øor of Mahomet; and others to other Lords, called in Arab. Sadats. They that payed to the Mo≈øques, or Lords, were called Lay-Tributaries: And they that payed to the Trea≈øure of the Grand Seignior were called Tributaries of the Grand Seignior. The fir≈øt ≈øort of Tribute is very moderate, becau≈øe it ≈øeldom amounted to above two Pia≈øters; but the la≈øt hath always been, and is yet, one hundred and twenty Para's, that is, four Pia≈øters and a quarter. Be≈øides this, the Villages and Towns were taxed only in common: For Example, ≈øuch a Village was tax'd to pay ≈øuch a Sum, according to the number of the Chri≈øtians that dwell there; and when the Chouli, or the Collector, went to receive it, he tax'd every one according to his ability: The poor paid little, the rich more; ≈øo that this Tribute was equal.

But in this Year 1672. Ibrahim Pacha taxed them all as Tributaries to the Grand Seignior; and upon the ≈øame account cau≈øing them all to pay equally one hundred and twenty Para's; out of which the Pacha paid that which was due to the Lords and Mo≈øques, and the re≈øt was put into the Grand Seigniors Coffers.

This novelty hath reduc'd the poor Copties to de≈øpair; therefore when the Collectors come into any Village to gather the Tribute, they fly to the Mountains, leaving all to ≈øecure them≈øelves from violence, and affronts that would be done to their Per≈øons.

That the Receivers of the Tribute might know them that have paid it, they leave a little Ticket of coloured Paper, ≈øealed with the Seal of their Chieftain, where the name of the Chri≈øtian is written, his Village, his Province, his Dwelling, his Age, the Day, the Month, and the Year that he hath paid.

But they put not into this Ticket the whole Sum of one hundred and eight and twenty Para's, which they require, but only one hundred and three, becau≈øe there is no more that goes into the Trea≈øury of the Grand Seignior; the other five and twenty Meidins are for the Farmer of the Caraffe, paid to him becau≈øe of the great expences which he is at, to entertain a great many Men for the di≈øcharge of his Office. The Chri≈øtians carry always with them this Ticket, to ≈øhew it when they are que≈øtioned by the Men that belong to the Farmer, and this is their Acquittance.

The 18th of September I bought, of an Arabian, a great Lizard, alive, called in their Language,
Varal. I cau≈øed it to be skinned, and ≈øent the Skin to Mon≈øieur Arnoul, Superintendent of the Kings Galleys at Mar≈øeilles.

The body of this Lizard was altogether like that of the Crocodile, the Skin excepted, which was gray and ≈øpotted, as that of a Serpent, and without any Shells. It was three-foot long, and had five Fingers to each Foot, and long white Nails, as have the Crocodiles. Its Tongue was forked as that of a Serpent, the Headlong, and the Muzzle ≈øharp. Its Teeth were ≈øtrong, and cutting; the Arabians told me, that its biting was venomous and deadly.

I have ≈øince recover'd another of a differing ≈øort, when I was in the Mona≈øtery of S. Anthony. The Head of this was like that of a Tortell, and its Tail very big, and le≈ø≈øening by degrees, and ending into a ≈ømall point. It was full of knots round about, as ≈øo many Shells. This Lizard was not venomous, for I took it with my Hand, and when I had well con≈øider'd it, I gave it to an Arabian Dog that eat it.

div.head: A Voyage to the Mona≈øtery of S. Anthony the Great.
div.p:
VVHEN I had re≈øted my ≈øelf, a con≈øiderable while, at Cairo, after my return
‚Ä¢ rom Fium, and the great heats were over; I re
‚Ä¢ olved to travel to the Mona≈øtery of S. Anthony,
‚Ä¢ o ≈øee in this venerable place the foot-≈øteps of ‚Ä¢ he Father, and Founder of all the Monks. For that
‚Ä¢ urpo≈øe I left off writing my Church of Alex
‚Ä¢ ndria, and I embarqu'd my ≈øelf the 26th of September,
in the Afternoon, at Old Cairo, in a Ve≈ø≈øel loaden, and bound for the upper Egypt. I landed at Bene≈øuef, a great Town, in the Ca≈øcieflick of Be ‚Ä¢
ne≈øe, about two days travelling from Cairo.

I ≈øaw nothing remarkable in this way. The Villages, and Mona≈øteries, before which we pa≈ø≈øed, were the Convent or Deir il aduvie mentioned before, the Convent of the Abbot Ber≈øum il erian, or or S. Ber≈øom the naked, ≈øcituate in the Ea≈øt of Nilus, where his body re≈øts. The Village of Scieh il etmani, ≈øcituate on the We≈øt-≈øide, and the little Mona≈øtery of S. Anthony at the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus. Bou≈øche, a great Village on the We≈øt, where the Monks of S. Anthony have their Farm: at la≈øt, Bene≈øuef, on the We≈øt-≈øide of this River.

He that will travel to the Mona≈øtery of S. Anthony, ought fir≈øt to land at Bene≈øuef, and enquire from the Chri≈øtians of that place, whether the ways be free or not. If they be free, he ought to go to Beiha, which is a Village ≈øcituate almo≈øt over again≈øt Bene≈øuef, on the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, in the Ca≈øcieflik of Atfieh. There he ought to bargain with the Arabians that dwell there, concerning the price, the number of the Camels, and Men that he de≈øires to lead with him: which when he hath done, he ought to cau≈øe them to confirm the Bargain before ≈øome of their Chieftains, by repeating over the Fatha, which is the fir≈øt Chapter of their Alcoran; for which the Mahometans have a great veneration, and as much as the Chri≈øtians have for their Pater, or Credo; otherwi≈øe he mu≈øt not expect that they will be faithful. But when they have ≈øaid th ‚Ä¢ Prayer he may go with them confidently, at if h ‚Ä¢
were with his own Brethren: which ≈øufficiently declares, that there is no people in the World, never ≈øo barbarous and ≈øavage, but have a re≈øpect for their own Religion. And if at any time any other cro≈øs intere≈øt hath blinded them to commit any perfideous Action, God hath puni≈øhed them at the ≈øame in≈øtant for it with ≈øeverity; ≈øo that they would have wi≈øh'd that they had kept their Faith, as the Reader may under≈øtand by what follows.

Be≈øides the Price that he is to give them, he ought to grant them ≈øome quantity of Beans for their Camels, and give them ≈øome Meidins to buy Sandals, for the ways are full of ≈øharp ≈øtones: He ought to buy them ≈øome Meal, black Bisket, ordinary Hony, and Tobacco, as much as will be needful, to accompli≈øh the Voyage, and the number of the Men. He mu≈øt not forget every Morning and Evening to give a Di≈øh of Coffee to every one; if he delivers it generou≈øly, and freely, he may promi≈øe to him≈øelf a happy Voyage, and to be well tended. The Arabians have the care to provide Ve≈ø≈øels to grea≈øe, and fill them with the River-water, for there is none to be found in the way; or if there be, it is ≈øo noi≈øome, and ill-ta≈øted, that it is not drinkable.

There is two ways that lead from this Village Beiha, to this Mona≈øtery. The fir≈øt called, by the Arabians, il Tarik il Kihli; the upper way: and the other il Tarik il bahri, the under way; in re≈øpect of this Village from whence they ≈øet out.

The under way is the ≈øhorte≈øt, the mo≈øt frequented, and that which the Caravan takes, keeping upon the bank of the River for a while; and when one leaves it, the way turns at the right hand
into the Wilderne≈øs, to a place called Gibei. There is the fir≈øt Well which Nature hath digged deep in a firm Rock, into which the Rain-water runs; which Water is white as Milk, and ≈øweeter than that of Nilus.

About a days Journey farther is another, at the left hand of the High-way, at the foot of a high Mountain, called Gebel il cheleil; but its Water is noi≈øome and green, and the We ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ is full of Canes. A little farther is another, very well known to Travellers, becau≈øe it is near the Dwelling of a famous Arabian called Eid il beidavi; but the Caravan never goes thither but when they want Water, becau≈øe it ≈øtands from the High-way, at a di≈øtance: Therefore when they are furni≈øhed with Water at the ≈øecond Well, they pa≈øs at the left hand ≈øtreight to the Mona≈øtery.

The upper way leads from Beiha towards the South-Ea≈øt, and after a day and a halfs travelling it goes to the Ea≈øt. In this way are neither Waters, nor Trees, nor Hou≈øes, nor Gra≈øs; therefore it is needful to make good Provi≈øion of Water at Beiha for the whole Journey.

Therefore, knowing this before, I took at Beiha a Camel purpo≈øely to carry Water, and four others for me and my followers, the Aby≈ø≈øin, the Coptie, and Idris my Blackamoor. Be≈øides the≈øe, I took with me five Arabians, armed with Lances, to go on foot, and take charge of the Camels; and to protect us, if perchance any Robbers ≈øhould have a≈ø≈øaulted us; ≈øo that we were in all ten in number, and five Camels. When we had got all that was needful for the Voyage, we went from Beiha on Friday the 30th of September, about three a Clock in the Afternoon.

Though the under way was the ≈øhorte≈øt, and the mo≈øt frequented, yet we cho≈øe the upper way, that we might not meet with the Arabians, the declared Enemies of tho≈øe that conducted us. When we had travelled four days through a boundle≈øs Plain of Sand, which was not moveable, but hard, and full of ≈øharp cutting ≈øtones, that cut as ≈øo many Razors, we arrived at la≈øt, through a thou≈øand turnings, to the Mona≈øtery, the third day of October.

The Mona≈øtery of S. Anthony, which includes another, anciently peopled by the Aby≈ø≈øins, and now totally ruinated, is in the Wilderne≈øs, now called in Arab. Gebel Araba, or the Mountain of Carts; becau≈øe heretofore Provi≈øions were carried thither upon Carts, and not upon Camels, as now.

It is built upon the decline of the Mount Colzim, at its Ea≈øtern end, which reaches from Ea≈øt to South: It appears like a long Square; and the Front of the Mona≈øtery, which ≈øtretches from North-Ea≈øt to North, looks again≈øt another Mountain called Gebel il Cheleil, of which I ≈øhall ≈øpeak hereafter.

It is incompa≈ø≈øed in with an high Mountain, but feeble, and unable to make any re≈øi≈øtance; for it is old, and built with Bricks dried in the Sun. There is no Gate to the Mona≈øtery, one enters in by a Pulley, Men and Bea≈øts are all drawn up over the Wall.
It hath a large Circuit, about ≈øix hundred Fiddans, or two thou≈øand four hundred Acres within the Walls.

The Monks of the Levant dwell not together in the ≈øame Cells, as tho≈øe of Europe, but every
one hath a little Hou≈øe or Cell to him≈øelf, and the≈øe Cells are more or le≈øs beautiful and convenient, according as the Country hath experienced the cruelty of the Turks. Therefore the Mona≈øteries of the Levant, and chiefly tho≈øe of the Archipelago, are like ≈øo many great Towns or Ca≈øtles, becau≈øe of their Walls, Turrets, and number of hou≈øes that are within; but the Mona≈øteries of Egypt have nothing of that ≈øplendour, becau≈øe the Mahometans have been here more cruel than in any other Country ≈øubject to them. Neverthele≈øs, this Mona≈øtery is like tho≈øe of Greece, for it is ≈øurrounded with Walls: In the middle is a Dungeon, and round about many Hou≈øes where the Monks live; but in regard it has been de≈øtroyed long ago by the Arabians, it hath remain'd in that condition three≈øcore and ten years: The Copties who have lo≈øt, under the tyranny of the Mahometans, all their ≈øtrength and power, could never yet re≈øtore it to its former e≈øtate.

Therefore the Cells now are very little, and poor, of yellowi≈øh Earth, without Timber, Plai≈øter, Order, or Symmetry: they are ≈øo low, that a man may ea≈øily reach up to the top with his hand: therefore the Monks cannot well ≈øtand upright: there is a little light that enters in through holes in the wall, about a foot long; the doors are ≈øo low, that one mu≈øt ≈øtoop low to go in; that which is mo≈øt commodious, is that they have all flat roofs for the Monks to take the air at night, when the Sun is gone, and to ≈øleep when they plea≈øe.

Their dining-place is very dirty, and ob≈øcure: There is for Strangers a place of it ≈øelf, large
and decent, with two other Chambers hard by to put their Goods and Cloaths; and a little Kitchin.

The Gardens are very large, and great, and con≈øiderable, becau≈øe of the Herbs and Fruits that they bring forth. One might make of them the mo≈øt plea≈øant Gardens of the World, becau≈øe of their convenient ≈øcituations, for they lie ≈øhelving, with beautiful Plains.
There are two ≈ømall Vines that yield a ≈øort of White-wine, very delightful: They u≈øe it in ≈øaying of Ma≈øs, and in treating Strangers of Quality that come thither.

In this Mona≈øtery is a great quantity of fre≈øh water, as clear as Cry≈øtal, but very ≈øalt. It runs from the Mount Colzim, near by, in little ≈øtreams, under the Walls, into the Gardens, where they receive it in places made on purpo≈øe. They drink it, and make other u≈øes of it. this an≈øwer, and treated me afterwards with contempt.

The Vicar was afraid to want Bread in his Mona≈øtery; therefore he re≈øolved to quit it, and to ≈øeek another where he might be better treated: And becau≈øe he had no money to hire a Camel to carry him through a tedious and trouble≈øome way, he intreated me to give him ≈øome, which I did very generou≈øly, though I had cau≈øe to be offended with him. But he put this money in his Pur≈øe, without dreaming of hiring a Camel, believing that my men would ≈øuffer him to ride ≈øometimes upon their Camels: But in the way he found him≈øelf deceived; when he was weary, and his feet cut with the ≈øharp ≈øtones, he murmured at me; I told him of his covetou≈øne≈øs, unworthy of a man of his Profe≈ø≈øion, of his little love for his Flock, whom he left in the time when they needed mo≈øt his Fatherly care, but he received the≈øe reproofs very ill; ≈øo that from thence it may ea≈øily be imagin'd, how we travell'd together.
The Aby≈ø≈øin and the Coptie were at a continual variance, becau≈øe one thought him≈øelf more u≈øeful to me than the other; ≈øo that at every foot, I was oblig'd to make peace between them.

The night before the Arabians vi≈øited me, I was oblig'd to cau≈øe all my Cloaths to be carried into the Tower of the Mona≈øtery, into a ≈øecure place. In that hurley-burley I lo≈øt ≈øome, valued at five or ≈øix Pia≈øters; I cannot tell who≈øe fault it was, the Aby≈ø≈øin ca≈øt the fault upon the Coptie, to di≈øcredit him with me: However, as ≈øoon as we were come to Beiha, the Coptie vani≈øh'd away ≈øuddenly, without bidding us farewell.
This cau≈øed me to ≈øu≈øpect that the Aby≈ø≈øin had not accu≈øed him wrongfully.

To all the≈øe di≈øplea≈øures we mu≈øt add the fear of Thieves in the way; for at every ≈øtep, we look'd on the ground to ≈øee whether there were any foot≈øteps in the Sand; when we ≈øaw ≈øome that were fre≈øh, we were then grievou≈øly afraid; but our apprehen≈øions increa≈øed, when we ≈øaw the foot≈øteps turned our way, for we imagin'd that we ≈øhould meet them; fear alone made us take Bea≈øts at a di≈øtance for Men, and Bu≈øhes for Robbers that waited for us.

At la≈øt we were in ≈øight of Beiha, we imagin'd then that all our fears were over; but the Camels knowing the Fields where they were wont to feed, began to leap for joy, becau≈øe they were return'd to their ordinary Pa≈øtures; ≈øo that the Saddle of that upon which I rid being not well girded, nor the Bridle ≈øufficient to ≈øtop the Bea≈øt, it jolted, and ca≈øt me up into the Air ≈øeveral times: at every moment I thought I ≈øhould tumble down, and break my Neck, which happen'd not, through the care of the Arabian that ≈øtopt the Camel.

This Relation is ≈øufficient to make it appear, that if there is ≈øome plea≈øure in travelling, and ≈øeeing Forreign Curio≈øities, one buys them very dear, with the hazard of many dangers and cro≈ø≈øes, chiefly in Egypt, where cruelty and barbari≈øm ≈øeem to dwell.
I ≈øhall add ≈øome other Curio≈øities which I have ≈øeen in the De≈øarts.

We left at our left hand when we came from the Mona≈øteries, the ruines of a very ancient Town, ≈øcituate on the top of the barren Mountain,
called, Gebel il cheleil. This Town is in the mid-way between Beiha and the Mona≈øtery, in that place where the Mountain ≈øeparates it ≈øelf, and by which one pa≈ø≈øeth in coming or going from Beiha, in the way of the Caravan. The Arabians were ignorant of the name, and we had no time to ≈øtay there, having taken notice upon the Sand, of fre≈øh foot≈øteps of Hor≈øe-men that had pa≈ø≈øed that way, which cau≈øed us to conceive ≈øome danger, if we continued there any time.

I found there a Plant, which the Arabians call Barnub: It hath a little full Stalk, as a Moucheron, and at the top a little Butron, about the bigne≈øs of a Nut, which is full of Powder, which the Dyers u≈øe in dying. Its leaves are as ≈ølender as the leaves of Poppy; I gathered three or four of the≈øe Plants, but I could not keep them long, becau≈øe of their tenderne≈øs. I ≈øaw al≈øo an Herb which is called by the Arabians Rabl, that ≈ømells as Mint, my Arabians fed upon it. I ≈øaw there a great deal of Alcali, called in Arab. Kilu, which hath the virtue to take away from Cloaths all manner of ≈øpots. Upon the Mount Colzim, there is a Wood that grows, called Oud il akrab, or Scorpions Wood, the Monks of S. Anthony reduced it to powder, which they judge to be a good remedy again≈øt the biting of venomous Creatures, as well as to cure weak eyes, and eyes inflamed: They gave me half a pound in Canes; I have ≈øent it to Paris with the other Curio≈øities. In this De≈øart is a great deal of Coloquinte, and under the Sand much white ≈øalt very good, which my Arabians u≈øed to ≈øea≈øon their Fatir, and their Mafruca.

Fatir are great Cakes, as thick as finger, and
as large as a French Hat, baked in the Coals.

Mafruca is made of the Fatir, by breaking it in pieces, when it is yet hot, and taken from the fire; and by pouring upon it Oyl-Olive, and kneading it with the hand in a wooden di≈øh, as if it were Pa≈øte. My Arabians imagin'd to do me a great plea≈øure to offer me ≈øome to eat, for this is highly e≈øteem'd among≈øt them; but though I had a good Stomach, I had not the courage to ta≈øte of it, for I had good cau≈øe to loath it.
I return now to ≈øpeak of the things that happen'd at Cairo, where I landed the 30th of October.
That day they began the Zine, or Fe≈øtival of publick joy, becau≈øe the Grand Seignior had taken Caminiez from the Poles. This Fe≈øtival la≈øted from Sunday till Thur≈øday in the Afternoon.

It is the cu≈øtom at Cairo, that in ≈øuch like Fe≈øtivals every one adorns the out-≈øide of his Hou≈øe or Shop with Carpets and Pavillions, lighting about them all night many Lamps tyed to wooden Engines, ≈øome made in an Hexagone figure, others in an Octogone; ≈øome as Stars, others in another manner. The≈øe Engines are ≈øu≈øpended with Ropes tyed cro≈øs the Streets, which are beautiful to look upon. The Streets in all other times are ≈øhut in the night, but then are open, and the Chri≈øtians, during this Fe≈øtival, may walk about more freely than at other times at mid-day, becau≈øe one cannot di≈øtingui≈øh in that ob≈øcure light of what colour is the Turbant that they wear, nor di≈øcover whether it be ≈øtraked, or all white.

Be≈øides the≈øe Lamps and Carpets, the Beys hang up in a good order before their Palaces upon
the Walls; their mo≈øt beautiful Armour, as Head-pieces, Brea≈øt-plates, Coats of Male, Mu≈øquets, Hangers, Targets, and other ≈øuch In≈øtruments of War. The French Con≈øuls, who never come ≈øhort of them, cau≈øe beautiful Carpets to be hung in all the Streets of their dwellings, and Pavillions over the Streets, from one end to another, to keep off the heat of the Sun. Mon≈øieur de Tyger, Con≈øul of the French Nation, cau≈øed a kind of a re≈øting place to be erected, beautifying it with Carpets and Cu≈øhions, to receive the Per≈øons of Quality; he put round about the Pictures of the King, of the Queen, of the Dolphin, and other French Lords, in ≈ømall ingravery, with Tapers before them, to cau≈øe the Turks to admire the wit and invention of the French, who can make Pictures much like the Originals. But the Turks were ≈øurprized to ≈øee their Beards ≈øhaven off; they ask'd whether they were yet Children.

The≈øe Fe≈øtivals give much diver≈øion to the people, but they are very chargeable to tho≈øe that will ob≈øerve them, chiefly to the Con≈øuls; for be≈øides the Tents and Carpets, and other Ornaments that they mu≈øt hire, they are wont to give Coffee and Tobacco to all that come to ≈øee them; and if they be per≈øons of Quality, they mu≈øt have Sweet-meats: ≈øo that if a Con≈øul will come off with Honour, it will co≈øt him three or four hundred Crowns. The people run about the Streets, from morning till three hours after mid-night, all the time of the Fe≈øtival.
On the fir≈øt of November I went to ≈øee the Ca≈øtle of Cairo with a Chiaoux, a very good friend of mine.

The fir≈øt thing that we ≈øaw was the Royal Hall, where the Pacha keeps the Divan. He ≈øhewed me in the middle of this Hall, a great Cord tyed double to one of the Beams of the Roof, where, according to the cu≈øtom of the Country, the Ca≈øciefs that have not ≈øufficient to pay the Taxes of their Province, at the end of the year are lifted up in the air, with their hands behind, tyed to their backs: be≈øides, they are whipt upon their naked backs with a Whip of Cords, whereunto are tyed ≈øome Leaden Bullets.

We went up next to the top of the Ovens where they bake Bread, from whence the place called Kara, or the place of exerci≈øe, is di≈øcoverable. There the Pacha's men ≈øport them≈øelves with Bows and Arrows, and by running on Hor≈øe-back, aiming at a mark fixed at the top of a very high Tree.

We went to ≈øee next the Chambers where they make the Gun-powder, which are two great Parlours or Rooms on the ground, over again≈øt the Royal Hall of the Divan, with very ≈øtrong walls, and vaulted over head. In each are twelve Mortars of Pewter placed round, about a Cubit high, with their Pe≈øtels of Iron, which receive their motion, to pound the matter in the Mortars to powder, from a long Pole that an≈øwers to a Beam that ≈øtands in the middle of the Chamber, which a Hor≈øe turns round. There are near ≈øeveral other Chambers, where are many little Mortars, in which they refine the Gun-powder.
On the 19th of November I was pre≈øent at a Marriage of two Copties; the Ceremonies were performed in this manner.

After the Oration or Prayer of mid-night, or
as if we ≈øhould ≈øay, after Morning-prayer, the Friends and Parents led fir≈øt the Bridegroom, and next the Bride, from their Hou≈øes to the Church, with ≈øeveral lighted Tapers before them, and ≈øinging through the Streets Hymns in the Copties Language, and ≈øtriking with little wooden Hammers again≈øt ≈øome ≈øticks of Ebony wood, which is their Mu≈øick.

When they were come to the Church, they led the Bridegroom into the inner Chancel, where u≈øually the Prayers are ≈øaid, and brought the Bride to the place of the Women: Then the Prie≈øts and the People began in the Chancel their Prayers mingled with Hymns, which la≈øted very long: At the end, he that performed the Ceremony of the Marriage, went to the Bridegroom and read three or four Prayers, making over him the Sign of the Cro≈øs, before, and at the end of every Prayer. He cau≈øed him afterwards to ≈øit on the ground, having his face turned towards the Heikel, holding behind him upon his Head, in a ≈øtanding po≈øture, a Silver Cro≈øs, and continuing in Prayer.

Whiles this was doing in the Chancel, the Beadle cau≈øed the Bride, with one of her Kindred, to ≈øit down upon a Bench that he had there put out of the door of the uttermo≈øt Chancel. As ≈øoon as the Prie≈øts had ended in the innermo≈øt Chancel, the prayers of the Knot, as they name them. He that performed the Ceremony, cloathed the Bridegroom with a Surplice, and tyed him about the middle with a Girdle, putting upon his head a white Cloth.

In this manner he led him to the Bride, cau≈øing him to ≈øit by her: He then covered them
both with this white Cloth, and made them put their heads together. Then he anointed the Bridegroom with Oyl-Olive in the Forehead, and above the Fi≈øt, and the Bride in the ≈øame manner: Afterwards he cau≈øed them to give one another their hands, reading aloud the Exhortation that contains the Duties which they were to perform to one another. So with a long train of Prayers, interrupted with ≈øeveral Ceremonies, this Solemnity of Marriage ended, which they call the Coronation of the Married Couple.

Afterwards they read Morning-prayer, or as we call them, the Laudes. They ≈øung next Ma≈øs, where the Bridegroom and the Bride received the Communion; which being ended, they all returned to their ≈øeveral homes.

div.head: The beginning of the Year 1673.
div.p: THE night of the 16th of January, 1673. the Copties celebrate the Fe≈øtival of the Epiphany. I was then at Cairo in the Church of Mary Moncure, to ≈øee how they dip them≈øelves in Water in remembrance of the Bapti≈øm of our Lord and Saviour, which was performed that night according to the Traditions of the Church. I took notice of the≈øe Particulars.

They ≈øaid the Prayers of Midnight, where the Font ≈øtands, and where they dipped them≈øelves, which they call il Magtas. This Pond, or Ba≈øon: of Water is in a Chamber near the Church, about three Perches ≈øquare, as deep as a Man is high. As ≈øoon as Prayers were ended, the Patriarch went to the Kolomie, or Ve≈øtry, to put on his Pontifical
Attire; from thence he return'd to the Water, with a Deacon and a Prie≈øt before him. The Deacon had on him a Cape, bearing in his hand an Iron Cro≈øs, as long as a Pa≈øtoral Staff. The Prie≈øt was Cloathed with a Surplice, that he might be u≈øeful to the Patriarch in ≈øaying of Ma≈øs; that is, that he might be his a≈ø≈øi≈øtant, and Ma≈øter of the Ceremonies.

When he was come to the Water, he began to ble≈øs it, by reading over it ≈øeveral Le≈ø≈øons taken out of the Prophets and the P≈øalms, and out of the New Te≈øtament; ≈øometimes in the Copties Language, ≈øometimes in Arabick. The Patriarch perfum'd it al≈øo, and ≈øtirr'd it cro≈øs-wi≈øe with the Pa≈øtoral Staff of Iron, which the other Prie≈øts did al≈øo, every one in his turn. And whil≈øt they were ble≈ø≈øing this Water, which la≈øted near two hours, there was a Candle≈øtick of Iron ≈øtanding within, about the length of a Man, with three Branches, upon which there were three Tapers burning all the time of this Ceremony.

As ≈øoon as this ble≈ø≈øing was ended, the Pond, or Ba≈øon, was all uncovered, that the People might go in and dip them≈øelves. Then there was heard a ≈øtrange confu≈øion and noi≈øe, ≈øo great that I wonder'd; for every one endeavoured to be one of the three fir≈øt, whom the Patriarch dips in the Water. They that could not obtain this honour, dipp'd them≈øelves, skipping and playing, all naked, in the Water, without having any thing to cover their nakedne≈øs, and privy Members; and all this in the pre≈øence of their Patriarch, and many Prie≈øts that were there.

As ≈øoon as the Men had ended their wa≈øhing, and were gone to the Chancel; the Women, and
the Maids drew near, and followed the Mens Example, skipping all naked in the Water, and ≈øportting one with the other. It is true that ≈øuch as did thus dip them≈øelves were of the poorer ≈øort, and that as many as were of the wealthier, and better ≈øort, wa≈øh'd their faces and hands.
When the Women had ended their bathing, they went away to their own places to hear Ma≈øs, which was already begun.
Thus this Ceremony was performed, which I ≈øaw from the beginning to the end.

The 26th of this Month Mon≈øieur de Tyger, who had been, till then, Con≈øul of the French Nation, left Cairo. He is a very able Man, and under≈øtands his duty very well; but the Merchants of France made their complaints again≈øt him at Court, and caus'd him to be di≈ømi≈øs'd. Mon≈øieur de Bonnecor≈øe, the Cou≈øul of Seyda, was named in his place.

div.head: The departure of the Mahmel towards Mecha.
div.p: SAturday, the 28th of this Month, the Pacha ≈øent away, in great pomp, from Cairo, the Mahmel, or Burying-Cloath, which the Kings of Egypt, and the Pacha's are wont to ≈øend every Year to Mecha, to cover Mahomets Tomb; which was performed in this manner.

Fir≈øt two Ki≈øve, or Burying-Cloaths, of black Damask, richly wrought with great Arabick Letters, expre≈ø≈øing ≈øome Sentences of the Alcoran, were carried before. The≈øe Letters were very great, Embroidered with Gold, and artificially Interwoven.
The≈øe Burying-Cloaths were each carried upon a Bier, made almo≈øt in die ≈øame fa≈øhion as tho≈øe that are in Europe, and they were about three Perches long.

An infinite number of Schiechs, or Eccle≈øia≈øticks, followed after in a confu≈øion, cau≈øing ≈øeveral Banners to be carried before them, which had been taken out of the Mo≈øques of Cairo: Some were on foot, others riding upon A≈ø≈øes, and all cloathed in a very ≈øtrange manner, with Garbs made up with divers pieces of many colours patched together. They cau≈øed them≈øelves to be wondered at by their howling and grimaces, for they wagg'd their Heads, their Eyes, and their Mouths, in a thou≈øand ways; others pronounced the word Hu, which is one of the Attributes and Names of God, with all the ≈øtrength of their body; and there was none without Armour, a Club, or a Halberd, or a wooden Sword, or ≈øome other ru≈øty Weapon.

After this Crowd came the Cloth with which they cover Mahomets Tomb, which they call in Arabick, il Mahmel. It was carried upon a Camel painted yellow, with an Herb called Henne, and very richly harna≈ø≈øed and trapped with gold Embroidery, with feathers upon the Head, and about the Neck and Legs little Bells.

This Mahmel was made like a Bed, but the kind of Stuff, and the colour, was not to be di≈øtingui≈øh'd, becau≈øe it was all covered with Flowers, and Arabick Characters, very long, all Embroidered with Gold and Interwoven very artificially. At the four corners were four great Bo≈ø≈øes, covered over with a rich Stuff; and from the middle of the≈øe Bo≈ø≈øes, they ro≈øe up in Pyramides.

The Camel that carried this Engine, was followed by five others: Upon the fir≈øt was mounted an Arabian, ≈øounding a Trumpet; upon the ≈øecond a Moor that plaid upon two Cymbals; and upon the three others, three young Boys; after the≈øe went five and twenty Metferracas with their Swords by their ≈øides, and the Turban of the Chiaoux upon their heads; and after them ≈øeven other Per≈øons cloathed with Coftans: A Troop of Scherifs, or Noble Men of Mecha, followed next, on hor≈øeback; after them a Man who carried upon his head a little Mortuary, or Burying-Cloath, Embroidered, ≈øquare, ≈øtretched upon Staves; next went four others that carried every one upon their ≈øhoulders a Cloath of the ≈øame fa≈øhion. They told me, that they hanged them up where they celebrate the memory of Abrahams Sacrifice. Eight and twenty Jani≈ø≈øaries went next, two and two, with their Caps upon their heads. They went immediately before the Emir hag, or the Bey that commands this Caravan. This Bey was cloathed with a Coftan, and had upon his head a Turban, proper to the Beys, which is called in Arabick, Emame Ber≈øciani, which is like a Flowerpot turn'd up-≈øide down. His Dome≈øticks, who were twelve Archers well cloathed, and a Troop of Mu≈øqueteers on Hor≈øes, waited upon him; after followed the Drummers, the Trumpeters, the Pipers, either on Hor≈øeback, or riding upon Camels; and at la≈øt there was an Engine, drawn by the ≈øtrength of Men, upon which was repre≈øentented the Porch of the Temple of Mecha, in green Sattin Embroidered with Gold: They call it Arab. Burca.

The Money needful to make all the≈øe Cloaths,
is taken out of the Revenues of the Lands which the ancient Kings of Egypt have appointed for that purpo≈øe, which hath been confirmed by the Ottoman Emperours. For that purpo≈øe they have appointed a Superintendant, whom they call in Arabick Nadir il Ki≈øve, or the Superintendant of the Habit, who hath the care to cau≈øe the≈øe Lands to be Manur'd, and to gather the Revenues, and to employ them in the u≈øes for which they were appointed.

That which was worthy of notice in this Pomp, was the blind Devotion of the≈øe Wretches for the things which are to be u≈øed by their Prophet, or employed in their Religion. All the People, notwith≈øtanding the extraordinary crowd in all the Streets where the≈øe Cloaths were to pa≈øs, pre≈ø≈øed forward with incredible earne≈øtne≈øs, that they might cau≈øe their Handkerchiefs, or their Turbans, to touch the≈øe Cloaths that were de≈øigned for the Tomb of their Prophet, which they ki≈øs'd afterwards, and rubb'd them upon their Eyes with much devotion.

div.head: The Departure of the Caravan of the Pilgrims for Mecha.
div.p: EIght days after the Mahmel of the fal≈øe Prophet Mahomet was gone, the Bey went away al≈øo, with his Caravan, in this manner and order.

Fir≈øt ≈øix little Pieces of Artillery were drawn by Hor≈øes, with their Ammunition that followed next; after followed nine and forty Camels, loaden with Provi≈øions for the Bey, for his Kitchin; after them nine and fifty others that were
not loaden, and fourteen others that carried Water; after them two and twenty other Camels, well harne≈ø≈øed, but not loaden; eight and twenty Arabians march'd after them, every one of them had, upon his ≈øhoulder, a Torch, or Me≈øchal, to give light in the Night, before the Caravan: nine and forty Camels without burden, and two and twenty others loaden with two Cradles a-piece, to carry the ≈øick and weak, and the poor, went after: next to them went nineteen Camels loaden with Water-pouches; and before and after them there was a Troop of Moors that beat upon the Drum: after them followed twenty beautiful Camels, without burden; they belong's to a Lord. A Troop of Mu≈øitians, and eighteen Camels without burdens, the foremo≈øt bearing ≈øome Mu≈øitians, went next. Eight of the Field Tapers, called in Arabick, Me≈øchal, were carried after; and them the train of a Ciurbachi, well hor≈øed, ≈øucceeded: after went two and two Mu≈øitians, mounted upon Camels that went before another Camel with Trappings richly Embroidered; next a Troop of Drummers rode by upon Camels; and after them three Camels, bearing in their Saddles many Colours flying, that yielded a beautiful ≈øight; Twelve Moors carried next twelve Torches; next went twelve Camels loaden with Water-pouches; ≈øome Ciurbachies rode next on hor≈øeback, followed by two Camels that carried two Mu≈øitians, and ≈øix and twenty others loaden with Banners, as the former; between the≈øe, and two others that were loaden with Water, went two Men that carried Tapers; two Camels loaden followed after, with the Train of a Lord on hor≈øeback, two Drums, and nine Camels; and after them ≈øome
Ciurbachies, with their Servants, on hor≈øeback; after went the ≈øeven orders of the Militia, and the Alai Chiaoux, who are to be di≈øtingui≈øhed by their black Rod which they bear in their hands, which hath two Branches hooked, upon which hang two Silver Chains, furni≈øh'd with little Bell, tied at the middle of the Rod: next followed the Servants, and Attendants of a Lord, all riding on Hor≈øes. The Imam, or Chaplain, of the Emir-hag, cloathed in white Searge, followed them upon a Camel; after him went a Troop of young Men, mounted upon Camels; next went the Attendants of a Lord, and a Troop of Jani≈ø≈øaries on foot, with their Ceremonial Caps on their heads; next followed their Serdar, or Colonel, with forty Chiaoux, two and two on hor≈øeback, with their Swords by their ≈øides: twelve Sangiac-Beys went after, two and two, on Hor≈øes, with their Ceremonial Turbans on their heads, with their Servants: next eight Chiaoux, and a Bey all alone, and the Vali, or Provo≈øt Mar≈øhal, with the Methte≈øib, or Superintendant of the Provi≈øions, on Hor≈øes: they had after them a thou≈øand Azappes on foot, walking two and two: the Apprentices were at the head of their Troop, having a little Mu≈øquet on their ≈øhoulders, and a Cutla≈øs at their ≈øides: the young Men without Beard followed them; next the Men of full age; next the old Men, all cloathed with skins of Tygers: after them a thou≈øand Jani≈ø≈øaries went on foot, in the ≈øame order and at the la≈øt the Emir-hag, or the Bey that commanded this Caravan, clo≈øed up the rear of thi ‚Ä¢ Company, on hor≈øeback.

We mu≈øt not think that all the≈øe Per≈øons go with the Bey as far as Mecha: They accompany
him a little way out of Town, as far as the Caravan hath a Rendezvous; none remain, but ≈øuch as are bound to go through with him.

div.head: A Voyage into the Upper Egypt.
div.p: ON the 24th of February, being Friday, S. Matthias's day, I went from Cairo towards the ∆≤pper Egypt, with an intention to vi≈øit the Mona≈øtery of the Holy Martyrs at I≈øne, and the other Antiquities that are about that City.

Be≈øides Idris my Man, I took along with me a Moor, called Hagali, our near Neighbour, to accompany me. We went aboard of a Bark that I had hired to carry us to Momfallot, for five and twenty Paras. The Vi≈øiter of the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe cau≈øed us to ≈øtop till the Evening; ≈øo that this night we only went round about the I≈øle Roude, which is at a Musket-≈øhot over again≈øt Old Cairo.

Saturday the Rain fell betimes, and la≈øted till Noon; the Showers fell ≈øo furiou≈øly, that our Bark ≈øunk almo≈øt to the bottom: I wi≈øh'd then that ≈øuch as ≈øay that no Rain falls in Egypt had been there, for they would have ≈øeen the contrary. This Rain was ≈øucceeded by cold and tempe≈øtuous Winds.

The next night there was another Rain fell as great as the former, which continued till three hours after the ri≈øing of the Sun. As ≈øoon as it had di≈ø≈øipated the Clouds, a good Wind, called Teijab, or North-we≈øt, began to blow, and kept us company in all our Voyage.

Monday, very early, the 27th of the Month, we landed at Bene≈øuef, a great Town ≈øcituated
upon the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, and tow hours after we went on board, to proceed on in our Voyage, leaving at our right hand, on the We≈øt of the River, Fe≈øohn, a great Town, about three or four hours travelling from Bene≈øuef, towards the South: At the Ea≈øt we ≈øaw the Village Savadi Kedami, and about Sun-≈øet we went by Heggiar Selame, a dangerous Bank of Nilus. At this place the Lands of Egypt, which are at the Ea≈øt of Nilus, begin to be manured, for from Cairo to this place, they are all cover'd with Sand.

Tue≈øday morning, the 28th of February, we left at the Ea≈øt of Nilus two Ca≈øtles ruinated, near one another, and pa≈øs'd by the Mountain called Gebel-garanat, ≈øcituate on the ≈øame ≈øide, where the Territory of Egypt begins again to be unfruitful and ≈øandy.

A little before Noon we ≈øaw our ≈øelves over again≈øt Serarie, a Village on the Ea≈øt of Nilus, but within the Land, ≈øeated at the foot of this Mountain. In this place our Bark ran in the Sand, and when the Boat-men were not able to free her, the Jani≈ø≈øaries that were with us forced all the other Travellers and Chri≈øtians with Cudgels to leap over into the water to help them.

As ≈øoon as it was freed, we proceeded on in our way, and we began to di≈øcover the Caves of the Mountain which are at the Ea≈øt of Nilus, and a little after the Mount of Birds, called in Arabick Gebel Teir, which is ≈øo equal from the top to the bottom about half a mile, that it looks like a ≈øtrait Wall, built by hand, rather than a Rock made thus by Nature, which is a very delightful ≈øight to Travellers. The water of Nilus wa≈øhes a great deal of it: On the top of this Mountain
is the Mona≈øtery of the Copties, called Deir il baccur, and a little further ≈øeveral Caves, and the ruines if an Ancient Town.
Tue≈øday night we were in ≈øight of Minie, but our Ve≈ø≈øel ran a-ground once more in the Banks of Sand, ≈øo that the Boat-men could not free it before night, and there it ≈øtopt till next day.

Wedne≈øday in the morning, whiles our Boat-men were bu≈øie in freeing the Boat, I went to ≈øee the City of Minie, ≈øcituate on the We≈øt of Nilus, belonging to the Ca≈øcieflik of Behne≈øe. I went al≈øo into the Mo≈øques without fear, becau≈øe I was cloathed in a Turki≈øh Habit. When our Boat-men had freed the Bark, they drew her up to Minie, for we ≈øail'd upwards; there I went on board to go towards Melave.

About an hours ≈øailing from Minie, we began to di≈øcover on the top of the Mountain, which lies at the Ea≈øt, the Caves. This, in my judgment, is the beginning of the Country of Thebes: They are to be ≈øeen along the Mountain, as far as Momfallot; I counted four and thirty in a rank, but the Mouths of the Caves were ≈øtopped up with Earth that was fallen in.
The ≈øame day, about three a Clock in the Afternoon, we pa≈øs'd by the Ruines of the Ancient City In≈øine, leaving it at our left hand, and at night we went to lie before Melave.

We ≈øailed away on Thur≈øday morning, the ≈øecond of March, and we ≈øaw in our way many Caves in the Mountain, which is at the Ea≈øt. At Noon we left the great Channel of Nilus, becau≈øe there was but little water, and we enter'd into one of its Branches, which makes an I≈øland, by meeting again with the great Stream. We pa≈øs'd
before the Mouth of the River of Jo≈øeph, of which I have ≈øpoken ≈øufficiently in the de≈øcription of Fium.

Friday morning, the third day of the month, we landed at Momfallot, where I lodged in an Hou≈øe called Ocalet Emir Otman, or the dwelling of Prince Otman, which is in the Marketplace. It is an old dwelling much decayed, and though there is another more beautiful, and more commodious, I would not lodge in it, that I might not ≈øuffer the affronts of the Jam≈ø≈øaries and Spahins, who lodg'd there, and who would have in≈øulted over me, had they known me to be a Franc.

Momfallot, the abode of the Ca≈øcief of the Province, is a very great and beautiful Town of Egypt, ≈øcituate upon the banks of Nilus, on the We≈øt-≈øide, in the middle Egypt. There is made much Linen-cloth: A great many Chri≈øtian Copties live here, but they have no Church.

The name of this Town ≈øignifies in Arabick the Exile of Lot, becau≈øe a certain Lot was bani≈øh'd thither by his Brother, an ancient King of Egypt, as the Copties ≈øay. Over again≈øt, on the other ≈øide of Nilus, are the ≈øigns of an ancient Town, I could never under≈øtand the name.

From Cairo to Bene≈øuef there are two days journeys by Land; and by water, ≈øometimes more, ≈øometimes le≈øs, according to the wind; from Bene≈øuef to Minie, are three days journeys by Land, from Minie to Melave is a little days journey, from Melave to Momfallot is a little more than a days journey, chiefly when the Hor≈øe is not good; and from Momfallot one may go and dine at Siut, if one takes the morning.

In the Province of Momfallot they reckon one and fifty Towns, ≈øix and thirty at the We≈øt ≈øide of Nilus, and fifteen at the Ea≈øt; which agrees not with the Relation of James Albert of Egypt, who reckons up two hundred and ≈øeventeen. In this he is mi≈øtaken. Here are one and twenty Churches, or Mona≈øteries; eleven at the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, namely Moharrak, with that of the Aby≈ø≈øins, near by. The Church of the Angel Gabriel, at Buk: That of S. Theodore at Tim≈øahte: That of S. George at Ballot: That of the Arch-Angel Raphael at Tetelie: That of S. Philothea at Nemire: That of the Arch-Angels, Gabriel and Raphael, at Benekelb: That of S. Mercurius at Gauli: That of the holy Virgin at Mee≈ø≈øera: That of S. John of Heraclea at Om il Ko≈ø≈øur.

There are twelve at the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, namely, the Church of S. Theodore, Martyr, S. John's Son, at Bo≈ø≈øra: The Mona≈øtery of S. Menna, ≈øirnamed Thoumatourgos at ‚Äî The Church of the holy Virgin at ‚Äî and another at Maabde: The Church of Mary Poctor at Gebravi; another of the ≈øame Saint at Fadda: That of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin at Bene mohammed: That of S. George at Bene morr: and three that are at Ibnub il hammam; namely, the Mona≈øtery of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin: the Church of S. John the Bapti≈øt, and that of Abufam il ghindi.
The 7th day of this Month I went, about ≈øeven a Clock in the morning, for Siut, where I arrived about noon.

The≈øe are the Villages in the way; 1. Mandara, where ≈øeveral Ruines remain, that be≈øpeak it to have been a great Town: 2. Hantaca: 3. Gauli, where are to be ≈øeen ≈øome ancient
Ruines, and an old Bridge, to give pa≈ø≈øage to the River Nilus, when it overflows the Country: 4. Negghe, where the Caravan commonly re≈øts that comes from Dungala, when it goes towards Cairo: 5. Beneh≈øein, and a little further Coum Beneh≈øein, where is to be ≈øeen the Tomb of one called Sciech I≈øcander: 6. Mongabat that new, which is a very good Town, at the We≈øt of Nilus, and at the foot of the Mountain hard by old Mongabat, but now ruinated: At la≈øt we came to Siut, which lies South-South-Ea≈øt from Momfallot.

When I was arrived at Siut, I took two Chambers in the Hou≈øe called Occalet il hammam, or the Bathing-hou≈øe; ≈øo named, becau≈øe it is over again≈øt a Publick Bathe; and though it be but little, it is plea≈øant and commodious.

A few days after, I craved acquaintance with the Bi≈øhop of the City, called Amba Joannes; he is a very hone≈øt Man, of a good life. He made me know a certain Coptie, named Muallim Athana≈øius, the only Man of all the upper Egypt that under≈øtood his natural Tongue, that is, the Copties; but I could not benefit my ≈øelf much by him, becau≈øe he was deaf, and about four≈øcore years of age: neverthele≈øs I had the ≈øatisfaction to behold that Man, with whom the Copties Language will be utterly loft.

Siut, called in Greek Lycopolis, is one of the mo≈øt famous Towns of the Upper Egypt, ≈øcituate at the foot of a barren Mountain that ≈øtands on the We≈øt-≈øide, about half a league from Nilus. The Town is great and populous, full of Chri≈øtian Copties, who may be about five hundred Caraches, or Ma≈øters of Families that pay Tribute. They have there a Bi≈øhop, and a poor Church dedicated
to the Abbot Der, who≈øe Body, with that of his Si≈øter Erazi, a reputed Saint, with his Brother al≈øo, re≈øts at Em≈øciul, which is a Village belonging to I≈øchmunein. In Siut are wrought the be≈øt Linen Cloaths of all Egyppt. It is the chief Town of the Province, and the abode of a Ca≈øcief.
The≈øe are the Churches and Mona≈øteries of Chri≈øtian Copties that are in this Province.

The Church of Doronke, dedicated to the three Children of Babylon ca≈øt into the Furnace. The Mona≈øtery of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, ≈øcituate upon a Mountain that is behind this Village. The Church of Rife, dedicated to Mary Colte. The Mona≈øtery of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, behind this Village, upon the ≈øame Mountain. That of Sauvie, dedicated to Athana≈øius. The Church of Doveine, dedicated to S. John the Bapti≈øt; but now there is nothing remaining of this Church, but the Altar in the open Air. The Church of Bagur, dedicated to S. Claudius. That of Cateia, dedicated to S. Philothea. That of Sciothe, dedicated to S. Moncure; but it is now ruinated.

Upon the Mountain that is near Siut, on the We≈øt-≈øide, among≈øt a great many Caves cut in the Rock, there is one made like a Stable, therefore the People call it by the name of il Stabl, or the Stable: It is ≈øo large that a thou≈øand Hor≈øe-men may ea≈øily draw up Battel in it. I have not ≈øeen it, though I had a great de≈øire; for no body would venture to lead me thither, for fear of the Ca≈øciefs di≈øplea≈øure, who is afraid that ≈øome body ≈øhould carry away the Trea≈øures that are ≈øaid to be hid there.

div.head: A Voyage to Tahta.
div.p: M∆≤nday, the 13th of this Month, I went from Siut with the Bi≈øhop of the Town, leaving my Men till my return, for Tahta; which is another City of the Upper Egypt, about two little days Journey from Siut, towards the South.

At our left hand we left the Ruines of the ancient Town, Scioth, named by the Copties
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ : next Rife, a con≈øiderable Town at our right hand: next Mu≈øcie, where the Copties had anciently a Church, dedicated to Mary Poctor Sciu, taking its name from the City of Sciu, which was next to Abnub, but now ruinated. At three of the Clock in the Afternoon we arrived at Doveine, where we continued two days, becau≈øe the Bi≈øhop of Sciut was to con≈øecrate there an Altar.
This Village owes its beginning to Tuh Bekerim, a Village near adjoining, whereof there appears not now the lea≈øt ≈øign: This is the cau≈øe.

A Gentlewoman of this place, called ∆≤deine, having built a Church out of Tuh Bekerim, to the honour of S. John Bapti≈øt: many of the Inhabitants cau≈øed Hou≈øes to be built near this Church; ≈øo by degrees, the number of People increa≈øing more and more, they left Tuh Bekerim empty, and the place where this Church was built became a Village, which they called after the name of the Gentlewoman,
∆≤deine, and now corruptly Doveine.

This Church was afterwards overthrown by the Doveider, a Branch of Nilus artificially made, which wa≈øhed the Walls; now there remains nothing but the Altar, upon which the Bi≈øhop ≈øays Ma≈øs after a re-con≈øecration.

Over again≈øt Doveine, upon the ≈øide of the Mountain, We≈øterly, there are to be ≈øeen the Relicks of two ancient Towns; one was named Bablu, and the other Billu; they are near together. I had an intent to ≈øee them, but the Bi≈øhop of Siut di≈ø≈øwaded me.

Wedne≈øday, the 15th of this Month, we went from Doveine towards Tahta, near the Ruines of the ancient Town Abutig, called by the Copties
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øcituate upon the Banks of Nilus; there is a Ca≈øcief dwells there. 2. We pa≈ø≈øed by Necheile, a Village upon the ≈øide of the ≈øame River, where were a great many Copties. 3. The Ruines of the ancient Town Sitfe, called in the Arabian Books Sedafe. 4. The Ruines of Amba Bi≈øcioi. 5. Other Mountains of Ruines, called Kimam Selamun, which we left at our right hand. 6. Temeh, which was anciently a Town, but now is but a poor Village. The Chri≈øtian Copties that live here, make a certain ≈øort of black Searge, indifferent ≈øine, which Per≈øons of Quality, and the Clergy of the Copties wear. Out of the Town they have a Church, dedicated to Amba Fam il Au≈ø≈øimi, or to the Abbot Fam of An≈ø≈øim; but it is pitiful. There is in this Village a Ca≈øcief.

When we had well re≈øted our ≈øelves at Temeh, in the Hou≈øe of a poor Chri≈øtian, we went on our way, pa≈ø≈øing fir≈øt by a Village called Coum il arab, over again≈øt Kau il Kubbara, which is at the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, anciently a very beautiful Town, called by the Copties
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , where the Bi≈øhop of Siut told me is yet to be ≈øeen the Ruines of a beautiful Church of the ancient Egyptians. We went next to Me≈øchta, a pretty good Town, and next
to Sciahrota; afterwards we went upon Mountains of Ruines of a Town called Abvaitg: Next night we lay at Sciech zein Iddin, a poor Village, inhabited by Copties and Moors, very mi≈øerable.

Thur≈øday morning, the 16th of the Month, the day ob≈øerved by the Copties in remembrance of the Invention of the holy Cro≈øs, we went to Nezelet i≈ø≈øciehid, a little Village full of Coptier, all Dyers. Heretofore in this place was a Church, dedicated to S. Cyriack; but it is now down, and there remains nothing but the Altar in the open Air.

This day the Bi≈øhop of Siut made ≈øome young Men Deacons, and when Ma≈øs, and the Ordination was ended, we went to Tahta, a great Town near to this Village, where we lodged at the Hou≈øe of one Muallim Petrus, a Coptie, an hone≈øt, and rich Man.

div.head: A Voyage to the White Mona≈øtery.
div.p: SAturday, the 18th of this Month, I went very early from Tahta, towards the famous Mona≈øtery of S. Sennodius, ≈øirnamed the White, about a good days Journey from Tahta. The Bi≈øhop of Siut gave me one of his Arabians, named Havaras, to guide me.

At the going out of the Town I met with a kind of a Jani≈ø≈øary, called Seimen, who received no Sallary from the Grand Seignior, but lived by the orders of the Ca≈øciefs; he was ≈øitting in the Highway, where we were to pa≈øs, his Mu≈øquet upon his ≈øhoulder, a Cutla≈øs at his ≈øide, and ready to march.

When we drew near him, he came to us, and ≈øtopt me bluntly, telling me that I mu≈øt alight. I was much ≈øurpri≈øed with this affront, and vexed that without cau≈øe I was to lo≈øe my Bea≈øt, I ≈øeem'd to be re≈øolved not to alight; we continued a pretty while to di≈øpute together, till I ≈øaw him lift up his Hatchet, which he wore at his Girdle, to cleave my head in two, and that my Arabian look'd idly upon us, as unconcern'd, I was forced to yield him my A≈øs; upon which he got immediately, and rode away.

I returned to the Town, on foot, to the Bi≈øhop, who under≈øtanding my misfortune, cau≈øed another to be given me. I went on in my way, and at our going out of Tahta, we pa≈øs'd by the Ruines of the ancient Town of Beneviet; we le≈øt at our left hand other ≈øigns of an ancient Town, called Po≈øone; from thence we pa≈øs'd to Sciendavil, a good Town, and at noon we got as far as Gezire, which is a Town where the Ca≈øcief of the Province lives; when we had a little re≈øted our ≈øelves in a Coffee-hou≈øe, we went on our way towards the Mona≈øtery, leaving the way of Sohaitg, which we had kept till then; we turned to the right hand, towards the Mountain which is on the We≈øt of the Town, we went by Itfu, an ancient Town, called by the Copties
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ; about noon we got to the Mona≈øtery, where we lodg'd at night.

The Mona≈øtery of S. Sennodius, the Archimandrite, ≈øirnamed the White, is built near the Ruines of the ancient Town Adribe. There are the Remains of one of the mo≈øt Magnificent Structures that hath been in Egypt. It is four≈øquare; its Walls are builded with hewn Stones, very
white; every Stone is four foot long, and a foot and three inches high. It is ≈øeven and thirty Perches and two foot long, which make two hundred and twenty four foot, and eighteen Perches and three foot broad, which make one hundred and eleven foot. There be ≈øix great Gates of a red Stone, which now are walled up, one only excepted, which now hath an open place as high as a Man. The chief Gate that is walled up is now called Bab il bagl, or the Mules Gate, in remembrance of what happen'd to a Daughter of an Heathen King, who offered to go into the Church in contempt, riding upon a Mule, and was ≈øwallowed up alive in a Pit that opened, to puni≈øh her in≈øolency; which Miracle happen'd by the Prayers of S. Sennodius, who begg'd this puni≈øhment from God. This Gate is ten foot high, and ≈øix broad; every one of the Supporters is made up with four great Marble Stones, as well as the Lintil, upon which is graven three Cro≈ø≈øes, one great in the middle, and two little ones on the ≈øides.

Round about the Building are two ranks of Windows, the lowe≈øt are in the middle, and the others almo≈øt touch the top. The two longe≈øt ≈øides of the Building have each ≈øeven and twenty Windows in each Rank, and the ≈øhorter ≈øides each have nine in each rank, but all the≈øe Windows are walled up.

The in≈øide of this Mona≈øtery is demolli≈øhed, the Heikel excepted, where Ma≈øs is ≈øaid, and the middle. The body of the Church, called by the Copties Giamelun, was heretofore ≈øupported with two ranks of Pillars, each having fourteen; which are yet ≈øtanding, but in the open Air; for the Vault is fallen down.

All the Pillars are not of the ≈øame Stone, nor Workman≈øhip, nor bigne≈øs, nor height; for ≈øome are rea≈øonably big, others are ≈ølenderer. And to ≈øuch as are ≈ømall, they have clapt ≈øome Plai≈øter, to make them as big as the others.

At the going in of the Chancel are to be ≈øeen two very beautiful Pillars of Marble, at the entry of the Heikel. Upon that which ≈øtands at the left hand is graven an Epitaph in Greek, of one named Heliodorus. The≈øe Pillars are yet entire, and their Workman≈øhip is very beautiful.

Almo≈øt every where in the Walls of the Mona≈øtery, in the Pavement that is before the Chancel, and in the great and beautiful pair of Stairs that lead up to the Sleeping-place of the Monks, are certain great Stones full of Cyphers and Hieroglyphick Figures placed not right; by which we may under≈øtand, that tho≈øe that have put them there had no knowledge of this my≈øterious Tongue. In the Walls within are ≈øix holes in each ≈øide, vaulted above, and curiou≈øly adorned with carved Leaves, ≈øo hand≈øomly wrought that I could not ≈øufficiently admire the Workman≈øhip. Round about the Mona≈øtery there is much black Marble.

In one of the Apartments of the Mona≈øtery, towards the We≈øt, at the left hand as one goes in, there is a large and deep Well. The Monks told me that the Water was forty Cubits deep, and that it had been ≈øanctified, or ble≈øs'd, by our Saviour. It is very ≈øweet and whole≈øome, and ri≈øes and falls with Nilus, though it hath no communication with this River.

The next day in the morning, being Sunday, and the ninth day of the Month, after Ma≈øs, I went,
with my Arabian, towards Red Mona≈øtery, about an hours travelling from the White, at the foot of the ≈øame Mountain, towards Tahta.

The colour of the Bricks with which this Mona≈øtery is built, hath given it the name of Red. It is built in the ≈øame manner as the White, but a great deal le≈øs. At the South-≈øide it hath yet a Building ≈øtanding, that was cre≈øted, as the Monks ≈øay, by S. Helene, when ≈øhe went to I≈øne to vi≈øit the bodies of the holy Martyrs. It was intended to inclo≈øe the Well of the Mona≈øtery within the Walls, and to hinder the Arabians, when they made in roads from their Mountains, from troubling the Monks, or taking away from them the Water.

There remains nothing of this Church, but the Chancel, and the Heikel, or place where Ma≈øs is read. The Pillars that kept up the body of the Church are yet ≈øtanding, all of an equal length and bigne≈øs. In this particular they excell tho≈øe of the White Mona≈øtery, as well as in the beauty of the Workman≈øhip, e≈øpecially their Capitals.

The Builders of this Mona≈øtery was Amba Bi≈øcioi, who having a long time liv'd as a Robber, as the Story of his Life ≈øaith, at la≈øt he repented and ended his days very well. Some told me, that the Club with which he us'd to knock down Pa≈ø≈øengers is hung up in the Chancel of this Church. I ≈øaw it not, becau≈øe I was told of it after I was gone out of the Mona≈øtery.
There is a Pillar al≈øo at each ≈øide of the Door of the Heikel, of an excellent Workman≈øhip, e≈øpecially their Capitals, which are the mo≈øt beautiful that I ever beheld.
But this Mona≈øtery, as well as the White, is altogether ruinated within.
When I had ≈øeen all that was worthy of notice, I return'd to Tahta, where I arriv'd, about noon, the 21th of the month, and the next day we went to Siut.

A few days after, I went with the Bi≈øhop of Siut to the Mona≈øtery of S. Athana≈øius, which is about three hours travelling from thence, I fancied to ≈øee there ≈øome rare Reliques of Antiquity, but I was deceiv'd; for I ≈øaw that it was one of the mo≈øt woful Mona≈øteries in Egypt, ≈øo that I ≈øhall not mention it any more.
In our way to this Mona≈øtery, we ≈øaw that of the Virgin at Doronque, ≈øcituate upon the Mountain that ≈øtands at the right hand.

This Mona≈øtery, with its Church, are cut in the Rock; which is the only thing there to be noted. All the re≈øt was ≈øo far from ≈øatisfying my Curio≈øity, that I beheld nothing but Ruines and mi≈øery.

But that I might not lo≈øe, altogether, my labour, in climbing up to the Mountain, I went to ≈øee the Caves that were near. My Guide led me into one as high as a Man on hor≈øeback, ≈øo extraordinary large, that without hyperbole a thou≈øand Hor≈øe might there draw up in Battel array, which cau≈øed me to wonder not a little.

As ≈øoon as we were out of this large Cave, my Guide led me into another hard by, larger than the former: when I was within about two hundred paces, he told me to hearken to a certain place of the Wall, at the left hand as one goes in. U≈øe no doubt had made him take notice of this place; for I ≈øaw no ≈øign outward to cau≈øe one to mind it. I drew near to li≈øten, and I heard behind the Wall, the noi≈øe as of a Wind-mill, ≈øo di≈øtinct that I marvelled greatly, only the noi≈øe
≈øeem'd to come from far. I wonder'd the more, when he told me that behind this Rock there was no empty place, nor pa≈ø≈øage, for the Air to make this noi≈øe, which has continued during the memory of Man. All Per≈øons of whom I inquir'd for the cau≈øe of this Wonder, told me nothing el≈øe, but that it was a Tali≈øman, and that there was ≈øome hidden Trea≈øure.

A little further, towards the South, upon the ≈øame Mountain, are to be ≈øeen the Ruines of an ancient Mona≈øtery, dedicated to S. Severus, Patriarch of Antioch, whom the Copties reverence as a Saint, becau≈øe he maintain'd the Doctrine of Dio≈øcorus their Patriarch, who≈øe opinions they follow. The Bi≈øhop of Siut told me, that heretofore three hundred and three≈øcore Monks inhabited in this Mona≈øtery, who employed them≈øelves in ≈øeeking for the Philo≈øopher Stone, and in the works of Chymi≈øtry; an excellent Employment for ≈øuch as have left the World, and for≈øaken their Riches.

div.head: My return from Siut to Momfallot.
div.p:
THE 26th of March I return'd to Momfallot, with an intent to take Boat for Girge, and continue my Travels farther. I enter'd into the Town about noon; as ≈øoon as I was in my former Lodging, a Man of my acquaintance gave me notice that the Chri≈øtians of that place, tho≈øe very Per≈øons to whom I had been recommended by their Patriarch, had accu≈øed me to the Ca≈øcief, and told him that I was a rich Franc, who made it my bu≈øine≈øs to run up and down the Land, to di≈øcover
where the Trea≈øures were hid, to inform the King of France, who intended to come and Conquer Egypt. This Friend ≈øaid al≈øo that the Ca≈øcief had commanded to take me, where ever I ≈øhould be found.

This wicked news made me think upon a retreat, and at that time there was no conveniency to go by Water to Girge, and becau≈øe the Ca≈øcief might have ≈øooner taken me on that ≈øide, his Juri≈ødiction reaching a great way; I went back to Melave, becau≈øe his Dominion was but narrow thitherward. I took that way to return to Cairo, the place of my ordinary abode, whither I went by Land; for I had been by Water before.

At our going out of Momfallot we went by Om il Co≈ø≈øur, a Village, where great Mountains of Ruines are to he ≈øeen. We left next at our left hand, the ≈øigns of the ancient Town Co≈ø≈øie, which is called by the Greek Authors Apollonopolis. We went by Sennabo next, which is a very good and populous Town. We ≈øaw Biblau, Bamib, and after Sun ≈øet we came to Tarut I≈ø≈øcerif, a great Village, where we were entertained gratis by an Arabian Lord, who keeps an Hou≈øe of Ho≈øpitality, called in that Tongue Beit diafe, to lodge Strangers, that will ≈øtay there a night, with their Bea≈øts. He entertains them at his own charge.

The next day, the 28th of the Month, after that I had returned thanks to my Benefactor, I went ≈øtreight to Melave. At our going out of Tarut I≈ø≈øcerif, I went through the Channel of Jo≈øeph's River on foot, for there it begins. I went next to Tanuf, a Village, where ≈øome Ruines are yet to be ≈øeen; and about noon we were at Melave, where I lodged at the Occale, or Inn, that is near the
Market-place, at the We≈øt-≈øide of the Town, near the great Mo≈øque; and becau≈øe the upper Chambers were all taken up by Turks, I was obliged to lodge in a very low Room, where I met with many inconveniences, becau≈øe it was near the Door, at the pa≈ø≈øage of all comers and goers.

Wedne≈øday, the 29th of the Month, the Turks begin the Fea≈øt called Eid il dehie, or the Ea≈øter of the Victims; for they u≈øe to kill Sheep during this Fe≈øtival, and give the Fle≈øh to the Poor for Gods ≈øake. This Fe≈øtival continues three days, during which time the Copties buy no Victuals from the Mahometans, nor Bread, Wine, Fle≈øh, Coffee, nor Water. By this they di≈øcover their abhorrency of that Religion; for thereby they ≈øhun all occa≈øions of communicating with them.

At Melave I got acquaintance with an Arch-Prie≈øt of that place, called Na≈ø≈ør alla. He was the hone≈øte≈øt, civile≈øt, and able≈øt Man that I ever knew of that Nation. There are about ≈øeven hundred Caraches, or Heads, that pay Tribute. They have there a Church, dedicaced to S. Michael, which is but little, poor, and ob≈øcure.

The River Nilus ≈øwallowed up heretofore the ancient Melave, and now the River runs in the place where that Town ≈øtood. The Town now is built in another place, where was anciently a Wood that was a retreat for Robbers.

div.head: A Voyage into the Lower Thebes.
div.p:
I Was loth to return to Cairo without ≈øeeing the Country of the Lower Thebes, or at lea≈øt a part of it, ≈øeeing that I was ≈øo near it; I re≈øolved therefore to follow the advice of my Friend,
the Arch-Prie≈øt, and to go to the Mona≈øtery of Abuhennis il Ke≈ø≈øir, or of S. John the little, whereof he was Governour, ≈øcituate near the ancient Town In≈øine, on the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, about an hours travelling from Melave, to ≈øee the Rarities thereabouts.

Saturday, the fir≈øt of April, I went from Melave to this Mona≈øtery; and the next day, being our Ea≈øter-Sunday, I got a Guide to lead me upon the Mountain, which is behind, on the Ea≈øt-≈øide, to ≈øee the Caves of the ancient Hermites that are round about, and near to the Town, which have given to it the name of Thebes, as we ≈øhall ≈øee in the following di≈øcour≈øe.

I went into many of the≈øe Caves that were all very large. I ≈øaw nothing worthy of notice, but in ≈øome certain Cro≈ø≈øes graven in the Rock; and upon the Walls of one I ≈øaw two Angels, holding up with their hands a Cro≈øs in the Air.

The only thing that pleas'd me among the≈øe Caves, was a Mona≈øtery, with a Church, all cut in a firm Rock. The Vault of the Church was ≈ømooth, and the Paving very even. The Walls were painted in an antick fa≈øhion, with the Hi≈øtories of the New Te≈øtament, with Images of Hermites, and Saints, who≈øe names were written underneath in Coptick Letters.
