At the end of the Church, Southward, I ≈øaw a Cro≈øs cut in the Rock, with a Greek In≈øcription, in ancient Characters. And upon the Walls of another Cave, at a little di≈øtance from this Church, and higher, about the top of the Mountain, I ≈øound al≈øo another graven upon the Wall; and near this, two others, which are all Epitaphs of Abbots there Interr'd. I could not cau≈øe them to be put here,
becau≈øe the Printer would not be at the charge of the Characters.
April the third, being Monday in Ea≈øter Week, I went to the ancient Town of In≈øine, called in the Copties Dictionaries Antinoe, and Thebes.

I went to ≈øee fir≈øt the Tomb of Mahomet Bey, a Bey of Girge, about fourteen years ago. When he took arms again≈øt Pacha Gaze, he was defeated at Melave, and his men for≈øook him; he was taken and ≈øtrangled. His Tomb is out of the City in the common burying place, and though there is nothing there extraordinary, I was de≈øirous to ≈øee it, becau≈øe he hath been, and is yet in great reputation among≈øt the Inhabitants for his Ju≈øtice and good Government, which hath cau≈øed him to be lamented by all the ∆≤pper Egypt.

When I had ≈øeen this Tomb, I walked into the Town, and the fir≈øt thing that I took notice of, as a great Antiquity, was the Pillar of Marcus Aurelius. Its bottom is above five foot, the four uppermo≈øt are all even, and the fifth below is adorned with carved leaves. In the Ba≈øis is a Greek In≈øcription containing thirteen lines.
I ≈øaw near this Pillar the pieces of three others, very much re≈øembling this, but broken down; there was nothing of them ≈øtanding but the Ba≈øis of one.

From the Pillar I went to ≈øee the Arch of Triumph, which is almo≈øt all ≈øtanding. I took a delight to climb up to it by a little pair of Stairs winding up in the Wall of the Arch, containing fifty ≈øteps, or thereabouts. I re≈øted my ≈øelf at the greate≈øt Window which is upon the chief Vault, where I had the ≈øatisfaction to di≈øcover all its ruines, and the ≈øcituation of this Town, heretofore ≈øo famous.

This Arch is alone, and altogether ≈øeparated from the other Ruines, and about four paces from the River Nilus; but for want of an In≈øcription, none knows for whom, and by whom it hath been rais'd. It is not inrich'd with carved Works, as tho≈øe of Orange and Rome; neverthele≈øs it is one of the mo≈øt beautiful that I have ever ≈øeen.

One of its fronts hath eight and forty foot in breadth, and one of its ≈øides four and twenty. The great Vault in the middle, which is between two little ones, is about 16 foot broad, and each of the two little ones ≈øeven foot. The thickne≈øs of the Wall which is between the great and the little Vaults, which is but one ≈øtone, is of ≈øix foot and two inches: The thickne≈øs which is between the little Vault, and the outward Angle of the Arch, is of five foot: The front that looks towards Nilus, is on the South-Ea≈øt ≈øide.

There is yet fourteen Pillars of Marble on the left hand of this Arch, in a ≈øtreight line towards the River; ≈øome of them have their Capitals, others have lo≈øt them; ≈øome are joyned to the Huts of ≈øome Arabians that dwell there. On the ≈øame ≈øide, towards the Mona≈øtery of Abuhennis, are to be ≈øeen three beautiful Pillars of Porphyry ≈øtanding; ≈øome of them have their tops; a fourth lies along the ground near by.

In the Mo≈øque of this Town is a Sciech, or Saint, whom the Arabians call Sciech Abade, for whom they have a great Veneration, for they believe him to have been a Mahometan; but they are much deceived, he was a Chri≈øtian, a Bi≈øhop of I≈øne, he ≈øuffered Martyrdom at I≈øne. They have called him Sciech Abade, by an error which the Sir-name of this Bi≈øhop hath cau≈øed. He was called
Ammonius il Abed, or the devout Ammonius. The Arabians, through a mi≈øtake of the word Abed, making it a proper name, whereas it is but an appellative, have called him Sciech Abade. His Reliques are kept in the Heikel of this Church, which now is a Mo≈øque.

I went afterwards to take a view of a magnificent Palace, called by the Arabians Abulkerun, or the horned Building, becau≈øe, as I think, the Pillars that are before this Palace have Capitals, whereof the Angles are ≈øo great, that they appear as ≈øo many Horns to the beholders, which the word Kern ≈øignifies. But when I had viewed ≈øo many old Reliques, I was ≈øo weary, that I returned to the Mona≈øtery; and the rather, becau≈øe of the violent heat, with an intent to return another day, and examine all things more exactly.

Tue≈øday the fourth of April, I went with my ordinary Guide to ≈øee the Vadigamus, and the Caves that are there. Vadigamus is a narrow Valley, between two Mountains, which are as high as one another, and flat on the top. This Valley is like a Bugle, from whence I believe this Valley hath borrowed the name; for the word Vadigamus ≈øignifies the Valley of the Bugle. At the beginning it hath a large entrance, which an≈øwers to a great ≈øandy Plain, which is at one ≈øide of the Mona≈øtery of Abuhennis. It ≈øtretches it ≈øelf Southwards, about half an hours travelling over: Afterwards it ri≈øeth by degrees to the top of the Mountains, where it unites and joyns them, and repre≈øents the bottom of a Sack.

On both ≈øides of the≈øe two Mountains that face one another, are two Ranks of Caves, each Rank containing fifty Caves, or thereabouts,
which make one hundred Caves upon each Mountain. I enter'd into ≈øome of them that were ≈øo high, that three long Pikes tyed to one another would not have reach'd to the top: They are very large, but without order within, and uneven, and not perfectly ≈øquare.

I have wondered at the capricious de≈øigns of the Ancient Egyptians, to make ≈øuch wide Caves ≈øo high, and ≈øo numerous, yielding ≈øo little conveniency to the Inhabitants, for they are made upon the ≈øteep Mountains of Sand, far from Towns and Water, digg'd in the dark and main Rocks. If I had not perus'd the Hi≈øtory of Said ibn Patrik, who ≈øaith, that the Pharaoh's, Kings of Egypt, imployed the I≈øraelites in digging in the≈øe Mountains, I ≈øhould be of the opinion of the Country people, who believe that all the≈øe Caves have been made by Devils, who have been thereunto forced by Conjurers, this Art having been always much practis'd in Egypt; for one would think that it is not po≈ø≈øible for men to make them: and I dare ≈øay, that when a Traveller hath ≈øeen all the Curio≈øities of Egypt, if he hath not ≈øeen the≈øe Mountains and Caves of the Province of Thebes, he hath ≈øeen nothing.
Wedne≈øday the fifth of the Month, I went again to In≈øine, to look upon its Ruines with more exactne≈øs, and chiefly upon the Pillars that ≈øtand before the Abulkerun, on the North-we≈øt ≈øide.

There are in all four before the front of this Palace, which heretofore was very magnificent, but now there remains but little, incompa≈ø≈øed about with the Ruines. Two of the≈øe Pillars are on the one ≈øide of the door, and two on the other; three are yet ≈øtanding, only a third part of
the fourth appears: they are made of a certain white ≈øandy ≈øtone, which is taken out of the Mountains near this Town: they are hollow on the ≈øides, from the bottom to the middle, but the re≈øt upwards is ≈ømooth: the bottom or bulk is nigh thirteen foot about; their Capitals are of two pieces, ≈øeven foot in Diameter; every bottom is of five pieces, and every piece is ≈øeven foot long.

There was behind this Palace, on the South-Ea≈øt ≈øide, four other Pillars of the ≈øame bigne≈øs, form, and ≈øub≈øtance; but they are overthrown. I could ≈øcarce di≈øcern where their Ba≈øis ≈øtood: the Pillar of Marcus Aurelius ≈øtands at the North-We≈øt ≈øide of this old Palace.

The ≈øame day I went again to ≈øee the Pillar of Marcus Aurelius; its Ba≈øis is thirteen foot high, made up with eight ranks of ≈øtones; the fir≈øt and lowe≈øt is half in the ground, and half out; the ≈øecond is two foot high; the third a foot and eight inches; the fourth, fifth, and ≈øixth, upon which is the In≈øcription, each two foot and two inches; the ≈øeventh bends out; the eighth is the immediate Ba≈øis upon which the Pillar ≈øtands: This Ba≈øis is five foot long, and two foot and ten inches high; it is ≈øquare in the bottom, in the middle Octogone, or of eight Angles, and in the top Oval: upon this ≈øtone is the bottom of the Pillar, which is made up of five pieces; the lowermo≈øt is beautified with Oaken leaves carved in the ≈øtone; I have never ≈øeen the like el≈øewhere, it is three foot and a half high; the four other pieces are of ≈øeven foot each, and three inches long; the Diameter of the Pillar is of three foot and ≈øeven inches; the Capital is of
one ≈øtone, three foot and an inch high; the Circumference is of ≈øeven foot; upon the Capital ≈øtands an unpoli≈øh'd ≈øtone, four foot and two inches long, and three foot high.

I perceived that in this Town heretofore there hath been two Streets more remarkable than the others; one begun at the Abulkerun, and ended at the four Pillars of Marcus Aurelius, ≈øtretching from Ea≈øt to North. This Street was adorned with two ranks of Pillars, one rank in each ≈øide: the ≈øecond begins at the Arch of Triumph, which is at one end of the Town, at the South-Ea≈øt, drawing to the North-Ea≈øt. The≈øe Streets are very long, large, ≈øtreight, and full of ruines of ≈øtately Palaces.

About three a Clock in the Afternoon, I went the third time to ≈øee the Mona≈øtery digg'd in the Rock, mentioned before. I have always taken a great delight to view it, becau≈øe the ≈øight of it moved my Devotion: It ≈øtands about half an hours travelling a-foot from the Mona≈øtery of Abuhennis, where I was, and Ea≈øt from this Mona≈øtery.

In In≈øine, as well as in the Caves of the Mountains round about, are to be ≈øeen in the ground great Pots, in which the ancient Inhabitants of this Province kept their Wines: They have an Ear at each ≈øide, and are ≈øharp at the bottom, that they might be ≈øixed in the ground: my Guide found many, which he brought to me; but the Wine was dried within, and as black as Pitch: I have ≈øent two of them to Paris.

The ≈øeventh of April, the Good-Friday of the Copties, I went with my Guide to ≈øee the Caves that are near the Mona≈øtery of Amba Bi≈øcioi, about
a mile from the Convent, towards the South.

The fir≈øt remarkable thing that I ≈øaw, was the Hieroglyphick Cave, which the Country people commonly call the Church. I conceive this mi≈øtake proceeds from the Cro≈ø≈øes which are painted every where within.

To go into this Cave, one mu≈øt pa≈øs through another before it. This was heretofore very beautiful and great, but now it is much decayed. The top is fallen down; there remains nothing but the two ≈øide-walls, full of Hieroglyphick Figures graven in the Rock; ≈øome are great, others are little, others are of a moderate ≈øize, but all very clean in good order.

From thence is a pa≈ø≈øage into the Hieroglyphick Cave, which I believe was a Temple of the Heathens: It is ≈øquare, very ≈ømooth within, cut in the Rock, ≈øour Perches long, three Perches and one foot broad, and two Perches high: The door that leads into it is four foot and a half large. In this Cave, over again≈øt the door, is a hole in the Wall, of a Perch and a foot deep, and four foot broad, and a Perch and one foot and eight inches high. This Cave is full of Images in the Walls, and above, which repre≈øent their Sciences by Emblemes, and Hieroglyphick Figures, with very little Characters in their Language round about. The colours of them are ≈øo beautiful and lively, that I could not but wonder how they could continue ≈øo fre≈øh, during ≈øo many Ages.

Be≈øides this great number of Characters there painted, are to be ≈øeen ≈øome lines of the ≈øame little Characters very clean carved in the Wall,
≈øome reaching from one end to the other, others from the top to the bottom. The≈øe Characters, and Figures, are ≈øo numerous, that they are not to be drawn by any in le≈øs than a Months time.

Under the≈øe two Caves there is a rank of others in the Rock, very even within, but they are without Figures, and le≈øs, and not ≈øo high as the former; for they are but ≈øix foot high. In the bottom of every Cave is a Well, ≈øquare, and deep in the Rock, into which one may go down by the means of holes, or ≈øteps, made on purpo≈øe in both ≈øides of every Well. And in the bottom of every Well is an Alley in the Rock, but becau≈øe the≈øe Alleys are durty and ob≈øcure, none of our Company would venture to go down. In the Walls of ≈øome of the≈øe Caves are ≈øquare holes, ≈øix foot deep, and two foot broad, about the bigne≈øs of a Coffin; which makes me believe that the Egyptians did put here their dead in the≈øe Caves.
A little farther, towards the South, is another large Cave. I ≈øaw on the left hand an Hieroglyphick Picture in the Wall, with thirteen lines underneath, of Characters cut in the Picture.

From this Cave, which is at the end of the Mountain, towards the South, we went back to the Mona≈øtery of Abuhennis; and in our way we ≈øaw all the Caves that are in order upon this Mountain, as far as the place where the Vadigamus begins. We ≈øaw no rarity, only ≈øome painted Cro≈ø≈øes, in red, roughly drawn; from whence we gathered, that heretofore they have ≈øerved as Churches.

By the differing Workman≈øhip of the≈øe Caves, one may ea≈øily di≈øtingui≈øh ≈øuch as have been made by the ancient Egyptians, by the Chri≈øtians, and Anchorites that cau≈øed this Province to flouri≈øh;
for the former are very regular, out within, with much care, and ≈ømooth; but the others are rough, and irregular.

And becau≈øe the Country People think that there is no Cave without a rich Trea≈øure, the Arabians have digg'd every where, and ≈øpoil'd al≈øo the Hieroglyphick Cave, which is named the Church. They have ≈øo much undermin'd the Walls that ≈øome of the top is fallen down, and the Rain hath ≈øpoiled ≈øome of the Emblems, and Characters that adorned the Wall. And, as if Time had not blotted out enough, they have put out the Eyes of the Images, and Figures, in a bruti≈øh manner, natural to them. I was highly di≈øpleas'd to ≈øee this; for were it not for this brutality, this beautiful Cave would have kept it ≈øelf‚ñ™ entire till now.

When we had ≈øtaid nine days in the Mona≈øtery of Abuhennis, I return'd to Melave, the 8th of April; from whence I went, the 15th of the ≈øame Month, to Minie, altering my fir≈øt de≈øign to go by Land; for I ≈øaw that it would be too painful, and too dangerous.

Minie, in the Arabian Books called Miniet ibn cha≈ø≈øit, is an ancient, great, and beautiful Town, on the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus. Its Antiquity appears by its old Buildings, by its ≈øtrait Streets, ≈øo narrow that two Men can ≈øcarce to a-brea≈øt. In this Town the Bardaques, or Water-pots, are made, which are highly e≈øteem'd at Cairo, for their fa≈øhion, and property, to cool Water. They are made with a kind of Clay, taken about a days Journey from thence, on the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, in a place called Sciech fadl, from the name of a religious Mahometan there Interr'd.

The 19th of this Month, I went aboard a Ve≈ø≈øel, bound for Bene≈øuef; a good Wind carried us a great way in a little ≈øpace of time. At nine a Clock we were over again≈øt Gebel Teir, or the Mountain of Birds; ≈øo called, becau≈øe at a ≈øet day of the year, all the Birds round about meet in a place, where a Tali≈øman draws them together from all ≈øides, and cau≈øeth them to ≈øtay there one day; when they have continued there till night, they all fly away, one excepted, which remains there, the Bill fixed in the Rock, till the ≈øame day the next year; at which time it falls down, and another takes its place.

When we pa≈øs'd over again≈øt this Mountain, I ≈øaw on the top a Stone, which is called the Camel, becau≈øe, at a di≈øtance, it is like a Camel. A little further in our way, we di≈øcover'd Taka, or the Window, or a great hole which Nature hath made in the Rock, like a Window; which ≈øerves as a pa≈ø≈øage for the Birds when they go to their Rendezvous whither the Tali≈øman draws them, as the People of the Country ≈øay, and their Hi≈øtorians affirm.

When the Moors are come to this Window, they u≈øe to ≈øay the Chapter of the Fatha, or fir≈øt Chapter of the Alcoran, for the poor People, who live, as they ≈øay, in this part of the Mountain, as Bea≈øts, feeding upon nothing but raw Herbs. After Dinner we went by Bene Mohammed il Kifur, a Village ≈øcituate on the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus. Over again≈øt it is an old Mona≈øtery, ruinated; and a little further appear a great many Caves, upon the Mountain near by. After we had pa≈øs'd by an old Ca≈øtle de≈øtroyed, we went to lye at Benemzar, a great Village, ≈øcituate on the We≈øt-≈øide
of Nilus, this River having wa≈øh'd away almo≈øt half the Buildings.

We went from thence, Thur≈øday morning, the 20th of April, with a South-Ea≈øt Wind, fit to carry us to Bene≈øuef. It was yet in the morning when we ≈øailed before Heggiar Selame, which is a Bank in the River Nilus. Over again≈øt it are the Ruines of an ancient Town, and the Tomb of a Sciech, or Saint. About noon we were near the Ruines of another ancient Town, called Medinet Giahel, which ≈øtands at the Ea≈øt of Nilus; there are to be ≈øeen yet ≈øeveral Remains of Hou≈øes, made up with Bricks dried in the Sun. Over again≈øt it is Feggen, a Village often mention'd in a Book called Sinaxar. After Dinner a ≈øtrong Wind aro≈øe, and forced us to ≈øtop at Bebe, a great Village which is near Bene≈øuef, where we found incamped a Troop of Arabians, called Ateijat, with whom I pa≈øs'd the re≈øt of the day in di≈øcour≈øe.
Friday, the 21th of the Month, we arriv'd at Bene≈øuef, where we continued till the next day; and on the 24th of the Month I returned to Caire, without ≈øeeing I≈øne, as I had an intent.

But that the Reader may know what rarities are to be ≈øeen in this Town, and round about, I have here added that which hath been taken notice of by Father Portais, a Capuchin, in the year 1668. according to the account given me by the Reverend Father Francis, his Brother, and Companion in his Travels. M. Thevenot hath already in≈øerted it in his Collection of Travels, printed at Paris, in Folio; but not ≈øo large, nor with th ‚Ä¢ Particulars here added.

Of all the Towns of the Upper Egypt, wher ‚Ä¢
the Copties have Churches, that of I≈øne is the furthe≈øt from Cairo. It is built at the We≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, upon a Hill that ≈øtretches along the River. It may be judged to be an ancient Town, by a Temple of Pagans yet ≈øtanding. The Copties have there two Churches, but very poor; one is dedicated to the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, and the other to S. Pelagius. The Chri≈øtian Copties here may make twenty Caraches in number; they are all Weavers, and ruled by two Arch-Prie≈øts, the one named Matthew, and the other Soliman.

Half a mile from I≈øne is to be ≈øeen a Convent, which the Copties ≈øay hath been built by S. Helena, dedicated to the holy Martyrs of this Town, whom the Governour of Diocle≈øian Ma≈ø≈øacred in ≈øuch numbers, that their dead Corp≈øes covered four≈øcore Fiddans, or Acres of Ground. Round about this Burying-place are to be ≈øeen Tombs curiou≈øly wrought, which they ≈øay were erected by this holy Empre≈øs.

Three leagues from I≈øne is another Convent, dedicated to S. Matthew, where are four or five Tombs, like tho≈øe that we come from mentioning. Upon an Altar Stone of a little Chappel, dedicated to St. Michael the Arch-Angel, we ≈øound ≈øome Characters which were not Hyeroglyphick, in a Language that we under≈øtood not.
About eleven leagues on this ≈øide of I≈øne, at the Ea≈øt of Nilus, is to be ≈øeen Tuot, a great Town, where is a Temple of the ancient Egyptians.

Twelve leagues from Tuot, at the We≈øt of Nilus, is Arment, heretofore a great Town, but now for≈øaken and ruinated. They call it in Arabick Beled Mu≈øe, or the Country of Mo≈øes, becau≈øe the Egyptians believe that Mo≈øes was born here.
Here is under ground an ancient Temple.
Two leagues on this ≈øide of Tuot, are two Villages very famous; namely, Luxor, and Luxor il Kadim, or the old Luxor; they are about half a league from one another.

At Luxor is to be ≈øeen the Remains of an ancient, and beautiful Temple of the Egyptians, in which are three≈øcore and eighteen Pillars of a prodigious bigne≈øs, chiefly fourteen, placed in rank, two and two; ≈øo big that ≈øix Men can ≈øcarce embrace them, but they are but ≈øix Perches high.

The bottom of this Temple is yet entire; here are ≈øeveral Chambers, and ≈øeparations, whereof the Walls are full, from the top to the bottom, of Figures roughly drawn, and Hieroglyphick Letters carved over. Before the Door ≈øtands two Needles, ≈øquare, and very high and entire; ≈øo fre≈øh that one would think that the Workman hath newly fini≈øh'd them. They are on every ≈øide eight foot broad.
Near their Ba≈øis are two Statues of Women, of black Marble; and though they be half under ground, to the Girdle, they ≈øtand out as high as three Men.

Their bigne≈øs is an≈øwerable to their height; for there is twelve foot from one ≈øhoulder to another. They have a ≈øtrange kind of covering upon their heads, with a Globe on the top. Their Faces are disfigur'd, the re≈øt is whole.
The de≈øcription of the Fronti≈øpiece of this Temple, is with the other Pictures.

At the old Luxor is a very ancient Palace. Its Ruines ≈øhew that it hath been very glorious. They ≈øay, that here dwelt one of the ancient Kings of Egypt. In the Walks of this Palace are to be ≈øeen
many Sphinxes, in ranks, on both ≈øides of the Alleys, two foot from one another, looking upon the Alley. They have every one, one and twenty foot in length. This Palace hath four Walks, that an≈øwer to four Gates. In the fir≈øt are one hundred and twenty Sphinxes, three≈øcore in each ≈øide; and in the ≈øecond are one hundred and two, one and fifty in a≈øide. Every Walk is about the length of a place to play at Mall. the Gates of the Palace are extraordinary high, made with the mo≈øt beautiful Stones in the World; one of the ≈øides of the Gate is ≈øix and twenty foot high. (I find in another Copy of this Relation, that it hath thirty ≈øix foot.) The Palace is ≈øo defaced, that there is no order, nor beauty, that appears; neverthele≈øs there are ≈øo many curious things in it, that no Man in a Month, can take a full view of them; for there is above a Million of Figures, roughly drawn; ≈øome are covered over, others appear with an open face. Here are al≈øo a great many Pillars; I counted, ≈øaith the Father, in a Parlour three≈øcore, which are all ≈øo great, that five Men can ≈øcarce embrace one of them about.

In the Court of the Palace is a Ba≈øon garni≈øhed about with beautiful Stones, and full of a bitter VVater, which, as the People ≈øay, whitens Linen very well. I tried it, ≈øaith the Father, by dipping into it my Handkerchief, which kept above four days the ≈ømell of Soap. At one Front of the Palace are two Statues of a Giant, of one Stone, as white as Alaba≈øter. They have Swords by their ≈øides. In the middle of the Palace is another, as high as three Men, not well polli≈øh'd, but well proportioned.

A league on this ≈øide there is an ancient Town,
called Habu, where are to be ≈øeen many rarities, chiefly Mommies. At a di≈øtance one may there di≈øcover two Statues; one of a Man, the other of a VVoman. The Country People call that Sciama, and this Tama, They ≈øeem to be at lea≈øt as big as the Abulhon, or the Sphinx over again≈øt Cairo. Near this place is a Village, where is to be ≈øeen two Statues from the River Nilus, ≈øo new that one would think the Workman had ju≈øt perfected them.

Thirteen leagues on this ≈øide of the old Luxor, is a Town named Neggade, where is a Bi≈øhop with about ≈øeventy Families of Chri≈øtian Copties. Here is yet three Mona≈øteries, one is called Deir il Salib, or the Mona≈øtery of the holy Cro≈øs; the ≈øecond Deir il Megma; the third Deir Mary Poctor; but the≈øe two la≈øt are not inhabited.
Two miles from Neggade, on the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Nilus, is the ancient Town of Kus; but here are but three≈øcore Chri≈øtian Copties, who have here a Church, dedicated to S. Stephen.

Six leagues from Neggade, on this ≈øide, is Kenne, a Village ≈øcituate on the Ea≈øtern Bank of Nilus. It is a Mart-Town, and the Rendezvous of the Caravans that go from Cairo to Co≈ø≈øeir, heretofore named Berenice, four days Journies from this Village, and a Haven of the Red-Sea. The Chri≈øtians that live at Kenne are very poor, and without any Church.

Two leagues on this ≈øide of Kenne is the ancient Town of Tentiris, now called Dendera, where is a wonderful Temple of the ancient Egyptians, of a prodigious bigne≈øs and height. It is to be ≈øeen at two leagues di≈øtance.

Macrizi ≈øaith, that it hath as many Windows
as there are days in the year: They are ≈øo plac'd, that every one an≈øwers to a degree of the Zodiack; ≈øo that the Sun ri≈øing in a differing degree every day of the Zodiack, it ≈øends in its Beams into a di≈øtinct Window from the day before: And when at the end of the year it hath fini≈øh'd and run through every degree of the Zodiack, it hath al≈øo from the Ea≈øt ca≈øt in its Beams into every Window of this Temple: For this cau≈øe it is look'd upon as a Wonder in Egypt.

Ten Leagues on this ≈øide of Dendera, at the We≈øt of Nilus, is Ca≈ø≈ør, a Village where is an old Convent, dedicated to Amba Balamon: Over again≈øt this Village is the ancient Town Hu, where is yet a Convent dedicated to S. Menna, but there was then no Prie≈øt.

Two Leagues on this ≈øide of Hu, on the ≈øame Bank is Bahgiura, at a little di≈øtance from the River: Its Port is called Sahel; there is two Convents, one dedicated to S. Bidabe, the other to S. George. At two Leagues on this ≈øide of Bahgiura, on the ≈øame Bank, is the Village Beliene, where is a very beautiful Church under ground, dedicated to the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin. Girge, the chief Town of the ∆≤pper Egypt, ≈øtands ≈øix Leagues from Beliene on this ≈øide.

Here ends the Relation of Father Portais. I could wi≈øh that this good man had given us a more exact account, and more at large of the Rarities that he ≈øaw in the≈øe places, for this Relation is ≈øuperficial.

The 14th of June, I went at Cairo to ≈øee the Inchanted watering place, called in Arabick, Houd il mera≈ø≈øet, which is under the Mo≈øque of the Palace,
called Kalet it Keb≈øch, no Taveller hath over ≈øpoken of it.

It is a black Marble-≈øtone, made like a Watering place, ≈øeven foot long, ari≈øing out of the ground about a foot and a half: The ≈øides, within and without, are adorned with little Hieroglyphick Letters, as well as the Brims. The people of Cairo ≈øay, that in the time of the ancient Egyptians, the ≈øick people did recover their health by drinking Water out of it; and that by the virtue of a Ra≈ø≈øem, or Charm, which the Prie≈øts of Egypt had given to it.

The 20th of this Month I went to ≈øee the wonderful Well which is in the Ca≈øtle, commonly named Jo≈øeph's Well. Its top is ≈øquare, very large, cut in the Rock; it is about one hundred and twenty Perches deep, the Perch containing ≈øix foot. The water is drawn out with two Wheels, the one plac'd at the Mouth of the Well, and the other about three≈øcore and fifteen Perches underneath. There are two Oxen at each Wheel to turn them; the lowe≈øt, which is fifty Perches above the water, ≈øerves to draw the water into a Ba≈øon there on purpo≈øe; and from thence, the upper Wheel draws the water to the top. The Bea≈øts that work there, go up and down very commodiou≈øly by a great large Path, which receives the light through Windows cut on that ≈øide which looks to the water.

The Arabian Authors call it Bir haleizun, or the Snails Well, becau≈øe there is a Path-way that winds round about. The people commonly ≈øay, that it was digg'd by Spirits; I am almo≈øt inclineable to believe it, for I cannot conceive how men can compa≈øs ≈øo wonderful a work.

The Waters, as the Guardian told me, come out of the firm Rock, and yet increa≈øe and decrea≈øe as the River Nilus: But I have heard others ≈øay, that they come out of the great Aqueduct which is in old Cairo. Becau≈øe I could not under≈øtand the truth of it, I wi≈øh that ≈øome other Traveller would inform him≈øelf better.

They that think that Jo≈øeph, Jacob's Son, cau≈øed it to be digged, are deceived, for the Ca≈øtle of Cairo was built many Ages after Jo≈øeph's death; and it is the common opinion of all the Arabian Authors, that Jo≈øeph dwelt at Memphis, which was on the other ≈øide of the River, near the Pynamids, and not on this ≈øide where Cairo ≈øtands.

The 9th of this Month they cryed about Town Ouf alla, that the River was ri≈øen ≈øixteen Cubits high. The next day, being S. Laurences day, they cut through the Calitz with Ceremony; but there was no great rejoycings, becau≈øe the Pacha had ob≈øerv'd that before, and every Pacha performs it but once in his time.

On the 18th of the ≈øame Month there happen'd a mi≈øchance to a French Merchant, which di≈øcovers the wonderful jealou≈øie of the Turks. As this Merchant was taking the air at a Window of his hou≈øe in the Even, on the Calitz ≈øide, a Jani≈ø≈øary that lived over again≈øt him, thinking that he made ≈øigns to his Women and Slaves, ≈øhot off a Pi≈øtol at him, and wounded him in the hand. The French Con≈øul could never obtain from the Ju≈øtice of Cairo to cau≈øe this Villain to be puni≈øh'd.

On the fir≈øt of September, Mon≈øieur de Bonnecor≈øe, before Con≈øul of Seyda, ≈øucceeded to Mon≈øieur
de Tyger, before Con≈øul at Cairo, and landed at Boulac, in the company of many great Merchants, upon a great Bark well trim'd, with a Flag of the Arms of France on the Main Ma≈øt.

At his arrival he ≈øaluted Boulac with five little Bra≈øs-Pieces of Canon, which were at the Stern of his Ship. He landed not at the Douane, for the Con≈øuls are free from that Vi≈øit, but in a plea≈øant hou≈øe upon the River, near the Douane, until he had got leave from the Pacha to go to Cairo. As ≈øoon as he had received it, he mounted on Hor≈øeback without more ado, and rode into the City, with all the Merchants of his Nation riding on A≈ø≈øes. The Pacha ≈øent none to bid him welcome; only the Venetian Con≈øul ≈øent his Servants to meet him, and his Hor≈øe.
The ≈øame day, one of tho≈øe Swimmers, whom I have already mentioned, ≈øwum all along the Calitz, according to the Cu≈øtom.
On the ≈øeventh of the Month, Ibrahim Pacha went from Cairo in Pomp.
On the 29th, I went with Mon≈øieur Bonnecor≈øe to Adelia, a Suburb of Cairo, on the North-Ea≈øt ≈øide, where are the Tombs of the Kings of Egypt, to ≈øee the coming in of the new Pacha.
It is not ami≈øs to mention here two Cu≈øtoms, which all the Pacha's ought to ob≈øerve when they come fir≈øt to this Government, and when they leave it.

Every Pacha, before he enters into Cairo, is bound to vi≈øit the Tomb of Sciech il Sciafei, who is buried in the Caraffe, for he is the Protector of the Ottoman Family; for the Turks following the Doctrines of the Mahometan Religion, believe
that he is able to obtain for them from their Prophet, a happy and peaceable Government: And when they depart, they are bound to render the ≈øame re≈øpects to the Tomb of Sultan Cajed Bey, though an Enemy of the Ottoman Race, and one of the la≈øt lawful Kings of Egypt, to thank him, becau≈øe he had ≈øuffered his Government to be without di≈øorders and di≈øgrace.

The≈øe two Cu≈øtoms are ≈øo Religiou≈øly to be ob≈øerved by the Pacha's that the people of Cairo ≈øay, that they have ≈øeen ≈øome that have neglected or contemned them, to have been ≈øuddenly depo≈øed, and to have met with unhappine≈øs in their time.

I have heard ≈øay, that when Sultan Selimus had overcome the Mamelucs, he was afraid to go into Cairo, to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Conque≈øt, till Sciech il Sciafei appeared to him, to a≈ø≈øure him, that he need not fear any thing. And that the next day when he made his Entry, an unknown per≈øon led his Hor≈øe by the Bridle into the Town, and then vani≈øh'd away.

When I had continued in ≈øo incommodious a City, as Cairo is to the Francs, twenty Months, the fear of ≈øome mi≈øhap which might have befallen me if the Turks had known that I bought up their Books, cau≈øed me to think upon my departure; and to ≈øecure my ≈øelf, I imagin'd Con≈øtantinople to be the mo≈øt fit for my purpo≈øe. I re≈øolved therefore to go thither: I left Cairo the 12th of October, 1673. to ≈øail to Ro≈øetta; and becau≈øe the River was then fulle≈øt, a good Wind and a ≈øtrong Current carried us thither in two Nights and a day. From thence, I went aboard the ≈øame
day in a Ve≈ø≈øel of a Greek bound for Con≈øtantinople. I landed at Chio, an I≈øland of the Archipelague, the 25th of November, where I ≈øtaid two Months and a few days, wondering at the delight≈øomne≈øs of this I≈øland, and at the Civility of the Inhabitants to Strangers: I went to vi≈øit tho famous Mona≈øtery of the Religious Greeks of Neamoni, or of the Ble≈ø≈øed and Only Virgin: I ≈øaw the Library, and all the other Rarities of the I≈øland. From thence I went to Smyrna, the 27th of January, 1674. where I arrived the ≈øecond of February, and ≈øtaid till the 13th of March. Then I went aboard with Sir John Finch, the King of Englands Emba≈ø≈øadour of Con≈øtantinople, where I arrived the 24th of March, being Holy Saturday.

The 24th of July I went from Con≈øtantinople to the City Brou≈ø≈øe, called by the Europeans Bur≈øia, the chief Town of Bythinia, and the ancient Seat of the Ottoman Emperours, to ≈øee the Hot Baths, the Tombs, and the ≈øtately Mo≈øques of the≈øe Emperours: I ≈øtaid there about eight days. On the fourth of September I went to the I≈øle of Chio the ≈øecond time, to ≈øee the gathering up of the Ma≈øtick, a ≈øweet Gum, which begins the 14th of this Month, according to the Greek computation; and the 28th of October I returned to Con≈øtantinople.

On the ≈øecond of January, 1676. the day that I was to depart with the Caravan to Aleppo, that I might return the third time to Cairo, I found my ≈øelf oblig'd to go back for France; and becau≈øe there was then no French Ships in that Haven bound for France, only a ≈ømall Bark loaden
and bound for Lisbon, which was gone out of the Haven to wait for a good wind at the I≈ølands near by. I went aboard that Ve≈ø≈øel, with an intent to leave her at the fir≈øt Port of the Archipelague, where I might find ≈øome French Ve≈ø≈øel bound for France. I found one according to my de≈øire; for a furious Storm forced us to run into Suda, in the I≈øland of Candy. The 18th of this Month, I had news from the French Con≈øul of Canea, that there was a Ve≈ø≈øel of Provence ready to ≈øet Sail for Thoulon; I left therefore my Bark, to ride to Canea, in the company of many Per≈øons on Hor≈øeback, whom the Con≈øul ≈øent to meet me. The 24th we ≈øet fail for Milo, where we arrived the 26th day of the Month: There we ≈øtopt eight days. The 20th of February we landed at Genoa, where we ≈øtaid one day; and the 24th of this Month we arrived happily at Thoulon, and the 22th of April I returned to Paris, after five full years Travelling.
